TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray; that you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Services and Health Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, beseech you to oppose the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, Part 3, No. 10 Section 3F, 3G, 3H.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Insurance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senate assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate that the Government is about to introduce into the Senate, legislation changing health insurance. These changes will increase the cost of health insurance to members of employee based funds and will do nothing to help the elderly, as is being claimed. Big public funds will increase their surpluses by taking money from more efficient funds. People will be forced back onto Medicare, which will not help to maintain private health insurance.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate reject this legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Leonid Yakovich Lubman
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned shows:
1 Leonid Yakovich Lubman, electronics engineer, was born on 5 March 1936 in the Soviet Union.

2 He is believed to have been arrested on or about 29 August 1977 and to have been charged under Article 64 (a) of the RSFSR Criminal Code with Treason and Slander of the USSR and to have been sentenced to 13 years strict regime.
3 He is presently believed to be in Prison Camp 35, and it is believed that he is due to be released on 29 August 1990.

4 He has, whilst in prison, undergone extreme suffering and is in poor health and is grossly undernourished. He is believed, inter alia, to be suffering from stomach, lung and liver pain; intensive headaches and blackouts; hunger pains and partial paralysis.

Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should make a formal request to the diplomatic representatives of the USSR in Australia on behalf of the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia on humanitarian grounds for the immediate release of Leonid Yakovich Lubman.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 344 citizens) and Reid (from 96 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Royal Australian College of General Practitioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned oppose the proposal to introduce financial disincentives, through disproportionate Medicare rebates to general practitioners who choose not to become fellows of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners in the interests of patient care.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of the Bill is to remove section 41 of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 which exempts from the operation of the Act discrimination in superannuation on the ground of sex or marital status and to insert a number of more limited exemptions dealing with superannuation practices and prohibits discrimination by persons conferring dependant superannuation benefits. As section 41 also provides an exemption in regard to the terms on which insurance may be offered, the amendments have necessitated that the insurance exemption be rewritten and reinserted.

The process which has led to the Bill dates back to the preparation of a report by the Human Rights Commission titled ``Superannuation and Insurance and the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 Part 1-Superannuation.'' That report was prepared in response to a request by the then Attorney-General, Senator the Hon. Gareth Evans, and was tabled in Parliament on 25 November 1986. The report was considered by the Government and the Government decided to remove the exemption and to insert into the Act certain more limited exemptions for particular practices in superannuation. Following the Government's decision, consultations on the proposed exemptions were held with the superannuation industry, employer groups, State and Territory Governments and the ACTU.

The Government, as indicated in its National Agenda for Women, is committed to the objective of removing discrimination in superannuation on the grounds of sex, marital status and pregnancy. The major effect of the Bill is to remove most forms of direct discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status in superannuation practices for new schemes.

Where funds are unable to comply with the new obligations under the legislation, the reasonable expectations of the members will be maintained and the discriminatory fund will be allowed to continue. However such funds will not be entitled to admit new members. Further, members of such discriminatory schemes will generally have to be given an option to obtain ``non-discriminatory superannuation benefits''.
The proposed continuing exemptions, shortly stated, deal with the following areas:
the inclusion in fund conditions of a provision which is based upon reasonable actuarial data upon which it is reasonable to reply.

the current practices whereby lesser death and disability benefits are provided to members who are single, that is members who do not have a spouse or a de facto spouse or to members who do not have a child.
the possibly discriminatory effect of current vesting, preservation and portability arrangements in funds' conditions.

The introduction of the Bill has been delayed to date pending the reappraisal by the Government of a proposed exemption which would have allowed funds to confine the provision of superannuation benefits to permanent and full-time employees. In January 1989 the Government decided not to proceed with this exemption. Following that decision a further round of consultations on the issue was held with the superannuation industry, peak employer bodies, State Governments and the National Women's Consultative Council. Those consultations have only recently been completed.

I turn now to a brief description of the proposed limited exemptions to be inserted in the Act. Because, statistically, women live longer than men, the actuarial exemption covers the resulting difference in costs of providing a pension for women. Schemes will be able to continue to offer optional conversions between lump sums and pensions which differ by sex, so long as the difference is based on reliable actuarial data. As many superannuation benefits are provided via insurance this exemption is interlinked with the insurance exemption.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission is currently preparing a Report on the exemption of insurance from the Sex Discrimination Act. The need for the actuarial exemption for superannuation will be reviewed in light of the Commission's recommendations concerning the insurance exemption.

The exemption for dependent superannuation benefits is designed to allow schemes to continue current practices, whereby upon a member's death or disability no benefits are payable to a member who does not have a spouse or children. In the absence of this kind of exemption it may have been possible for a member who was single to succeed in a complaint of marital status discrimination. There are a number of reasons for maintaining this exemption. As the former Human Rights Commission noted in its Report, the exemption reflects the community's attitude that it is appropriate to make special provision for persons who have a spouse or who have children in the event of the death, or physical or mental incapacity of the members of superannuation funds. As was noted by the Commission, to provide benefits to all dependents of members on proof of financial dependency, would create difficulties both in administration and in finding a suitable objective test of ``dependency''.

In regard to the exemptions dealing with vesting, preservation and portability, the issue of discrimination arises because there is evidence that women statistically do not remain in continuous employment for the same length of time as men. Matters such as vesting, preservation and portability fall within the area of the operating standards for superannuation funds administered by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. Regulations made under the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 impose a number of operating standards with which superannuation funds must comply in order to be eligible for taxation concessions.

I am advised that current vesting standards require a superannuation fund to vest in full in a member all benefits arising from contributions made by the member and earnings thereon. The effect of this is that all member-financed benefits are fully vested.
The preservation standards which require benefits to be preserved generally until retirement at or after the age of 55, apply to the following benefits (except for amounts less than $500):

any vested employer-financed benefits arising from employer contributions made in accordance with an agreement or award certified or made by an industrial authority (ie the 3 per cent award based superannuation); and
any new or improved vested employer-financed benefits arising from any arrangements entered into after 21 December 1986.

The preservation standards do not extend to vested employer-financed benefits flowing from ongoing superannuation arrangements which were in place prior to 22 December 1986. They also do not extend to member-financed benefits arising from member contributions which are non-tax deductible made to employer sponsored funds.

As part of its review of retirement income policy, the Government is looking at the question of whether improved vesting and preservation standards should be developed in respect of superannuation funds. The issues are discussed in Social Security Review Issues Paper No. 6, ``Towards a National Retirement Income Policy,'' which was released for public comment last year. Submissions and comments on the paper are currently in the process of being assessed by the Government. It is to be noted that any improvements that are introduced would have the effect of reducing any indirect discrimination in vesting and preservation arrangements.

The Bill also provides in clause 3a that section 14 of the Principal Act will be amended to make it unlawful for a person who exercises a discretion in relation to the payment of a dependant superannuation benefit, for a member of a superannuation fund to which the provisions of 41a of the Bill apply, to discriminate on the grounds of sex and marital status. The purpose of this provision is to ensure that trustees, when deciding who should receive such benefits, consider the circumstances of all the potential beneficiaries rather than making their decision purely on the basis of a person's marital status. For example, it will not be lawful to pay a death benefit to a current de facto spouse, purely because of a fund policy to always pay such benefits to the current spouse.

I now turn to the provisions of the Bill which are designed to protect the existing expectations of members in superannuation schemes. Proposed section 41b will enable schemes which cannot or do not wish to comply with the new requirements of s41a to continue to provide benefits for existing members, providing that members of these funds have the option to obtain non-discriminatory superannuation benefits. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission may however grant an exemption from this requirement pursuant to section 44 of the Sex Discrimination Act. This will enable trustees or employers to apply for an exemption where it is clear that it would not be beneficial for members to join a new scheme or obtain non-discriminatory benefits. It will not be necessary that members actually be offered the opportunity to join a new scheme, as it will be sufficient, for the purposes of the option, that existing members be offered the option to obtain benefits which would comply with proposed s41a.

Proposed section 41c will enable regulations to be made to repeal section 41a or 41b. This provision reflects the Government's commitment to progressively moving to a truly non-discriminatory superannuation industry. This provision continues the status of existing subsection s.41 (1) of the Act which could be repealed by regulation. The Government believes that this provision will encourage the superannuation industry to progressively remove discrimination in the terms upon which superannuation is offered. Regulations under s.41c will only be able to be made after consultation with industry and will not come into operation until 1 year after their making.

The proposals put forward in this Bill should not impact upon Government expenditure. However it is anticipated that Commonwealth schemes will be amended in separate legislation to comply with the Act by the time of the commencement of the amending Act. These changes may have some effect on Commonwealth expenditure.

Superannuation is a very technical area of the law and the issues of discrimination which may arise may vary from case to case and industry to industry. The Attorney-General has therefore written to the Sex Discrimination Commissioner requesting that guidelines be published on issues which have not been specifically addressed in these amendments. Where trustees or employers feel that they should be exempted from a particular requirement of the Act they may apply to the Commission for an administrative exemption under s.44 of the Sex Discrimination Act. Decisions by the Commission under s.44 are reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The Government believes that the amendments outlined above represent a significant reform. While I am informed that most schemes will be able to comply with the new amendments with only minor adaptations to their existing conditions, the amendments will require schemes which have not yet improved their benefits to do so over the next two years, or to close off their membership. Further the amendments are likely to increase the opportunity for part-time employees to gain access to superannuation. This will significantly improve the opportunities for women to build up a worthwhile superannuation entitlement over their working lives. A large majority of part-time employees are women and it is clear that women tend to return from child rearing to part-time employment. Where part-time employees are performing the same duties as their full-time counterparts and the full-time counterparts receive superannuation, it is likely that a Court would find that a failure to provide access to superannuation to such part-time employees unlawfully discriminatory.

These amendments should therefore be viewed in light of the Government's commitment to increasing superannuation coverage for the Australian workforce. Arbitrated superannuation awards are providing increasing superannuation coverage. These amendments will not only encourage this development and help Australia make appropriate provision for its ageing population, but the benefits which will be offered will be fairer and more equitable and in line with the Government's commitments under the National Agenda for Women.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to order of the Senate of 10 April 1989, the resumption of the debate shall be an order of the day for the first day of sitting in August 1989.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN TELECOMMUNICATIONS CORPORATION BILL 1989AUSTRALIAN POSTAL CORPORATION BILL 1989TELECOMMUNICATIONS AND POSTAL SERVICES (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1989TELECOMMUNICATIONS BILL 1989TELECOMMUNICATIONS (APPLICATION FEES) BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 6 June.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS BILL 1989
The Bill.
Bill agreed to.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS (APPLICATION FEES) BILL 1989
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 2, paragraphs 4 (2) (a) to (d), , lines 8 to 14, leave out the paragraphs.

The Opposition moves this one amendment to the Telecommunications (Application Fees) Bill in relation to the payment of fees. The whole reason for this Bill is to justify the excessively bureaucratic structure which has now been put in place, requiring the granting of permits, variations of permits and licences, supposedly in the name of regulating the industry. But from our perspective, and I believe from the perspective of the market, it is a cumbersome and unnecessary approach.

There are essentially two ways that one can go in seeking to scrutinise an industry which is dynamic and fast moving. One is to take the bureaucratic approach, whereby we keep a piece of paper attached to everything that moves and closely scrutinise any changes which might be sought by way of application for variation of licences and permits. The other way is to stand back and take essentially the market approach, which would involve simply taking action where it is necessary. We do not see that there are any players in the game who are likely to transgress deliberately. To the extent that they accidentally did so, they would be very susceptible to advice proffered by Austel. If they were to disregard such advice, they could clearly have action taken against them by way of Federal Court injunctions or actions for damages in due course by any one of the carriers. We think that regime would effectively ensure that there was proper scrutiny of the industry and, therefore, an adequate degree of supervision. We do not think the bureaucratic solution, which involves a whole series of permits, licences and variations, is necessary. This Bill is just a self-serving excuse to justify that regime by imposing licence fees which can then be used to fund the additional public servants who will be required to supervise the licences. Therefore, we have moved that paragraphs 4 (2) (a) to 4 (2) (d) inclusive be deleted from clause 4. That would mean that there would not be a need for the payment of fees in respect of value added services, private network services, or customer premise equipment, or, indeed, for variation or registration of those services.

Of course, we understand that if one is committed to such a regime, one will obviously want to tax it to garner revenue to fund that bureaucratic solution. The Government and the Democrats have combined to ensure that that sort of regime remains in place. Nonetheless, we want to make it clear that we do not approve of that solution or see the need for the payment of fees. We would certainly move accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats do not support this amendment. It is another in the category of amendments-of which there have been many in the process of debating this package-in which Senator Alston is putting to us a new twist on an old story. The new twist is that he is saying, `Trust us; we are not from the Government'. Basically, he is suggesting, as he did in relation to another amendment last evening, that we ought to take self-regulation on trust and that those private sector groups which in a sense are going to plug in to the public network can be trusted not to do anything that would be unacceptable or damaging to the network, which they will feed on and out of which they will make profits. In typical fashion, Senator Aston proposes, by way of this amendment, that no system will regulate that process or charge fees appropriately for that sector which is going to use a publicly provided infrastructure facility by way of the communications network.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to delay the Committee unnecessarily but I have to correct what I presume is yet another accidental distortion or misunderstanding. I put to the Committee that there is an alternative regime that involves overall supervision and requires Austel to exercise its statutory obligations and to take action where necessary. Clearly Senator Powell is not aware of the long and protracted debate in the United States of America over the last decade or more involving what was colloquially known as `harms to the network'. The outcome of that was that there were very few instances of any carrier or provider of telecommunications services wishing deliberately to sabotage the network or infringe beyond the letter of the law. The simple reason for that, and the reason why we say one can trust the market-in contradistinction to the Australian Democrats, who have a deep and abiding hatred of anything that is market-oriented and believe that the only solution is one predicated upon continued market failure-and the proper solution, is that we do have a regulator with absolute powers where necessary to take action to restrain.

SPEECH.PARA: That in itself is perhaps the single most powerful instrument if it is necessary to deter improper behaviour. But at the end of the day, if people are in the business for the long term, surely it is in their own self-interest not to do anything that would damage the integrity of the network or to infringe beyond a network boundary. Otherwise people will find themselves involved in protracted litigation and, at worst, put out of business.

There will be a number of cases at the margin, especially with technological change occurring as rapidly as it is, where it will be necessary to have test cases to define those boundaries. The way to do that has got nothing to do with the imposition of licence fees, permit fees and variation fees; it has got a lot to do with making judgments about where the boundary line ought to be drawn. That can be done just as simply by people approaching Austel for advice and, if necessary, Austel seeking restraining orders until the position is clarified. None of that has anything to do with fund raising.

This whole regime which is predicated on the need to somehow be involved in every bit of change and movement in the industry can only slow down the process and ultimately only result in Telecom being made prematurely aware of any changes in the system. This will give it not only the first mover advantage but also a decidedly unfair advantage in terms of its privileged access to information. I do not have the blind confidence that Senator Powell seems to have that we can assume Chinese Walls in Telecom but we should not trust anyone out in the marketplace. If anything, I think the situation ought to be reversed, simply because of the structural dynamics. There are inevitable and irresistible temptations for a monopolist to abuse that market power.

Anyone who is familiar with the Tytel case will know that Telecom persisted in maintaining that it was not susceptible to the Trade Practices Act and engaged in an elaborate regime of locating equipment manufacturing offshore and importing from places which would minimise the duty payable. I would have thought that Senator Powell would regard that as anti-social behaviour. But no, she will undoubtedly spring to the defence of Telecom and say that anything that a public sector entity does is right and proper by definition; while anything that the private sector does must be treated with deep and abiding mistrust. We say that is not so. The incentive structures operate in quite the opposite direction. Telecom, as a monopolist, is put into that invidious situation where the temptation is irresistible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think Senator Powell has a political motive on this?

—I can only suspect that Senator Powell thinks there is a constituency out there, that if she can frighten the pants off enough nervous Nellies they will come scurrying back and say, `We must maintain Telecom, irrespective of the inefficiencies and the level of cost that consumers have to pay. What we will do is beat up a big scare campaign about privatisation'. That is perhaps a fairly shabby and predictable political strategy, which Senator Messner quite rightly identifies, but I regard it as totally dishonourable and indicative of the sort of expedient and opportunistic political approach that the Democrats take to this issue. They have shown no willingness at all to come to grips with very complex issues and understand the complexities of the market. They have shown no ability to comprehend the experiences of other Western countries which have gone down this very same path and have no apparent awareness that throughout the rest of the Western world the telecommunications industry is being opened up on all fronts to the point where, once this package goes through, Australia will now have the most conservative and regulated telecommunications environment amongst the developed countries of the Western world.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Powell seems utterly oblivious to any of that. She does not understand why it is happening. She probably thinks that it should be treated with suspicion and distrust. She is obviously not concerned with what we are concerned about, which is to introduce as much competition as possible in order to drive down the cost of the services and minimise the inefficiencies that palpably exist, even on Telecom's own concessions, in the customer access network and the way in which the first mainframe monopoly has operated to date. Senator Powell's uncritical approach is not shared by anyone in industry or business or anyone who has any understanding of the telecommunications industry around the world. It is a cheap, populist approach, a frantic endeavour to somehow whip up a bit of a scare campaign and pretend that the Democrats are the big, bold defenders of Australia's largest business entity. If they are in the business of supporting big business without criticism, I am very interested to hear about it. But, of course, they are not; they spend most of their time deploring multinationals and trying to kick all the larger--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is only big government businesses they support.

—That is right. All the larger business enterprises, if they are in the private sector, are by definition threatening and dishonest and need to be restrained at all costs. Of course, the Democrats will be vigilant in making sure that there are no excesses or tax minimisation schemes, that there is no unfair treatment of employees and that big business operates properly and fairly. But when it comes to public sector big business the Australian Democrats have never a word of criticism, even to the point where we had that pathetic display last night of Senator Jenkins wandering in here to retail some anecdotes about her own experiences in Western Australia. That was all in order to demonstrate that somehow Telecom is beyond reproach. I want to make it clear that we have said time and again that Telecom has a very efficient board, and it has some top people in its management structures. It is an enterprise poised to go. It is a tiger in a cage and this Government will not let it out of the cage. If it were able to get out and perform in the competitive jungle it would do very nicely indeed. One has only to look at the experiences of NTT and American Telephone and Telegraph, or AT and T, to see what first mover advantage is all about. The dominant carrier will continue to dominate the industry. There is no suggestion that Telecom will be under threat. As I have said repeatedly, Telecom has money coming out its ears. If it can keep its net operating profit this year below $1 billion, I will be amazed and I will want to call in the stewards and check its accounting procedures.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, yet again the Democrats seem determined to misunderstand the approach that economic rationalists on all sides of the political spectrum except the far Left-that clearly includes the Democrats in this instance-appreciate is necessary. Unfortunately the Government is hidebound and constrained, as it has been in a whole range of areas when it has attempted to embark on meaningful micro-economic reform. The great tragedy is that it did not even bother to try in this area. The conservatives have held the day from the outset. Mr Willis, I am sure, has no thought at all of looking positively at what is happening around the world. Obviously the Democrats are not interested in finding out about it. To the extent that they do, they simply see in it more evidence that the citadel is crumbling and they are determined to go on with their uncritical defence of government business enterprises. We are not in the business of putting them out of business; we are in the business of making them more efficient and more competitive. We do not believe that this new regime of wholesale licences and payment of fees at all stages will do anything to free up the industry or to ensure that consumers and telecommunications customers get a better deal. I regret that the Democrats are not prepared to read or understand about this very involved and difficult area. I sympathise with Senator Powell to the extent that she has a number of portfolio responsibilities. Whenever I attempt to discuss these matters with her, there is always something else on her plate. That is regrettable, but it should not be any basis for her coming in here and pontificating about solutions to difficult problems in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —She is not Robinson Crusoe in pontificating.

—I am sure that Senator Button has been explaining that to his colleague. I know it is regrettable that Senator Evans dumped on Senator Button yesterday the debate we had on the airlines. I suppose he had a word to him about it before he left. At the end of the day one would hope that logic and reason does prevail in the majority of debates in this place. As far as I am concerned, the Opposition can feel very comfortable indeed when it comes to the debate on the telecommunications industry. We have the rest of the world on our side, we have all the intelligent commentators on our side, we have all the industries on our side and we know what is involved in a competitive marketplace.
—What about God?
—We have had a word to him. I can assure the Minister that he is officially neutral, but he is really barracking for us.
—That is a breach of the Electoral Act.
—Is it? If the Minister would like to refer it to the ecclesiastical jurisdiction perhaps we could arrange for separate representation.
—Only you would take the brief.

—We would certainly have to negotiate a proper fee. We do not regard anything that the Democrats have said as casting any criticisms upon the approach that we have taken to the payment of fees or indeed to the overall approach to competition that we think is necessary. We regret that the Government finds it necessary simply to placate other factions in its ranks and has never been prepared to bite the competitive bullet in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had an interesting third reading stage speech from Senator Alston which was mainly aimed I thought not so much at the amendment but at heaping abuse on the Australian Democrats with the tried and true method that they are much more sensitive than anyone else here and that if one abuses them long enough they will eventually agree to one of the amendments. There is not much point in doing it to our side because we are not so sensitive to these matters. What we saw in this particular contribution from Senator Alston did not have much relevance to this clause. Nevertheless it summed up his frustration. It was only a week ago that he stood in this chamber and accused me of spitting out the dummy. I tell Senator Alston that his performance on this Bill--
—I didn't use that term.

—Senator Alston described my reaction as a fit of pique among other things on the immigration issue. Senator Alston's advice was not to get so personally involved and upset about it. Basically what Senator Alston did-I have commended him for it before-was go to an adult education course on Telecom at Monash University, my old alma mater. One thing Senator Alston should also have done at the same time there was Statistics 1. He would have then realised that he cannot win with 34 votes and I would not have sore feet from walking to 22 divisions last night. But we are straying a fraction from the amendment. Basically the argument was put last night. If Senator Alston had won the argument last night his amendment would have great rationality. But he did not. Where a beneficiary of government regulatory action can be identified, it is our policy to recover costs when we are providing that particular benefit. We also argued that fees are not onerous and that the Government can see no good reason for not applying them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will spare the Committee any elaborate defence. However, I would like to point out that Senator Alston's remarks about the general handling of this legislation need some response. I find them extraordinarily patronising apart from being a demonstration, to use his words, of fits of pique. Just because people do not agree with Senator Alston does not mean that they have not discussed and considered the issues concerned. All he can say with any accuracy is that he was not agreed with on this occasion. That is factual. The rest of it is a load of garbage arising from the fact that Senator Alston is obviously not satisfied with having tied up the Parliament for an inordinate length of time and also he has had to find some sort of whipping person and he has found him. Fair enough. I do not accept the patronising approach that suggests that the Democrats had too much to do. Certainly he may feel a bit put upon that people do not agree with him. He knows that he is not agreed with, that his view is not agreed with. We chose not to take up extensive time of the Parliament in this matter. We chose to put our position clearly at the beginning and then to let matters flow. It is a shame that the time of the Parliament has been so abused by this process. I hope that what might have been a new shining light on the front bench can toughen up a little bit and take it a bit better in future.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Robert Ray) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: SNOWY MOUNTAINS ENGINEERING CORPORATION (CONVERSION INTO PUBLIC COMPANY) BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 May, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.
Amendment (by Senator Lewis) proposed:

At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that the Government should sell the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation to the private sector, with the first option to purchase being given to the Corporation's employees''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the amendment. In saying that, I do not want it to be believed or understood that there are ideological grounds, if you like, for saying that the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (SMEC) should remain in public ownership forever. Because it was once appropriate for it to be in public ownership does not necessarily mean that it should always be in public ownership. That is a matter for examination from time to time on the basis of the facts and the circumstances of the organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government would say that the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (Conversion into Public Company) Bill, providing for a corporatised structure of SMEC-if that is the right expression-is appropriate at present because SMEC still fills an important flag carrier role. Its reputation both in Australia and particularly internationally has been an important one in that regard. It has already assisted a number of Australian engineering organisations to obtain a foothold overseas. What we have seen in the last few years in this country is something which just was not there perhaps five years ago. We have seen the development of big consulting engineering firms in Australia such as Kinhills, Rankines and MacDonald Wagner which, in time, will probably fill the same sort of function in international markets as SMEC has done traditionally.

SMEC is a national asset with 85 per cent of its work overseas-a higher proportion than any other private sector consulting firm at this stage of Australian history. It is an exporter of overseas services, providing significant export income for Australia. It has an outstanding reputation for excellence and in that context currently there is still a role for it to play in government ownership. That is not to say that SMEC has been without difficulty. Senator Lewis and I have had occasion to discuss this issue in the Senate. SMEC has recently returned to profitability and it is expected to resume paying a dividend to the Government this year. As far as the Government is concerned, there will be no more capital advances made to SMEC of the kind which were necessary in previous years and there will be no cost to the Government in retaining ownership of the organisation. However, in this transition phase from a period of great difficulty, which started with the downturn in 1982, SMEC has been restructuring its operations and, in our view, it should be allowed to continue that process and show a record of profits.

In the amendment moved by Senator Lewis to the motion that the Bill be read a second time, in terms of the possible sale of SMEC, the Opposition has homed in on the possibility of a management buy-out which may or may not be feasible at present. But what is lacking in that suggestion from the Opposition of a management buy-out is the possibility of competitive bids for SMEC. If one were about to sell it one would hope for competitive bids for the organisation, including the possibility of a management buy-out. By implication that suggests that the Opposition, in pursuit of what I suspect to be an ideological gismo, grabs at the management buy-out possibility because it does not see the likelihood of competitive bids at this time. For a variety of reasons the Government has determined on the course which is embodied in this Bill as being appropriate at present. For that reason we do not support the amendment moved by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will also not be supporting the second reading amendment moved by the Opposition but for reasons quite different from those just outlined by Senator Button. Clearly, Senator Button was foreshadowing a move towards greater privatisation. That was the substance of my address in the second reading stage of the debate. Subsequently, after the defeat of this amendment, we will be moving our own amendment. I foreshadow that now because we believe that both the Government and the Opposition are moving in the wrong direction. There should be no doctrinaire ideological commitment to privatisation as expressed by the Government and the Opposition.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Nothing I said expressed an ideological commitment to privatisation.
—We thought better of you than that. We hoped that you did have an ideological commitment to privatisation.

—Hope springs eternal in the Liberal heart; it has to. After seven years, I guess it must. I do not have an ideological commitment to privatisation. What I do have is a very pragmatic approach with regard to the question of public or private sector ownership. I was touched to the quick by Senator Coulter saying that we had an ideological commitment to the privatisation of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, or any other organisation. That is not so. What I did say was that one considers the ownership of a corporation such as this at a particular time. Whether at that particular time it is appropriately in the public or private sector is a matter of judgment based on the circumstances at the time. That is why the Opposition's amendment is not acceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Government and the Australian Democrats have indicated that they will oppose our amendment that the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation should be privatised, I will not be calling for a division. That is not to say that we do not support the amendment wholeheartedly.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Amendment (by Senator Coulter) proposed:
At the end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate deplores:
(a) the Government's continuing policy direction to privatise important public utilities; and

(b) the contents of this Bill, to the extent that they reflect that policy direction by moving towards privatisation of an invaluable public resource in the engineering field, namely the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes Senator Coulter's amendment for reasons similar to those for which it opposed Senator Lewis's amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The first matter I raise in relation to the Bill is the vote by the Australian Democrats. The Democrats divided the Senate for a statistical reason. We are aware that the Democrats are producing statistics which demonstrate the number of occasions on which the Government and the coalition parties have voted together. They call divisions at a particular stage, as they did then, allegedly for an ideological reason, but in truth to have it recorded statistically. Yesterday, we demonstrated that that can be a nonsense and can blow back in their faces. Earlier today I did not call for a division, saying that it would save four minutes, but the Australian Democrats did not respond. We have noted what the Democrats did and we shall take that into account for the rest of the sittings.

SPEECH.PARA: I now refer to the actual contents of the legislation. During the speech by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) on the second reading, he indicated to the Senate that there would be no more capital injections of the size of those that have recently been given to the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation-I take it that is a reference to the almost $12m that this Government has spent on this body since it has been in office. I put it to the Minister that the Government is at risk with regard to this body. If he examined the most recent statement of assets and liabilities and profit and loss, he would see that there are not provisions in the body's funds for contingencies. That means that if this body, which is involved in the engineering field, makes a mistake it could be subject to some action for damages, so someone is at risk and the ultimate responsibility would rest with the Commonwealth Government. Does the Minister therefore deny that the Government is at risk, because this organisation is continuing as, what will ultimately be, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Commonwealth of Australia?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Lewis is confusing ownership with some other provisions of the legislation. He says the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (SMEC) has no provisions in its accounts for contingencies. I accept that statement. I have not looked at the accounts.
—Very little; insufficient.

—As an engineering organisation, one would believe and hope that SMEC would carry insurance against risks of the kind to which Senator Lewis referred. I recall that on one occasion in its history SMEC had a substantial claim made against it arising from some work done in Malaysia. Those circumstances are covered normally by similar engineering corporations through insurance. The purpose of the Government legislation is to put SMEC essentially in the same position as a private company. It cannot stand behind the shield of the Crown in respect of any of its operations. Those provisions are contained in the legislation and that is the intention. One of the purposes of the legislation is to see that the Government does not have some contingent liability. I do not think I can add anything to that. Similar legislation has been introduced in respect of a number of government business enterprises.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already indicated privately to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce that I seek some explanation of proposed section 51. After passage of the Bill section 51 will provide:

SPEECH.PARA: SMEC, as it exists after the transition, shall be taken for the purposes of a law of the Commonwealth or a State or Territory:
(a) not to have been incorporated or established for a public purpose or for a purpose of the Commonwealth; and
(b) not to be a public authority or an instrumentality or agency of the Crown; . . .

There are a great deal of negatives in relation to this body. I ask the Minister: What is the reason for proposed new section 51? What is its ultimate purpose? Does this mean that the Commonwealth will not in any way be responsible for its liabilities? What is the whole purpose of this proposed new section? Let me go a step further and ask: Does proposed new section 51 of the Bill not prove, if I can use that word in a particular sense, the validity of our amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time that this organisation ought to be privatised? It seems to me that, under proposed new section 51, the Government is proposing to set up a corporation that will have so many negatives about what it is not to be that it really establishes and proves that case of the coalition parties that the Government ought to divest itself of its shareholding as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis will know the expression, `Now you see it, now you don't'. When he asked his first question, he did not see it; but now he does-it is proposed new section 51. In this case, it is the other way round.
—I don't understand that. I have known all about section 51 longer than you have; you found out about it only 10 minutes ago, when you were briefed.
—Senator, that is an outrageous suggestion.
—It is the truth.

—Senator Lewis has maligned me by suggesting that I have not been living and breathing section 51 of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Registration for the last month. That is an outrageous slur on my character. The honourable senator is absolutely right. He read the provisions of the proposed new section which, in essence, says that the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (SMEC) shall not be regarded in any way as a public purpose instrumentality, which it was once, or as a public authority, which it was once in the time of the Chifley Government when it was established, pursuing Commonwealth purposes, such as building the Snowy Mountains scheme, or, subsequently, doing a whole range of things overseas. The proposed new section says that the Corporation is no longer a public sector instrumentality pursuing public purposes or the purposes of the Commonwealth. In that sense, it becomes independent of the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for proposed new section 51 is that the definition of a `corporation' in the Companies Code excludes `a body corporate that is incorporated within Australia or an external territory and is a public authority or an instrumentality or agency of the Crown'. The Companies Code excludes that kind of instrumentality from being a corporation for the purposes of that code. So this proposed new section is necessary for us to say that, for the purposes of the Companies Code, this Corporation will no longer be an exception; that it will have the character of any other corporation prescribed or dealt with by the Companies Code; and that it will not have the character of a public authority, instrumentality or agency of the Crown which were exempt from the Companies Code. So, by the provision of proposed new section 51, the Corporation is put in the same position as any other corporation which is subject to the Companies Code. That is necessary to ensure that the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation is changed in character to that of a public company, That is the reason for the proposed new section.

If I might say so without offence, the honourable senator then drew what I can only describe as a long bow. Having read proposed new section 51 to the Committee, he then said, `Doesn't this prove the validity of our argument that the Corporation should be privatised and that the shareholding should be sold at this point?'. Time being what it is and in light of the discussion we had earlier, I will characterise that argument as being in the long bow category. The answer to the honourable senator's proposition is no, it does not support that view at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer not only to the first part of the Minister's answer to proposed new section 51 but also to what he has said in relation to the whole Bill and during the second reading debate. Does this all mean that the Commonwealth would not stand behind this Corporation if it were bankrupted?
—Precisely.

—I want to make sure that it is properly on the record that the Minister said that the Commonwealth Government would not stand behind this Corporation if it were bankrupted. I mention that because some years ago there was an occasion in Great Britain where a wholly owned subsidiary of the United Kingdom Government went bankrupt, owing millions of pounds to various creditors. The United Kingdom Government failed to stand by that corporation. At the time I thought that was a shameful event because I would have thought that all of its creditors believed that they were dealing with the United Kingdom Government and, as such, they could allow that corporation adequate credit, for the purposes of their business arrangements, without taking the sorts of precautions that they might be tempted to take if they were dealing with what might be called a private corporation-that would include a public corporation. I think it should be publicly known that the Commonwealth Government is saying to the creditors of SMEC, `If this organisation finds itself in a situation where it is unable to meet its liabilities, the Commonwealth Government will not bail it out'. I think most creditors of this organisation, and creditors of any other organisation which is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Commonwealth of Australia, would be surprised to discover that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has indicated that I have not made out an argument that this body would be far better owned by the private sector rather than by the Commonwealth of Australia. I refer him to clause 9 of the Bill which states:
The functions of SMEC include investigating, advising on, designing, supervising and constructing, engineering works.

Since when has the Government believed that it ought to be in the business of `investigating, advising on, designing, supervising and constructing, engineering works'? Is that the sort of activity that this Government has been elected to perform, or is it true that this organisation is a hangover from the old Snowy Mountains scheme and the Government has not been able to persuade its Caucus committee that it is about time it got rid of its shares in it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that we have to go through this all again. Although I found fascinating the honourable senator's anecdotal material about the experiences of some public corporation in England, as he did not tell us the secret of what organisation it was or anything like that, I will not comment on what he said. The United Kingdom Government does things in its own mysterious ways.
—But you are adopting that principle.

—No, I am not adopting any such principle. Senator Lewis asked whether, if the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation were to go bankrupt, the Government would stand behind it. I said no, the Government will not stand behind it any longer. As I said earlier, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation will henceforth be in exactly the same position as some of the major consulting engineering companies in Australia which have developed in the last few years, such as Rankine and Hill Pty Ltd, Macdonald Wagner Pty Ltd and Kinhill Engineers Pty Ltd, in operating in the marketplace.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lewis asked me whether the Government should be in the business of engineering design, construction and so on. With respect, that is a funny question for Senator Lewis to come in here with. The Chifley Government decided that the government of the day should be in that business for the purposes of a great national project, the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has the Hawke Government decided about this?

—Senator Lewis talks about the Hawke Government. He should count up on his fingers and toes, because he will need to, how many years the Liberal Party has been in government since the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation was established. Out of 40 years, I suppose the Liberal Party was in government 30--
—Not long enough.

—I know that hurts. The Liberal Party has been in government 31 or 32 of the 40 years of the history of this organisation. In all that period in government did it ever do anything about this? Did it ever decide that engineering, design work for engineering and so on was not the function of the Government? Not once. Throughout that period it ran away from all these issues. It did not get anywhere near this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston has been in here boring us to death day after day talking about telecommunications. What did the Liberal Party do about the telecommunications system in all that time in government, when these changes were taking place elsewhere in the world? The answer is that it did nothing. Senator Lewis provokes me slightly by coming in here saying, `Are these things the function of government?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a good question, isn't it?

—The answer to the question is generally no. But one has regard to the history of these organisations. One must have regard to their economic circumstances. The purpose of this legislation is to put the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation in the same position as a private sector company. The fact that the Government remains a shareholder is coincidental to that process in the context of this legislation. Senator Lewis referred earlier to a lot of negatives in proposed new section 51. There are a lot of negative propositions coming out of him. I do not want to debate the matter much further. I understand his point of view, belated though it may be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has just provoked me to say that, while he may talk about history as much as he wishes, the truth of the matter is that the next government, the Peacock Government, will privatise this Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 May, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add `, but the Senate is of the opinion that the Government should sell the Australian Industry Development Corporation in its entirety to the private sector as soon as possible in view of the fact that the Corporation operates as a commercial enterprise and furthermore that there is no essential public interest reason for maintaining Federal Government ownership'.

In regard to the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) the Government is establishing a subsidiary company which the Commonwealth will own as to 70 per cent and the public will own as to 30 per cent. In other words, there is to be a 30 per cent partial privatisation. The Commonwealth Government will then do precisely what it was saying it would not do in relation to the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. Because the Commonwealth will be a 70 per cent shareholder, this body, the AIDC public company, will be out there in the marketplace competing with banks and other finance companies, but with 70 per cent government ownership. Whilst it will be operating as a private body in the marketplace, it will have government backing. When one considers the difficulties created by the Government's proposal, it is a nonsense. It is a sop to the Caucus back bench of the Australian Labor Party which, once again, would defy the Government's desire to rid itself of this body. Because the back bench Caucus committee would not allow the Government to sell the body, all that the Government has been able to persuade it to do is to allow it to sell 30 per cent.

This body should be in the private sector. It should not be owned by the Commonwealth of Australia. We are going through a partial privatisation measure simply because of the ideological beliefs of a section of the Australian Labor Party, and as a sop to that section of the Australian Labor Party we will see only 30 per cent of this body in the marketplace.

As I have said in my second reading amendment, there is no essential public interest reason for maintaining Federal government ownership. This Corporation will operate totally as a commercial enterprise. In all the circumstances, when the Government is talking about the problems of a lack of capital for Australian Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd and the difficulties in overcoming those problems, the Government could divest itself of this body, sell it in the private sector, take the funds and use them for some other purpose. We would encourage the Government to use the funds to pay off part of the national debt but, if the Government wanted to, I suppose, it would not be unreasonable for it to use them to assist some other government enterprise such as Qantas or Australian Airlines. The Democrats might come up with such a proposition. In our view there is absolutely no reason why the Government should maintain 70 per cent ownership of this body. The fact that it is able and prepared to sell 30 per cent of this body to the private sector to my mind proves beyond any shadow of doubt the validity of our argument that this body should be sold in its entirety.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be opposing this attachment to the motion for the second reading, for the reasons I stated before-namely, that we are opposed to the selling of Government assets as a matter of principle, which seems to have been adopted by both the Government and the Opposition. I will be interested to see whether the Opposition calls a division on this in the light of the remarks of Senator Lewis when we called a division on the Bill just completed.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lewis seems to have forgotten that the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) was a creation of a Liberal government, not a Labor government, and that it was brought into existence to help in a quasi-commercial way those industries which required financial assistance which was not generally available through normal commercial channels. Moreover, he seems to have forgotten the clear evidence that this organisation is now functioning profitably and therefore is of benefit to the Government and to the citizens of Australia. It can be sold off only once, and the Government can make a capital gain only once, whereas by hanging on to it, as long as it remains profitable it will be a source of income to the Government.

Senator Lewis also seems to have ignored the fact that the amendments, which I understand he will be supporting, in relation to the audit processes for both AIDC's principal subsidiary and the sub-subsidiaries underneath that principal subsidiary, call for the Government Auditor to remain the auditor. The effect of this attachment to the motion for the second reading would be to privatise the body entirely. The amendments which the Opposition is proposing and which the Australian Democrats are proposing would be quite inconsistent with this amendment.

For those reasons the Democrats are not supporting the attachment to the motion for the second reading. Whilst Senator Lewis claimed that our earlier division was simply to establish the statistics, we would counterclaim that that was precisely what caused all the waste of time yesterday. We hope that he will not continue down that road and call a division on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition's amendment is aimed at the complete privatisation of the Australian Industry Development Corporation and acceptance thereby that there is no essential public interest requiring government involvement in an organisation such as the AIDC. The Government is opposed to this amendment. I could hypothecate to my argument now an argument that I heard Senator Button put in terms of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation a moment ago: that the Opposition has been in government for a host of years since the war and during its periods of office it has not proposed to do anything about changing the structure of the instrumentality. But as soon as we propose to change its structure, to bring in 30 per cent public shareholding, then we are accused of not going far enough. I suppose this question arises: If the Opposition really believes that, why, when it had the opportunity to do what it now says we should do, did it not do it?

SPEECH.PARA: I want to give some background to the Government's position. The AIDC was moved initially to the Industry portfolio in late 1983, when the Australian Industry Development Corporation Act was amended to expand the goal of the Corporation. The amendments at that time enabled the AIDC to provide finance for the restructuring and revitalisation of the industry and for high technology and other growth industries in order to improve the overall competitiveness of Australian industry. Since that time the AIDC has made a significant contribution to the Government's industry objectives. Its ability to provide both loans and equity capital across the spectrum of new and old industries is a key characteristic that differentiates it from other financial institutions. Because of the contribution the AIDC can make to industry restructuring plans, such as in the heavy engineering and the textiles, clothing and footwear industries, and in projects such as the anti-malaria joint venture, the Government believes that it should maintain an ongoing interest in the AIDC.

In saying this, however, I quickly point out that the decisions made by the AIDC are based on its commercial judgments. On the one hand, it has not been and it will not be directed by government in its normal operations as to where it should or should not invest. On the other hand, it is, as we have already said, in need of a fresh injection of capital. The float of up to 30 per cent will overcome the problem and will provide the AIDC with sufficient capital to pursue its leading programs, particularly those related to equity. The AIDC has had an excellent record and is an attractive investment opportunity for the Australian people. The float will allow the AIDC to continue its operations and will give a wide spectrum of the community the opportunity to participate to advantage in the AIDC. At the same time, those investors will be confident of the AIDC because they know that the Government is going to continue as a major shareholder in the organisation.
For those reasons the Government does not accept the amendment moved by Senator Austin Lewis to the motion for the second reading, and we will vote against it in a division, if it comes to that.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Lewis's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 3-by leave-taken together.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Lewis.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Coulter-Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. The amendments proposed by the Australian Democrats were circulated several weeks before the Opposition amendments. As most of them are in similar terms, I believe that gives the Democrats precedence over the Opposition with respect to the moving of these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the first place, it does not; but even so, I am not quite clear what the honourable senator is talking about. At the moment we are dealing with clauses 1 to 3, to which there are no amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —One of these days we will have to explain to the Australian Democrats that they are not the Opposition in this Parliament; they are a minor addition to the Australian Labor Party in the Senate. In relation to clause 1, let me put paid to the arguments raised by the Government about what the coalition parties did or did not do during the course of earlier governments. The Government says repeatedly, `We have gone this far; you did nothing in government'. The truth of the matter is that the economic circumstances of this nation have changed violently for the worse-in fact, disastrously-under this Government. Under this Government, Australia's external debt has increased by $80 billion to $103 billion in little more than six years. By its mismanagement of the economy, this Government has sent this nation down the drain by more than $80 billion. We are now in a position where this Government has to take every step possible to try to get the nation out of its troubles. That means-and we will get the opportunity to debate it this afternoon-that this Government should be taking firm steps to rectify the problems on the waterfront.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday we debated the telecommunications package and we pointed out that the Government should be taking firm steps to bring about increases in productivity and efficiency in the telecommunications industry. That is the only way. I see that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, is now back in the chamber. He agrees with everything I say. He may stand up and make smart alec speeches or excuses in this chamber, but I have heard him say to the business community exactly what I am saying to the Committee now. This nation has to increase its productivity and efficiency. We have to become sufficiently efficient and produce sufficiently high quality goods so that Australian people will want to buy Australian made goods because they are the best, not because there is some financial inducement provided by the taxpayers of this country to do so. In that way we would reduce the amount of imported goods that we buy. Similarly, we need to increase our productivity and efficiency so that overseas countries want to buy Australian goods because they are the best at the most reasonable price, the service is first class and the backup and supply of parts is first class.

This Government must take steps to overcome the problems which this nation is facing at present. Here we are faced with an opportunity to take another step-and that is for the Government to get out of activities in which it should not be involved. This Government should not be in the business of providing airline services or finance for companies; it should be in the business of managing the economy. Here is an opportunity for it to get out of this industry by privatising the Australian Industry Development Corporation. The Government stands up and says, `We have gone this far. We are prepared to privatise it 30 per cent and you are criticising us for not going the whole hog. But you did not do something 20 or 30 years ago'.

Twenty or thirty years ago this country was not in the economic situation that it is now in. This country is sitting on the edge of an economic abyss where, if our commodity prices were to fall, the dollar would fall drastically. Senator Button smiles over there, but he knows that what I am saying is true. If the bottom falls out of the dollar, look out for this country, because we have really hit the Argentinean road. Inflation in Argentina is running at 25,000 per cent. This country is sitting on the edge of that abyss, and Senator Button knows it. We are maintaining our dollar value only by paying high interest and because of our relatively high commodity prices. The Government has to take every opportunity, whatever those opportunities are, to try to bring about an economic recovery. This legislation was an opportunity. All the Government can do is stand up and say, `Well, 10 years ago you did not do anything about it. You have been in government for 30 out of the last 40 years and you did not do anything about it'. But 30 years ago this country was not like it is now. Even 6 1/2 years ago we were not in a situation where we owed $103 billion and were going down the drain at the rate of $17 billion a year. The Government is sitting on its hands doing nothing about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is debating the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill. I mention that because people listening not in the chamber, if there are any, would have been pardoned for imagining that we were talking about something altogether different. Not only are we debating the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) legislation but we are debating clauses 1, 2 and 3, which deal with the title of the Bill, the setting out of the Bill and the contents of the Bill. Senator Lewis has used this opportunity to raise matters because in the last debate I touched him a bit when I made the point that for more than 30 of the last 40 years in this country we have been under conservative governments. Senator Lewis gets on his feet and says, `Well, you're not going to get away with that sort of stuff because in all those 30 years things were nice and now the country is in crisis'. Let me go back to some of the expressions about being on the Argentinean route that Senator Lewis used in his speech a minute ago. The books which told Australia about that, which warned Australia about that, were all published in his period of government. The Lucky Country by Donald Horne, Poor Little Rich Country by Max Walsh and Australia and Argentina on Parallel Paths were all published in Senator Lewis's period of government. The difference is that the Opposition of the day, the Australian Labor Party, read them and understood what they were about. When we came into government we started to do something about these things in terms of structural adjustment and so on, which the Opposition did not do for the 30-odd years that it was in government. It did nothing about these hard issue questions.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lewis has talked in his speech about weaknesses in the supply side of the Australian economy. They were apparent to anybody who had his eye on the ball 15 to 20 years ago. The Opposition did not have its eye on the ball in that period of government. In a commodity dependent economy, as we have, one has to address these important supply side issues. What is the solution of the Opposition? It comes in here this morning and says, in the context of this debate, that the solution to these problems is to sell airlines and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation; and not to turn the AIDC into a 30 per cent privately owned corporation but to turn it into a 100 per cent privately owned corporation. It says that these are the solutions. It has got these solutions, in ideological terms, from the Thatcher Government in Britain. One thing about Margaret Thatcher that could never be said about Liberal governments in this country is that she had the guts of her convictions and has done these things, whether one agrees with it or not. But if one wants to talk about economies in trouble with growing overseas debt and balance of trade problems, one ought to have a look at Margaret Thatcher's United Kingdom in 1989. Has the route which she has followed solved any of these problems? If one can find an economy which is closest to an identikit economy in terms of its problems with Australia, it is in Britain. There are growing trade deficits and all those sorts of things.

What I am trying to say to Senator Lewis is simply that the sorts of ideological solutions which he thinks he has borrowed from Margaret Thatcher and would apply here are not necessarily right and not necessarily productive solutions to the sorts of problems which he describes. Some of those things are probably right, some of them have merit, but let us not pretend, by coming in here and making beefy speeches on clauses 1 to 3 of the AIDC Bill, that we are, by this sort of mini-exercise in here, going to solve the problems of the world or of the Australian economy, because we are not. It is very easy to come in here and say that I go around making speeches about the need to improve productivity, design, quality and all these sorts of things. I do, and I do not retreat from that at all. All those things are correct. But when we come in here and talk about legislation in the serious sense and look at the mechanisms of it all, let us not pretend that there are any easy or glib solutions to some of these problems. I should have taken a point of order during Senator Lewis's speech because it was irrelevant to what is in this legislation before the Committee. I allowed him indulgence because I could see that he was enjoying it. There is no reason why there should not occasionally be a bit of enjoyment in this place. People are entitled to have a bit of fun. Senator Lewis was having a bit of fun, so I did not interrupt him, but I will if he tries it again and it is not relevant to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to hear what Senator Button has just had to say. He was reflecting on the way in which, as a nation, we have failed to read the portents of history unfolding before us. He has quite correctly drawn attention to the fact that the Opposition has failed to read those signs and failed to do things in good time to redirect this country in ways which would benefit both the country and the future of the society in it. I point out to Senator Button that the portents now are very different and that this Government is failing to read the signs. I have said to Senator Button before that he has come out with a car plan which took no account of things like fuel efficiency and greenhouse warming. Later today we will be discussing legislation which will seek to reduce the export levy on coal below that which it should be. So Senator Button should take note of his own observation, namely, that we should be looking to the future, reading the signs and doing something different from that which we are now doing.

SPEECH.PARA: To turn briefly to what Senator Lewis said in relation to the Australian Democrats, his wild arm waving and lack of logic is just incredible. He asserts that the Democrats are a rump of the Australian Labor Party, but he would know that our amendments are very much in line with the Opposition's amendments to this legislation. In fact, the Opposition is supporting the Democrats amendments. So on this occasion we will be lining up together. I understand that the Government will not be supporting those amendments. The fact that, in the main, we support the Government is that, on balance, we believe that the Government generally has the better arguments. We judge every issue on its merits. In this case we do not think that the Government does have the better arguments, and the Opposition will be supporting our amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the next speaker, I should make it clear that the question before the Chair is that clauses 1, 2 and 3 stand as printed. I have permitted a wide-ranging debate, but that cannot continue. Each spokesman of each party has already spoken on this Bill. I ask any further speakers to address themselves specifically to clauses 1, 2 and 3 of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I am addressing myself specifically to clause 1 which puts the short title of the Bill in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: This Act may be cited as the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Act 1989.

I wish to respond very briefly to some of the points that Senator Button made, but I will not try to extend the debate much further. I wish to say to him that I see nothing funny about what is before the Committee and that I am not having a good time. I think this debate about the future of this nation is most earnest. I believe that the legislation before the Parliament is another opportunity for the Government to pick up some part of the solution to the problems of this nation. I certainly do not believe that there is some simple golden key which can be inserted in a lock to solve our problems.
