I certainly do not believe that there are some simple glib solutions to our problems. I was indicating that everything should be up for review. This country's economic problem is now of such a size that we cannot afford to allow any part of it to pass without giving proper and due consideration to what is the best way to use a particular measure to assist us out of the crisis that we are in.

Senator Button said that 10 to 15 years ago members of the then Opposition-by that he meant members of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) in this Parliament-read certain books. Let me add that while parliamentary members of the ALP may have read the books, members of the ALP in the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and in particular Mr R. J. Hawke, then President of the ACTU and now Prime Minister of this country, certainly did not. Mr Hawke took every opportunity while the Fraser Government was in office to frustrate the measures that it was trying to take to bring about recovery and solve national problems.

It is clear from what Senator Coulter said during his point of order that the only thing that the Australian Democrats are interested in is who will be moving which amendments and who will be supporting what amendments, so that the Democrats in some way or other can manipulate this Parliament-which they will not be able to do because I will not allow them to do it-and say, `We moved the amendments and the Liberal and National parties supported our amendments'. What a pitiful performance that is. Here is the country going down the drain at the rate of $17 billion a year and the Democrats are worrying about who will move what amendment and who will support the amendment. It is pitiful.
Clauses agreed to.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call on the next clause, I should like to make quite clear the system used by the Chair where identical amendments are moved. The time at which the amendment is received is not a factor; it is not a question of priority. If the amendments are identical, the person who first catches the Chairman's eye will be the one to be called. If senators rise simultaneously, I would call the Opposition senator, he being a member of the larger of the two parties.

INTERJECT.PARA: (1) Page 2, clause 4, proposed definition of `Corporation auditor', lines 19 and 20, leave out the proposed definition.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter of history that these amendments were first circulated by the Australian Democrats. But the deviousness of Senator Lewis is quite remarkable. The point I was making was in answer to his claim--
—Order! The word `deviousness' is not parliamentary and the honourable senator should withdraw it.
—I withdraw it, Mr Chairman, and suggest that his--
—Order! There can be no substitution. The honourable senator should just carry on with his speech.

—The contorted logic of Senator Lewis is such that he is attempting to answer one point with something which is quite irrelevant. He was claiming that the Australian Democrats were a rump of the Australian Labor Party. I was merely pointing out that in this particular case we have identical amendments which are not supported by the Labor Party. The logic which one can draw from that is that we are considering these amendments on their merits. We believe that with this amendment, and the amendments that will follow, the Opposition has the best of the argument.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether we can deal with this in a more sensible way. This little amendment has been put forward as being consistent with the Opposition's and the Australian Democrats' view, as I understand it, that the Auditor-General should be the auditor of the Australian Industry Development Corporation. I wonder whether it might be convenient if the arguments in respect of the audit could be put during consideration of this definitions clause. If my colleagues agree with this course, we would not have to go through it again when we come to the other clauses relating to the audit.
—It is up to Senator Lewis and Senator Coulter. Senator Lewis has the call. If he wishes to foreshadow that the same argument will apply to a later clause, that would certainly be in order.
—Yes, that is what I would like to happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite happy to go along with the suggestion of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). I agree that it would probably save time. I find it quite fascinating that the Democrats claim some prior right to these amendments. That is absolute nonsense. The truth of the matter is that these amendments arise out of a report delivered by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts which was made on 9 March 1989. The coalition parties have considered that report and decided to adopt it in relation to the Auditor-General being the auditor of both the Australian Industry Development Corporation and the public company established under the AIDC, of which 70 per cent will be owed by the AIDC and 30 per cent will be owned by the public. This is set out quite clearly on page (xx) of the recommendations at the front of the report of the Public Accounts Committee. Recommendation 23 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Audit Act 1901 be amended to require the Auditor-General to be appointed the external auditor of all Government companies.
Recommendation 24 states:
The subsidiaries of all statutory authorities, government owned companies and Government Business Enterprises should be audited by the Auditor-General.

It is a very long report by a bipartisan joint committee of the Parliament consisting of senators and members of the House of Representatives from both sides. The coalition parties, having given great consideration to an alternative which Senator Button mentioned to me privately, finally decided that they would come down in favour of the report, including a provision in our amendments that the Auditor-General may either carry out the audit himself or subcontract out the audit to a private audit firm. At the end of the day, having given consideration to all these matters, this has been the decision of the coalition parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point that was raised by Senator Button, I believe that the suggested amendments naturally fall into three groups. Some amendments deal with the audit, one deals with the report and an amendment is to be moved by Senator Button himself. I suggest that we deal with the amendments in those groups; that we group all the amendments dealing with the audit together, move them as a block and discuss them together. That would expedite the discussion of this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a lot of discussion in private about this. Senator Lewis explained the background. I do not know which honourable senator moved his amendments first; I do not care. They originated from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. We had a committee of the Parliament which thought that the idea of amending the Audit Act to allow all government companies, so-called, to be audited by the Auditor-General was a good idea at the time. The Audit Act has not been amended following that report of the Committee. Politicians on the Opposition side, having decided it was a good idea, wheeled it into this legislation but did not do it in respect of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me quickly review the facts of the matter. The Australian Industry Development Corporation is a government-owned corporation. It is establishing a subsidiary company, AIDC Ltd, to which its assets and liabilities essentially will be transferred with one or two exceptions. That subsidiary company-AIDC Ltd-will be floated shortly and will enjoy subscriptions presumably by shareholders, up to 30 per cent of which will be private sector shareholders.

The question is whether it is appropriate for the Auditor-General to audit that subsidiary company, AIDC Ltd. There is no doubt about the corporation itself; it will be audited by the Auditor-General. In the Government's view that is appropriately a ministerial decision and I have said that that will be the position. The main corporation will be audited by the Auditor-General. In respect of the subsidiary company which will be up to 30 per cent private sector owned, the Government's position is that it should stand in its own right and have the choice of who its auditor is. The shareholders will determine through their representatives who the auditor of a company will be. The Commonwealth will be a 70 per cent shareholder. The private sector will be a 30 per cent shareholder. We say that that company, AIDC Ltd, should have the choice of who its auditor should be.

I remind the Committee that auditors of private sector companies perform a number of other functions besides just the audit. They are often advisers to companies on a range of both structural and financial matters. A company has the capacity, if dissatisfied, to change its auditor. Senator Lewis, the great advocate of the marketplace, is saying on behalf of this bonkers Opposition that this one company will not operate in the marketplace because it is the will of the Liberal Party of Australia, that it will not be able to choose its auditor and that the Government will impose one on it. In theory if the Auditor-General wants to charge $500,000 for something which could be done by a private sector auditor for $150,000 that does not matter to the Opposition. By the will of this Opposition, which talks about the marketplace, that will be imposed on the subsidiary company. It is extraordinary stuff from an Opposition committed to all of the things which Senator Lewis was committed to five minutes ago as pointed out in his speech on the importance of the market and Margaret Thatcher and how she has done all these wonderful things in Britain. Yet five minutes later Senator Lewis took pride that he, ahead of the Australian Democrats, is moving this motion to saddle the subsidiary company, AIDC Ltd, with no choice of audit.

That is the principle involved. Senator Watson is now sneaking into the chamber. He is a member of the Public Accounts Committee. He was never a believer in the free market system. Coming out of the textile industry, how could he be? Nonetheless, he is a member of the Public Accounts Committee. If he comes in to speak on this issue perhaps he will enlighten us as to why AIDC Ltd, a subsidiary company, should not have the right of choice of auditor, irrespective of cost, which other companies have. Why should it be denied that? This suggestion flies in the face of what, when I use my field glasses at short distance, I divine as being Liberal Party philosophy. I have to use field glasses to see it but it flies in the face of it. That is the argument. Senator Coulter, of course, supports the Opposition's argument. They are strange bedfellows.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite the contrary; for quite different reasons.

—Precisely, that is the point I will make. The Opposition is trying to distinguish itself from the Australian Democrats. Senator Lewis says he believes in a free market and Senator Coulter will get up and say that he does not. He wants to saddle AIDC Ltd with this because he has this profound faith in regulation and in the lack of a free market in things like this. The Opposition and the Democrats are together on this issue. How can we govern this country with this lot coming at us from both directions with philosophies which are antiquated and barren? Senator Lewis is determined on this course. He should not make any pompous speeches aimed at me for the next week or two about how he believes in the marketplace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to Senator Button by saying that in the just on 13 years that I have been in this chamber I have observed the activities of government business enterprises. I served for many years on a committee of the Senate dealing with finance and government operations when we analysed the statutory authorities of the Commonwealth and the problems which they can bring about when they enter the marketplace. As a result of that observation, I came to the firm conclusion that I was very concerned about government business enterprises in any way being involved in the marketplace.

SPEECH.PARA: I go back to a body called Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd which created great difficulties for the Fraser Government because of its activities. I say to the Committee that the problem is that the Government ought not to be involved in businesses of this nature. If it wants to go down the private enterprise route-I thoroughly support that-let it privatise this body and let it not retain 70 per cent ownership. Then the body could appoint whichever accountants it wished to conduct its audits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) for coming down and intruding into this debate. I do not normally do so in the committee stage but I was actually following the debate and I know that the Minister is too. The reason I intrude is the very point the Minister made very cogently. Senator Lewis's logic on this appears to be from his philosophical point of view that one might as well be hung for a sheep as a lamb. I assume that that was the logic in what he just said. It is not very consistent.

SPEECH.PARA: The only reason I wanted to contribute briefly to the debate is to say this: in the Northern Territory, the Northern Territory conservative Government accomplished a number of quite radical things in terms of government policy which were supported at the time, I might tell Senator Lewis, by the Australian Labor Party. One of them was the complete restructuring of the Northern Territory Public Service in a way that Dr Coombs had suggested years before for the Commonwealth Public Service in providing contract employment for departmental heads. That was totally supported by me at the time.

One of the other accomplishments was allowing highly competent and very professional private auditors, that is accounting firms that specialise in audit, to in fact audit government accounts. That process not only allowed for proper and competent audit of the books of government agencies as well as semi-government agencies in the Northern Territory but also allowed, I am pleased to say, access by that private sector group into what is a very lucrative area of accounting. I find that startlingly inconsistent with the Opposition's philosophy. Senator Lewis's logic leaves me cold. Given the fact that this body is likely to proceed-Senator Lewis would have to concede that at the moment it appears that it will-I would have thought that the proper and responsible approach of the Opposition would be to allow the operation to proceed in a manner as consistent with Opposition philosophy as possible. I would like an explanation from Senator Lewis-a better one than he has just given-as to why the private sector, which I am sure he would concede has extremely competent, professional and highly qualified and regulated auditors, is not allowed to bid for this market in the same way as it does for others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button knows that, given a challenge, particularly issued by him, I will always respond. So I thank him for offering me this invitation. What we are talking about is a loss of parliamentary control-a loss of linkage with this Parliament through the Auditor-General. Over the years, particularly those in which this Government has been in office, there has been a growth in the Executive branch of government. That growth has been associated with a decline in the power of the Parliament. I remind the Minister that report No. 296 on the reform of the Australian Audit Office has been recognised throughout Australia. The Auditor-General-the ally of the people and the Parliament-has been widely acknowledged. In fact, the major provisions of the report have been endorsed by the Liberal-National Party coalition.

SPEECH.PARA: I also remind Senator Button that this report was compiled by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, of which the Australian Labor Party has a majority membership. It is a significant majority. All members of the Committee, many of whom are high-ranking members of the Labor Party, overwhelmingly endorsed that report. They were concerned about this lack of control, this lack of parliamentary linkage. They were concerned about the Government's denial of adequate resources to its own Auditor-General or, should I say, the Auditor-General of this Parliament. One of the features of the recommendations was a separation to ensure the independence of the Auditor-General from the Executive branch of government.

What Senator Button is asking us to do today is the worst of both worlds. A statutory corporation, in order to get further and further away from its linkage with Parliament, is to set up its own company. But the Government is trying to remove the linkage with the Auditor-General. It believes that because there is a 30 per cent public interest the body would not be under the scrutiny of the Australian Audit Office, despite the fact that the Commonwealth will own 70 per cent. If the Government is so concerned about competitiveness and all that business, we say: privatise the organisation and we will support it; privatise it and allow the private sector auditors to compete. However, if one dollar of public money is involved, this Parliament and the Auditor-General will have a direct interest. Therefore, the amendment must be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Button for pointing out the inconsistency in the Opposition's position and Senator Collins also for reiterating that. However, Senator Button's logic fell down when he said that one cannot support the same form of words for quite different reasons. I thank Senator Button for identifying the Australian Democrats as at least being consistent on this, although for reasons which he seems to have misjudged in saying that we have an ideological commitment to regulation. I go back to his earlier reference to some of the writings which were present in the late 1960s and early 1970s and draw his attention to John Kenneth Galbraith's book The New Industrial State published, I think, in 1967. Galbraith made the point that bureaucracies, whether private or public, exist to serve their own ends and, therefore, need proper checks and balances to remain in place.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason that the Democrats will support this series of amendments-I think we are taking them as a block-is very similar to the one which Senator Watson has just given; namely, that in the private area there is a considerable incentive to do the sorts of audits that the company seeks and not have the public interest at heart. Recently we saw the Four Corners program and Bond's company coming out of that public discussion with an adjustment of the company's annual report for the year 1988. We saw the way in which that company, apparently, has prepared for public consumption audited reports which were initially misleading and required adjustment. That indicates that in the private area there is inevitably a strong incentive to produce the sort of audit, the sort of report, that the corporation requires, whereas in the case of the government audit process that situation should not obtain. We support this series of amendments on the ground that a public interest is involved. We believe that the Government Auditor will do the job, with the interest of the public, as expressed through the government ownership, more in hand.

I was distressed to hear Senator Button pull figures out of the air and suggest that the Government Auditor may charge half a million dollars whereas a private auditor may charge only $150,000. I want to put it on the record that he was quite clearly plucking figures out of the air. I do not think that there is any reason to suppose that the difference in cost between government audits and private audits should be that large.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding to Senator Collins's remarks, I do not think that I can put the position any better than Senator Watson put it. The issue is one of accountability to the Parliament and to the elected representatives of the people of Australia, who will hold 70 per cent of the shares in the organisation. I understand the merits of what Senator Collins said about the situation in the Northern Territory, especially with the creation of a new government. For example, if the Government were to use public accountants to audit the accounts of the affairs of the new Administration of the Australian Capital Territory, I would understand that. There could be a lot of merit in it. However, the truth is that in the Commonwealth Parliament we have established the Office of the Auditor-General. He has developed a responsibility to the Parliament. Sometimes I have been a little concerned about the exercise of that responsibility, but I am sure that, as a result of the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, those responsibilities will be enhanced, increased and improved for the benefit of the Parliament. Unless the Government is prepared to go down the path of privatising this organisation in whole, it will find itself stuck with not only this organisation but also any other organisation that it wants to partially privatise with amendments such as the one before us.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 4, clause 11, after proposed subsection 23g (3), add the following new subsection:

`` `(4) The Minister shall cause a copy of any direction given to the Board under subsection (1) to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 10 sitting days of that House after the giving of the direction'.''.
(5) Page 6, after clause 14, insert the following new clause:
Audit
``14a. Section 29 of the Principal Act is amended by inserting after subsection (7) the following new subsections:

`(7a) The Auditor-General is to be appointed auditor of each Australian subsidiary of the Corporation where any law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory relating to companies requires the appointment of an auditor for such a subsidiary.
`(7b) When the Auditor-General is appointed auditor under subsection (7a), he or she may appoint an agent to conduct the audit on his or her behalf.'.''.
(6) Page 7, paragraph 17 (1) (b), lines 13 and 14, leave out the paragraph.
If one looks at amendment No. 5 on page 2 of the revised sheet of amendments, dated 6 June, one will see under 14a the addition of 7b, which states:
When the Auditor-General is appointed auditor under subsection (7a), he or she may appoint an agent to conduct the audit on his or her behalf.

This is a slight variation of the previous amendment which we were debating. The Auditor-General may find that he does not have the facilities available currently and until such time as he can obtain the staff and other requirements, he may wish to use someone in the private sector. Ultimately, he will be responsible to the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a concession to the Government.
—Senator Watson indicates, and I agree, that we were trying in some way to make some concession to the Government's concerns about this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I also draw attention to our other amendment, amendment No. 2, which relates to ministerial directions being laid before each House of the Parliament. It has always been my belief since I served on the Senate committee that I referred to previously that where a Minister makes a direction to one of the statutory authorities, that direction should be tabled before the Parliament so that the people know what the relationship is between the Government and the statutory authority. For example, the Government may decide that there is an area of industry that should be given additional finance. It might decide that the computer industry in Australia might need additional finance. It directs the Australian Industry Development Corporation, or this subsidiary, to take some action with regard to interest rates or loans being made in that area. This is the sort of direction which it may wish to make. It is the sort of direction that the people of Australia are entitled to know about. We move this amendment so that the directions may be laid before the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments relate to the position of the Auditor-General, except for the amendment which deals with the question of directions, which Senator Lewis referred to. The Government opposes all the amendments relating to the Auditor-General-but the Opposition will win because this unholy alliance has been formed in pursuit of non-market forces. Senator Lewis's amendment No. 2, relating to directions, shows that the great privatisers here really do not understand what they are doing. The point of this legislation is to get this corporation away from detailed regulation and intervention by government. That is the dead hand of government in all these things-bureaucratic regulation. The amendment flies completely in the face of that.
—On the contrary.

—The honourable senator should let me finish. The whole idea of these proposals is to free up those regulations which restrict government business enterprises. They will make them more flexible and allow them to compete in the open market-place. This amendment imposes needless obligations on the Corporation. It is one which will put it in a disadvantaged position. Each year the Australian Industry Development Corporation provides the Minister with a corporate plan. That plan sets out the objectives of the Corporation, the overall strategies and policies to be followed. That has worked quite well over the past few years. If we look at the performance of the AIDC, we see that it has worked quite well. That corporate plan incorporates financial targets which will outline overall financial strategies, including the forecasted revenues and expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: The annual report of the Corporation includes a review of the Corporation's year. That is required to be tabled in the Parliament by the Minister. It is not necessary to table these sets of documents separately as it would impose an additional burden. Senator Lewis, by way of illustration, says that if the Government decides that it wants the AIDC to invest in the computer industry and tells it to do so, that should be a matter of public knowledge. I agree with that, but the Government does not do these things. If we look at the charter of the AIDC, we see that it is independent of ministerial direction, except under the national interest provisions where the AIDC may be directed on a particular course. But that has to come to the Parliament. If a Minister makes a determination on a national interest matter, as we did with the research and development of the malaria vaccine, then that is a matter which comes to the Parliament anyway. In all these issues about whether organisations should be in the private or the public sector the worst possible solution is to have them, in regulatory terms, half in the private sector and half in the public sector, with intrusive regulations. We oppose this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this matter of directions being tabled before each House, I think the Minister has been a little disingenuous in that there is a provision in the Bill for the Minister to give a direction. Surely that is the intrusive factor. I do not know whether he is arguing that the Minister should be denied the ability to give a direction. This amendment seeks for that direction to be laid before the Parliament so it will become obvious that a direction has been given. I have in front of me the policy guidelines for Commonwealth statutory authorities and government business enterprises, dated October 1987. The Minister has referred to the corporate plan which these organisations are required to prepare and submit to the Minister and on which the Minister may make directions. On the first page of these guidelines I read:

SPEECH.PARA: In considering financial targets the Minister will have regard for the trading conditions in the industry within which the enterprise operates for its relative commercial and market strengths, and-
I emphasise these words-

for the extent to which on the basis of government policy it is required to meet any `community service obligations' and to observe residual central controls designed to achieve other non-commercial objectives of the Government which adversely affect its profitability.

That seems to me to be a term of reference for the Minister with respect to the directions he or she might give which clearly should come under the surveillance of the Parliament. It is for that reason that we will support the Opposition's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take great exception to the comments of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), which must be taken as a reflection on the competence of the Commonwealth Auditor-General. They imply that the Commonwealth Auditor-General is not following current accounting practices. Therefore, it is necessary for the Minister to explain to this Parliament how the appointment of the Commonwealth Auditor-General will place `the dead hand of government' on this particular operation. We have seen how organisational arrangements, which are not dissimilar to what has been proposed here today, have gone wrong. We do not propose to allow a similar sequence of events to occur. I have great confidence in the competency and skills of the Commonwealth Auditor-General. From my close contact with him in Public Accounts Committee hearings, I cannot see how he is bound up with red tape, regulations and all the other issues of the so-called dead hand of government. I call on Senator Button to make a public apology because his comments must be construed as a reflection on the Auditor-General's competence and they imply to the people of Australia and to this Parliament that he is not following current accounting practices. I remind the Minister that if an organisation wants to go outside for other services this Bill does not preclude it from doing so. If it wants special services-personnel management services or a reorganisation-it can go outside and pay for them separately. Is the Minister implying that the organisation will get extra benefits at no extra cost as a result of an outside appointment? What does the Minister have to fear? Perhaps he could explain.
—We have moved on from that clause.

—I take the honourable senator's point, but I cannot allow this opportunity to pass without calling on the Minister to apologise to the Auditor-General for the sad reflection that he has made in this chamber today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to apologise to anybody.
—You don't ever, do you?

—The new shadow Minister has just walked into the chamber and made one of his usual comments. It is not my function to apologise to anybody because Senator Watson happens to be confused. It is Senator Watson who ought to be apologising. I said a minute ago that I did not want to debate further the questions relating to the Auditor-General, and that I did not intend to do so. I then went on to say, in relation to the directions amendment in this Bill which covers an entirely different matter, that that was part of the dead hand of government intervention resting on a corporation such as this. That was part of it and that was what we had to be wary of. I think Senator Watson is an honest man, but I think he is just confused.

SPEECH.PARA: In so far as the Auditor-General is concerned, the honourable senator has no proprietary rights in his view of the soundness, common sense, capability and integrity of the Auditor-General. He should not come in here making speeches charged with religious fervour about what a great bloke the Auditor-General is and what a great thing the Auditor-General's Office is. Senator Watson has no proprietary rights. I have the highest regard for the Auditor-General. After all, this Government appointed a new Auditor-General not long ago. That is not in issue. If Senator Watson wants to go around the country saying what a good bloke the Auditor-General is he should do so, but he should not see it as being relevant to the issues that we are discussing here.

As to the amendment relating to directions to which Senator Coulter referred, the only direction in this Bill which the Minister can give is a direction relating to the corporate plan. The AIDC presents a corporate plan each year. The Minister may, in respect of that corporate plan, give a direction. In essence, that is what the honourable senator wants tabled in the Parliament at the time when we are trying to free up regulations. That requirement has never been there before. The honourable senator wants to introduce a new burden on this organisation which has never been there in the history of the AIDC. After all, it was not a Labor government which created the AIDC; it was a conservative government. The requirement about directions has not been there before, yet the Opposition wants to introduce it now. I am surprised at Senator Coulter's lack of diligence in not having noticed that in his years in the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment is no burden on the AIDC. It does not hamper it or impose any heavy hand of government on it. The heavy hand of government already exists because under proposed new section 23g the Minister may direct certain variations of the corporate plan secretly. That is the point. We would like to know what the Government has done in the past, and we want to make sure that we know what it does in the future. I have had discussions with officers of the AIDC and I have been critical of them. I will give the Senate an example of the sort of interference that happens when governments stick their noses into this business. I have been critical of them for loans that they have made. I refer in particular to a joint venture that the AIDC entered into for the erection of a multi-storey building in a capital city. The AIDC provided the finance for a developer to build the multi-storey building. It and the developer then sold the building and made a very substantial profit that ended up on their books. I said, `That developer could have got his finance from anywhere. Any bank or finance company would have lent the money. Why would the AIDC enter into this venture? After all, you are making a millionaire a multi-millionaire. That is not what the AIDC was incorporated for or established for'. The response was, `But you parliamentarians require us to enter into these arrangements because of the requirement that we made a certain return on our capital every year'. So instead of being able to provide venture capital for new businesses or for some of our developing corporations-and I can think of one in Victoria at present that needs some finance-because of a particular requirement to make a particular return on capital, the AIDC has to enter into what I call absolute commercial ventures with a developer. The matters to be considered in setting the financial target are listed under proposed new section 23e which states:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) the need to earn a reasonable rate of return on the Corporation's capital and reserves;
(b) the need to maintain the Corporation's financial viability . . .

Proposed new section 23g provides that the Minister may give specific directions in relation to those particular matters. In other words, he can say, `Well, I find a reasonable return on your capital for this year should be 12 per cent'. Once the Minister fixes 12 per cent, the AIDC then has to target its lending arrangements to produce a return of about 12 per cent, so it cannot go into some area where there is a need for low return venture capital until an organisation gets established. I am not saying that that is wrong of the Government; it is a decision of the Government, but one which the people of Australia are entitled to know about. It is a decision of the Government which the Parliament is entitled to know about. That is why I say that it is essential that the Minister table these directions so that we all know what the targeted figure for AIDC is this year if the Government decides to alter the figure.

If the AIDC does not get a direction from the Government, it may set its own targets. It is only when the Minister interferes and applies his heavy hand to the AIDC that his heavy hand will have to be exposed. That is no detriment to or burden on the AIDC. It will make sure that the Minister who is sticking his nose into this area does so knowing that his interference or direction will be publicly known.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was interesting to listen to Senator Lewis because he clearly enunciated the original objectives of the Australian Industry Development Corporation in terms of venture capital and those sorts of developments which may not be able to acquire funding from elsewhere. He provided very good arguments as to why the AIDC should not be privatised. I just want to pick up on what Senator Button said earlier. I cannot allow him to get away with obfuscating the arguments over the matter of the directions being laid before both Houses of Parliament. While it is true that the AIDC was formed under a coalition government, the corporate plan to which he referred and the conditions which will obtain with respect to that corporate plan and the directions which the Minister may give with respect to that corporate plan, are clearly the initiative of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The policy guidelines are included in a document dated October 1987. I understand that they were tabled, and when tabled were referred to in a speech by Senator Walsh on 4 November 1987. So it was clearly an initiative of this Government and therefore it should be answerable for the reasons I have already indicated: that Government policy and the extent to which the directions conform with Government policy is clearly a matter which should come under the surveillance of the Parliament. We are supposed to keep a watchful eye on government to see whether it conforms-in itself, its policies and the directions it gives to various other companies and so on-to those government policies. Therefore, it is quite appropriate that directions be laid before each House of Parliament.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis's argument shows a degree of confusion. The charter of the AIDC, as spelt out in the Australian Industry Development Corporation Act, was established by conservative governments and not changed much by Labor governments. The charter says that the AIDC exists for the purposes of serving Australian industry objectives, but is to be a commercial operation independent of government in its commercial decisions. Everybody can make criticisms about what the AIDC has invested in. Senator Lewis referred to its investment in a certain building and said that it should not have invested in it. I cannot say anything about that, as Minister.
—I said they were required to produce a return which meant they had to look at that sort of investment.
—Senator Lewis should not try to wriggle off the hook yet.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —We must not get confused about these things. It is great joy to a politician's heart, as we have seen in Victoria, Western Australia and Queensland, to tell corporations what they ought to do in terms of commercial decision-making. The AIDC is not like that. That is why the national interest provisions are there. If there is anything that a Minister wants to tell the AIDC to do, he has to bring it to the Parliament under the national interest provisions. That is in section 8a of the legislation. We are talking here about the annual corporate plan which is presented to the Minister. That may contain some highly confidential material.
—We are not seeing the corporate plan, only the direction.

—I understand that, but if honourable senators see the directions without the corporate plan, the chances are that it would be meaningless. If they see the directions with the corporate plan, the chances are that it would be immensely damaging to the commercial confidentiality of the AIDC.
—It sounds like Yes, Minister.

—It is all very well to bleat in here, but that is not the honourable senator's function. The fact is that those two propositions are correct. We either give a direction which is published here, which is meaningless, or give a direction plus the corporate plan and then we damage the organisation. That is where the bureaucratic interference problem arises. The Corporation has an outstanding record as a commercial organisation and has been the largest investor of any financial corporation of its kind in Australian industry development. It has maintained an outstanding commercial record. It is not our business to make judgments about how it does that, so long as it discharges its fundamental objectives. It was not set up to provide venture capital; we have another vehicle for that. We can each intrude our own wishes into the matter, but that will not help very much.
