TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, is leaving Australia today on official Government business overseas. He will be absent from Question Time for the remainder of this period of sittings. During his absence, Senator Evans will be involved in bilateral discussions in India, will lead the Australian delegation to the Geneva International Conference on Indo-Chinese Refugees, and will also join the delegation of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the Australia-United Kingdom Investment Conference in London. Any questions in relation to Senator Evans's portfolio, or those he represents, should be directed to Senator Walsh.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Justice, deals with the situation of the companies and securities package of legislation following the meeting of the Ministerial Council last week, from which the Commonwealth Attorney-General was `exiled', to use his own word. I ask: What does the Government now propose to do in regard to the implementation of this takeover by the Commonwealth of the companies and securities laws and their administration? Will the Government now lay down a detailed administrative timetable for the transition from the cooperative scheme to the new scheme so that the business and professional community will know clearly where they stand? Will the Government also guarantee that important investigations and prosecutions now pending will not be frustrated or abandoned?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Durack for his question because it indicates his longstanding interest in this area of Australian commercial life. He was responsible for so much innovative work when he held the reins of the portfolio of Attorney-General some years ago. It is worth while being able to indicate to the Senate the transitional arrangements that are envisaged over the next several weeks and months in relation to the coming into effect of the will of the national Parliament as expressed by legislation passed in this place recently. There has been quite a bit of hysteria generated in various newspaper articles. It has been claimed, for example, that there is some sort of gap which will result in an amnesty for corporate crooks, and so on, which is absolute, utter nonsense. If I had time I would read out the whole article by Chanticleer in today's Australian Financial Review where the facts are separated from hysteria in the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) plan. However, I would rather answer Senator Durack's question.

ANSWER.PARA: It is the intention of the Commonwealth to proceed to establish the Australian Securities Commission as soon as possible. Honourable senators will be aware that the State and Northern Territory Ministers on the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities have been advised by the Attorney-General of the Government's intentions; that was made clear in press reports. In the event that one or more States institute proceedings in the High Court to challenge that legislation, the Commonwealth will consider immediately the implications of those proceedings for the commencement of the various elements of the corporations legislation.

The Government is aware of newspaper reports that Western Australia and Queensland may be considering a challenge. I am advised that they have not yet done so, and apparently did not indicate doing so, at the Ministerial Council meeting. At that meeting the States indicated that it was up to each State to reach its own decision on that matter. The fact of some unrealised threat hanging over the package by way of constitutional challenge will not delay the Commonwealth in moving quickly to establish the ASC. This will enable the Australian Securities Commission to begin work immediately on the development of a concrete implementation plan for the Commonwealth to assume responsibility for the administration of companies and the regulation of the securities and futures industries. In addition to responding to the calls of the business community for the early resolution of the outstanding issues, the purpose of the implementation plan would be to ensure its smooth transition to the new national arrangements. The Government will not be bringing the ASC into full operation until it indicates that it is properly ready to administer those laws.

To go to the heart of the question, Senator Durack and other senators will be interested to know that the present intention is for a phased introduced of the national scheme. While details have yet to be settled, the first stage of a phased introduction would most likely involve the initial operation of those parts of the new Australian laws covering takeovers and the securities and futures industries. This will give the ASC an initial focus on the important national activities in the share market. In the meantime, the ASC would be able to establish the administrative framework to assume control progressively of the other areas such as prospectuses and the registration and regulation of companies. The onus is on the States not to act to disrupt or disadvantage the business community and to cooperate with the Commonwealth in an orderly changeover to the new arrangements. We believe that, as more articles in the Chanticleer tone and tenor are written, that message will start to get through.

In answer to the final part of Senator Durack's question, existing investigations and prosecutions will not be affected by the passage of the Commonwealth laws. The National Companies and Securities Commission and the corporate affairs commissions will continue to investigate and prosecute breaches of cooperative scheme law. These matters are properly the responsibility of the States as they involve offences under State law. However, the Australian Securities Commission will have the capacity under clause 13 of the Australian Securities Commission Bill to conduct investigations into contraventions committed under State and Territory companies and securities law, including those laws which were in force prior to the coming into effect of the national legislation, if it considers it to be expedient for the due administration of the national law. Under section 6 of the Director of Public Prosecutions Act, the Director will be able to take over existing and future prosecutions on behalf of the States.

That is a rather lengthy answer but I believe the importance of the topic raised by Senator Durack merited such a response. I hope it indicates to the business community the intentions of the Government as far as the implementation of the scheme is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his very helpful answer and I am sorry to have to ask a supplementary question because it was a very careful and detailed answer. One question still remains outstanding. Will the Commonwealth Government, in the process of the transitional arrangements and timetables that have been indicated, be seeking to enter into cooperative arrangements with the States as envisaged in the new legislation for the detailed administration of companies?

—Honourable senators will be aware that the Federal Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, went out of his way to offer a cooperative approach to the States. He wrote to them indicating the way in which various corporate affairs commissions at the State jurisdictional levels might be usefully integrated into a national scheme with consequent recompense and revenue-sharing by the States. That proposal was rejected by all of the States and by the Northern Territory. Therefore, that leaves the Commonwealth free to establish the Australian Securities Commission and administrative arrangements at its will. The Attorney-General will be establishing the Australian Securities Commission and its various administrative networks, as I say, in a way which does not need to take account of the offer that the Attorney-General made in April 1988-12 months ago-in a most cooperative spirit, rejected as it was by the States and the Northern Territory. Nevertheless, I imagine that, as the States come to grips with the reality of the situation, further consultations will be held.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health whether he has seen recent articles in the Sydney Morning Herald indicating that general practitioners (GPs) have indicated that they will increase their fees by $5 a consultation from 1 August. Is the Minister concerned about this development and, if so, what discussions have taken place to resolve it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the reports in the Sydney Morning Herald referred to by Senator Collins. The new general practitioner fee arrangements are designed to provide incentives for general practitioners to take part in continuing medical education to ensure that they maintain and improve their skills. The aim is for doctors to be rewarded for their efforts in undertaking general practice training, just as they are for physician or surgical training.

ANSWER.PARA: It needs to be remembered that, under the proposal, no GP will be disadvantaged and no GP will be worse off. Current items will remain in the schedule for those doctors who choose either not to register or who are ineligible. However, some 90 per cent of general practitioners, both full time and part time, will be automatically eligible and, if they register, they will be able to use a new higher set of GP fees and rebates. In return, they will need to take part in continuing medical education and quality assurance programs. The Government believes that this will result in better trained general practitioners generally who will provide better quality patient care.

However, if this were blocked, general practitioners and their patients would be deprived of $136m in increased Medicare rebates. I believe that the Opposition and the Australian Democrats need to be aware that they will be held responsible if the vast majority of GPs are deprived of fee and rebate increases equivalent to $15,000 a year in the case of GPs. As well, the 5 per cent across the board increase to most fees and rebates, including all specialist items, could not proceed from 1 August as planned because of the disorder created by those in the Opposition ranks. Let me quote yesterday's news release from Dr Peter Doyle of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners on how general practitioners will need to increase their fees by at least $5 from 1 August if legislation is not passed. These are his words:

The options facing general practitioners are either to absorb cost increases, which means lower incomes, or charge patients more. Those most at risk are pensioners and the socially disadvantaged patients, whom doctors have traditionally treated at a significant discount for many years.
Failure to pass the legislation will make it increasingly difficult for GPs to provide adequate care to this important group at an affordable price.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Why did the Governor-General send a message of condolence, on behalf of the Australian people, to the Government of Iran on the death of the Ayatollah Khomeini, given that the Ayatollah was neither head of state nor head of government of the Islamic Republic of Iran?

—I will seek a definitive answer for Senator Watson. I understand that a message was sent. Whether the late Ayatollah could be technically regarded as neither head of state nor head of government is an intricacy of foreign affairs protocol that I do not think I want to get involved in; I will leave that to the professionals. I will try to get an answer for Senator Watson.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Is it not a fact that the Governor-General, in sending this message of condolence, was acting as the Australian head of state and that it has been past practice to send such messages only in regard to the deaths of heads of state or heads of government in countries with which Australia has diplomatic relations?

—I did not quite hear the last part of the honourable senator's question. I understand that it is the practice for the Governor-General, as head of state, to send messages of condolence to other countries where the head of state has died. Apart from that, I do not have anything to add to my previous answer.

—Is the Minister for Resources aware of a report in Monday's Sydney Morning Herald which stated that a Federal coalition government may allow the resumption of sandmining on Fraser Island and rainforest logging in the wet tropics World Heritage area? Is the Minister aware of Senator Puplick's personal explanation about the report? Would the Minister advise whether a resumption of sandmining and logging is possible and, if so, under what circumstances?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see the article in Monday morning's Sydney Morning Herald. I must say that I paid a great deal of attention to Senator Puplick's personal explanation which does not in any sense detract from the point of the article. In the dissembling that he entered into, I think he confirmed that there is a genuine worry that a Liberal-National party coalition would undertake sandmining on Fraser Island.
—Mr President, I take a point of order. It is clearly out of order for the Minister to say that the honourable senator was dissembling. He should withdraw that statement.
—I ask the Minister to withdraw.
—I withdraw, Mr President. I cannot quote what Senator Puplick said because I do not have a copy of the Hansard with me.
—Make it up.

—I will not make it up. If members of the community read Senator Puplick's words, they would be able to draw their own conclusions about the significance of what he said. However, what he has said does not scotch the possibility, that must be held to be real, that a Liberal Party government would allow sandmining to resume on Fraser Island.

ANSWER.PARA: I think these facts need to be made quite clear: Fraser Island is a unique and fragile environment. Following a report commenced under the Whitlam Government, a decision was taken by the Fraser Government to end sandmining in October 1976. The Fraser Government took that decision at that time for environment reasons and that decision was enforced by the use of the Commonwealth's export control powers. I now see that Martin Tenni, the Queensland Minister for Mines and Energy, and Geoff Muntz, the Queensland Minister for Environment, Conservation and Tourism, have said that there will be no mining on Fraser Island. but I have checked these facts today. Leases for mining on Fraser Island, which run for 21 years, were issued by the Queensland Government some time back. Despite what Muntz and Tenni have said, those leases have not been withdrawn; they are still active. There are only two possible reasons why those leases have not been exercised: Firstly, the price of the product of sandmining does not make it economic-anyone who looks at the indicators would see that that is not true; in fact, sand mining would be a very economic activity-and, secondly, the Commonwealth Government maintains, by the use of the export control powers, the ban applied by the Fraser Government.
Let me, therefore, go to the coalition's draft policy on energy and resources and refer to the subject of export control powers. That policy states:
We will abolish all export controls on the minerals and metals sector, except where such exports infringe on national security or international obligations.

In that case, these powers would not be used by a Federal coalition government-if it were to take office-to prevent sandmining on Fraser Island because national security and international obligations are not involved. Fraser Island is not a World Heritage area.
Let me turn to the Opposition's environment policy, released by no other than Senator Puplick in October 1988, to see whether there is some comfort there. That policy states:

The coalition parties have already indicated that they reject the improper use of the external affairs powers of the Constitution to interfere with proper land use policy decisions of the States or Territories or the orderly development of our economic resources. This policy repeats that assurance. Land use policies are primarily the responsibility of the States and the Territories and they should not be circumvented by the improper use of the indirect powers granted to the Commonwealth.

One presumes therefore that, even under the environmental policy released by Senator Puplick in October 1988, a coalition government would not obstruct the Queensland Government from the continuance of those leases and the starting up again of sandmining on Fraser Island.
Let us look at the words used by Senator Puplick in his personal explanation-a copy of which I now have before me. He said:
. . . any proposal for a renewal of mineral sands export activity would have to be considered by Cabinet and would be decided entirely on its merits, including obviously, its environmental ones.
That is in no sense a disclaimer that a Federal Liberal-National Party coalition government would not bow to the will--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. Standing order 99 states that questions shall not contain hypothetical matter or ask for an expression of opinion. The Minister is hypothesising about what a Liberal-National coalition would do. He is also expressing his own opinion. Mr President, I ask that you ask him to finish his answer.
—Order! The Minister has spent some time on his answer. I ask him to conclude as quickly as possible.

—Thank you, Mr President. I propose to do that. I have cited the policies. If those policies are hypothetical they are hypothetical only in the sense that it is very unlikely that the Opposition will ever get a chance to implement them. Nonetheless, that is the record. It is a proper conclusion that by no means is there any guarantee that a coalition government, should the coalition take power, would not do as coalition governments have done in the past and bow to a National Party government in Queensland, reopen sandmining on Fraser Island and overturn a Fraser Government environmental achievement-about the only one the Opposition can point to. Puplick is right at the heart of that. That is a matter of record.
—Order! There is a growing tendency for senators to call members of parliament by their surnames only, which I regard as being out of order.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, by noting that the Government has reached the benchmarks it set itself for the eradication of child poverty and by quoting from an article by Adam Farrar based on the achievement of those benchmarks in 1989 and published in the May 1988 Australian Council of Social Service publication Impact. The article states:

QUESTION.PARA: One question that apparently won't go away for the government is how serious it is about eradicating child poverty by 1990 . . . what is clear so far is that the package has gone a little less than half way to eliminating the need for children to live in poverty . . . and studies make it clear that sole parents . . . need most attention in the next round of measures . . .

I ask the Minister, firstly, whether the Federal Government's abject failure to deliver in its April 1989 economic statement any support to meet the special needs of single parent families means that they and their children have become the forgotten poor within Australian society; and, secondly, when the Federal Government will introduce measures designed to deal effectively with the poverty traps that single parents continue to face.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article. Reading the first part of it I thought that the researcher involved needed to do a refresher course. Senator Powell's question is based on a false presumption, a false inference from the article in question that the Government did absolutely nothing in the April economic statement to meet the special needs of single families. Nowhere in the article that Senator Powell refers to is that point made or developed. Sole income parents are not the forgotten poor under this Government. This Government has always recognised a need to address their particular problems. This Government has always seen the particular problems facing sole parents as a social tragedy. It is not a recent development, and that has to be recognised as well. In the way the Government normally approaches these issues, we have done that.

ANSWER.PARA: It should be recognised that in the 1970s and the early 1980s there was an explosion in the number of sole parents living in poverty. One stark figure indicates that fact more than anything else. Whereas, in 1974, 105,000 sole parent pensioners constituted 57.4 per cent of all sole parents, in 1983 the figure had risen to 82 per cent. So, by 1983, 82 per cent of sole parents were pensioners.

We are not happy with the situation. As I have said, we have addressed the problem consistently during our term of government. We have responded by rejecting income policies that imprison people in poverty traps and by introducing a whole raft of different measures. The child support scheme is one such important measure that is in place, and the family allowance supplement is another. We have also addressed the question of work force barriers, for instance, with measures addressing problems with pensioner earning credits and the retention of fringe benefits in certain circumstances. Those measures have gone some way towards addressing work force barriers for sole parents.

In addition, in 1987 the child free areas under the income test were increased, once again allowing sole parent pensioners to earn additional non-pension income. We have also recognised, however, that income support is vital. Income support for families with children, including sole parents, has been a priority of this Government since 1983. To that extent we have increased additional pension and benefit rates paid for children in every year of our term, the most recent increase being made in 1989. From 1983 to 1989 there has been an increase from $10 to $31, a three-fold increase, for younger children, and for older children the figure has gone up to $34.10. So there has been quite a substantial increase in income support for these families.

I refer to the family package announced earlier this year. We have made adjustments to family allowance, and the higher levels of payments under the family allowance decisions of this Government will also assist the families whom Senator Powell is concerned about. We should not forget the historic decision announced in the April statement to index these payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is ridiculous.

—It is not ridiculous. This is a serious matter which this Government is addressing and one which we will continue to address. It is of concern not just to this side of the Parliament. Let me address the specific part of the question which refers to the April statement. I will not have to go through it in depth.
—Turn it up. We are bored.
—It is not my fault that this Government's record in this area is so extensive that it needs to be explained.
—Order! I ask Senator Bolkus to ignore the interjections and answer the question.

—I will address two points, the April statement and work force impediments, which need to be addressed in any comprehensive answer. Sole parents benefited from almost all of the April statement measures. Sole parent rebates were increased and indexed; the family allowance was increased and indexed; the family allowance supplement was increased and automatic adjustment was provided for; and mothers or guardians allowances were indexed. Bringing forward pension indexation by 12 weeks will also assist. I do not need to go into any depth on the jobs, education and training program and the way it is geared towards addressing work force barriers experienced by sole parents. I will conclude with a statement from the Brotherhood of St Laurence issued in May this year--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Bolkus, I ask you to conclude your answer.
—I will conclude. The Brotherhood said:

ANSWER.PARA: We congratulate the Federal Government on its work on child poverty, which represents a historic breakthrough in the national attack on child poverty. The Federal Government has now built a solid foundation of income security for Australian families.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If those opposite do not like it they will stay there and enjoy it.

—Order! I point out that there have been only five questions in nearly 30 minutes. I realise that the answer to the first question from the Opposition went for 8 1/2 minutes, but I ask Ministers to take that into account.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Although I know it seems incredible after the Minister's long answer, I need to ask the Minister whether he agrees that the fact that there was no increase in the supporting parent's benefit or in the mothers guardians allowance-the only two benefits directly applicable to sole parents-in the April statement lends weight to my question regarding when the Government will act specifically on the issues concerned with sole parents. The other matters the Minister has mentioned are matters relating to families, whether they are sole parent families or dual parent families, which are much better off.

—I will not give Senator Powell a long answer. I refer her to the answer I have already given and stress the point that all these initiatives have a direct beneficial effect on the parents she is concerned about.

—Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce seen the article in the Adelaide Advertiser of 3 June 1989 headed `Winemakers Change Tack on Tax', which reports that the wine industry has decided to move away from a campaign focused entirely on wine stock tax to a broader examination of its industry, affecting domestic viability and its ability to expand exports? Can the Minister tell the Senate what forms of assistance the Government is currently providing to assist wine and brandy producers, particularly the boutique wineries, to find, develop and expand overseas markets for their products and what further assistance could be provided?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The article in question has been drawn to my attention.
—Surprise, surprise.
—It is not surprising, Senator.
—On notice again?
—No, this is a question from Senator Crowley.
—Who gave you the question and the cutting?

—Mr President, Senator Crowley drew my attention to the article in question and asked me to obtain some information. That is a totally legitimate function of Question Time. If Senator Newman does not understand that now, perhaps she will in a few years time when she has a bit more experience. I know of Senator Crowley's longstanding interest in the wine industry and, therefore, I obtained the following answer.

ANSWER.PARA: First of all, I welcome the emphasis on expanding export markets, wherever they happen to be. Exports of Australian wine have risen rapidly in recent years from $17m in 1984-85 to $97m in 1987-88. This has been across both bulk and bottled wine. To come to the point of the question of what government assistance there is in terms of wine exports-which, as I have just pointed out, have grown significantly-Austrade is active in the promotion of Australian wine overseas, in association with the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. Austrade posts assist exporters in finding markets by putting them in contact with potentially interested importers and distributors. In addition, the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation and wine exporters participate in a number of Austrade-sponsored trade displays and promotions in a range of overseas markets. For example, the Austrade post in Paris is now involved in assisting with arrangements for an Australian industry display at Vin Expo in Bordeaux, which will take place from 19 June to 23 June. That is the premier show for the wine industry internationally. Similarly, the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation is involved with Australian participation in a big wine show in Cologne in October 1989, and there have been similar efforts in North America, Scandinavia, the United Kingdom and, of course, Japan. The amounts of money and assistance provided by Austrade are in addition to the export market development grants scheme for trade promotional activity overseas. In the expansion of the horizons of the wine industry-I notice Senator Messner, who took up the cudgels on behalf of the wine industry in terms of the sales tax--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about interest rates?

—This expansion is very welcome. Senator Newman rabbits away about interest rates. The expansion is taking place, and will continue to take place. Senator Crowley-who has a legitimate interest in this subject, as distinct from Senator Newman-and the industry can be assured of the Government's continuing assistance in this area.
—We have a wine industry too.

—I knew the senator would introduce at the end of her interjections a parochial consideration in this matter. We are talking about an Australian industry which is expanding its export activity and doing so very successfully.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SCHOOL OF DENTISTRY, UNIVERSITY OF WESTERN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. In view of the moves of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training to reduce funding levels for tertiary institutions which have necessitated the proposed amalgamation of the University of Western Australia and Murdoch University, I ask, firstly, whether the Minister can confirm or deny that the Government is contemplating the withdrawal of funding from the School of Dentistry at UWA, thus ending the training of dental students at that institution and in Western Australia, with all future dental students being forced to study interstate. Presuming the foregoing, what savings does the Government anticipate it will achieve? Secondly, does the Government acknowledge that this cut in funding will have further financial consequences for UWA due to the loss of foreign student enrolment? Finally, what level of student enrolment in dentistry at UWA would be required by the Government to make the dentistry course capable of receiving ongoing financial support?

—I do not know on what basis Senator Panizza rests his assertion that funds to tertiary institutions have been cut. What I have been asked to do, principally, is confirm or deny that the School of Dentistry at the University of Western Australia is about to close. I cannot do either, I am afraid, because I do not know. I will try to get an answer from the Minister for Employment, Education and Training before the end of the week, which may cover some of the other points or allegations raised.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. It relates to the Beecroft Peninsula. Given that Beecroft Peninsula is listed on the Register of the National Estate for its outstanding aesthetic values, habitat diversity, vegetation and archaeological significance and is part of a greater Jervis Bay Estate registration, does the Minister agree that bombing the Beecroft Peninsula is compatible with protecting its natural and cultural values for present and future generations of Australians, consistent with its listing on the National Estate? Does the Minister seriously contend that because the Beecroft Peninsula has been continuously bombed for some 50 years, that level of abuse of national heritage is a justification for continued bombing? Does the Minister acknowledge that the current protests about the Beecroft bombing are an expression of the growing support for Aboriginal land claims which, unfortunately, were not a reality when the bombing commenced some 50 years ago? Given this situation, what measures will be taken, in accordance with section 30 of the Australian Heritage Act, to seek prudent and feasible alternatives to adverse effects caused by bombing to this National Estate area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I had a look at a map yesterday, not just of the Beecroft Peninsula but of the impact area of the firing range, which takes up only a small proportion of the Beecroft Peninsula.
—Minuscule.

—Not quite minuscule, but small anyway. I had a look at that map because I was interested in the very questions which Senator Vallentine raises today. I have to say that, having had a look at the size of the impact area, I doubt very much whether National Estate values in Jervis Bay are being destroyed by the Navy, at least in so far as this exercise goes in any event.

ANSWER.PARA: However, the question of Aboriginal sites is interesting. I would agree that there is increasing community concern about Aboriginal land rights and the protection of their sacred sites. That is certainly true. But when I consider this question, it seems strange that if this range was used as late as one week ago, when 100 rounds were fired into it from two Navy ships, those Aboriginal concerns had not been brought to the attention of the Department. As I mentioned in my answer yesterday, the Department is aware of 25 sites of significance in the area. Of those, only one is within the impact area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they archaeological sites?

—I will answer that interjection in a moment. It is called the Drum and Drumsticks, but because the site consists of offshore rocks it has not been bombed since, I think, 1986, which was when its significance was notified to the Department. I share concerns about Aboriginal sites, but the number has jumped from 25 to 200 in a fairly short time, and we will have to examine this question. It is very difficult for the Department of Defence to take into account information which has never been brought to its attention. I am a little disappointed that so much is being made of the Aboriginal argument on this occasion because, even as late as a week ago, this claim did not exist. It has come very late on the scene.

ANSWER.PARA: I am asked, by way of interjection, about these sites. I said yesterday that about 90 per cent of the sites in question-that is, the 25, because we do not know what the other 175 might be-are middens, and 70 per cent of those have already been disturbed. In terms of looking at National Estate values on the Beecroft Peninsula, I do not agree that they have been destroyed by the bombing, because the impact area is rather small. It does not cover anything like the whole of the peninsula.

On the question of section 30 of the Heritage Act and the possibility of feasible alternatives, I point out that there are in fact only two sites on the entire east coast that are used for these purposes. One is at Shoalwater Bay in Queensland and the other is at Jervis Bay. I do not believe that residents anywhere on the east coast or environmentalists would welcome the Department of Defence choosing any more sites. To attempt to do so would cause more problems than the use of the current two. So I should say that on environmental grounds I have not advised the Department of Defence to cease using Beecroft Peninsula.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HUON FOREST PRODUCTS PTY LTD: WOODCHIP EXPORT LICENCE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In view of the conflicting statements made by the Minister prior to the Tasmanian election, can he inform the Senate what decision he has finally made regarding the issuing of a licence to Huon Forest Products (HFP) Pty Ltd for the export of woodchips?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The decision on a licence for HFP is not a matter for me, so I have not made any such decision. I am not aware of any conflicting statements that I have made, but to clarify the exact position for Senator Walters, I point out that some time ago an examination was carried out of the resource available in Tasmania. That involved people from the Department of Forestry in Tasmania, from the Department of the Minister for Resources and from my own Department. After that exhaustive examination had been carried out, the Commonwealth determined that there was sufficient resource available for the Huon Forest Products mill to go ahead. I do not think that there is any doubt about that.

ANSWER.PARA: In more recent times, of course, there was an election in Tasmania. The Gray Government is about to be defeated on the floor of the Parliament and a new government will be sworn in. I am told that that new Government will not permit Huon Forest Products to go ahead. It was always within the province of the State Government to determine the way in which it would allocate resource. So I do not believe that there is any conflict. It will be up to the new Government to make the decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I take it from the Minister's answer that he has no problem with the issuing of a licence for that particular project?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Even Senator Walters would find it difficult to place that construction on what I said. What I said was that the Commonwealth had determined that there was sufficient resource. The way in which that resource is to be allocated is a matter for the Tasmanian Government. If the Tasmanian Government were to decide that it did not have to go ahead in its present form, then I would have no objections whatsoever.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Resources been drawn to the Australian Mining Industry Council's (AMIC) mineral production index for the March quarter 1989? Does this show that the index of mine production was 11 per cent higher in the March quarter than in the same period in 1988 and that, on a seasonally adjusted basis, mine production increased by 2 per cent compared with last year's December quarter? With increased outputs of coal, iron ore, copper, lead and gold outweighing declines in uranium, diamonds and tin, what benefits are likely to accrue to the Australian economy as a result?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of the question is yes. In fact, I have a copy of AMIC's mineral production index for the March quarter 1989, which I table for the information of the Senate. The second part of the question referred to the 11 per cent higher mine production output for Australia in the March quarter. The answer to that part of the question is yes, that is true. Our statistics verify that. In fact, the results of the Australian Mining Industry Council's index are broadly in line with the March quarter outlook by the Agriculture and Resources Quarterly, which is a publication put out by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, known as ABARE, which has forecast that the value of Australia's commodity exports will rise by $2.6 billion or 8 per cent in 1988-89 as compared with the previous year. In 1989-90, the ABARE forecast is for a further improvement in our commodity exports-a 10 per cent increase to $40 billion. The factors affecting this increase include a 3 per cent increase in the volume of commodity exports as a whole, a slightly lower average exchange rate and a wide range of world price increases for commodities.

ANSWER.PARA: As ABARE explains, one of the key factors that will influence Australia's prospects for a better balance of payments outcome will be the future level of world commodity prices. The downturn that we experienced between 1984 and 1986 was unusual in that most commodity prices trended in the same direction at that time-downwards. It is more usual for commodity prices to be divergent, responding to their own individual supply and demand conditions. ABARE stated in its March quarterly review:

The key feature of the present commodity price recovery is that supply constraints for a wide range of commodities are likely to permit markets to hold price gains for some time. This applies to many metals and grains and is also an underlying feature of markets for meat commodities. However, the reverse appears to be the case for precious metals.

The Bureau predicts that the volume of mineral production will rise by 3 per cent in 1989-90 compared with the 13 per cent increase for 1988-89. For 1989-90, significant increases in production are expected to occur in coal, uranium, aluminium, gold and iron ore. That is the market-related side of the story.

The other half of the story is the micro-economic reform that the Hawke Government has engaged in during its period of office. That micro-economic reform, which has led to greater efficiencies in the mining industry, covers a whole range of things. I cannot go into all of them, but I mention the reduction in tariff protection which will benefit the mining and minerals processing sector to the tune of $350m; the fact that during the period of this Government and for the future of this Government the prices and incomes accord has lent wage stability to the industry in a climate of high economic growth, reduced industrial disputation, caused unit labour costs to fall and higher productivity per head to be achieved; and that in the May economic statement last year we reduced corporate taxes to 39 per cent. All those elements of the Government's micro-economic reform package have helped the mining sector reach the targets that have been referred to by Senator Jones and which are supported by our own independent surveys from the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Did the Minister say in the Senate yesterday that people investing in interest bearing securities will have reaped windfall gains as a result of the Government's high interest rate policies? Have holders of government fixed interest bonds, particularly members of superannuation funds, incurred substantial windfall losses in the value of those assets as a result of those high interest rate policies? How can the Minister claim that members of superannuation funds will not lose one cent in the value of their share in the fund? Did the Minister also claim yesterday that the Opposition's amendments to the Government's new superannuation tax would cause fund managers to invest in foreign businesses rather than in Australian businesses? Why does the Minister contradict the Treasurer's comment on page 8 of his 1988 May economic statement when he said that those who invested in foreign businesses would not be penalised because they would receive credits for dividend and interest withholding tax on income received from foreign sources? Why did the Minister, therefore, mislead the Senate yesterday?
—I point out that part of that question referred to the debate that is currently before the chamber, and I would ask the Minister to take that into account.

—I am not sure whether I got all the questions down, but it is a fact that if there has been a general rise in interest rates long term government securities decline in price. But the holders of those securities lose money only if they sell the securities, not if they keep them until maturity. If cash investments are being turned over when they are reinvested, or if new funds are being invested, they would have been invested at a higher interest rate and that is the basis of what I said yesterday. As for the allegation about contradicting the Treasurer, I did not.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What action has the Government taken in response to the harsh treatment of ethnic Albanians in the Yugoslav autonomous province of Kosovo?

—I have a note about this somewhere. I am also in luck; I found it. My note says that the Government is concerned about reports of human rights violations in Kosovo province in clashes between demonstrators and security forces in that province. An ethnic Albanian majority is largely opposed to recent changes which have reduced the autonomy of the province. The constitutional status of Kosovo is clearly an internal Yugoslav affair. The Australian Government is nonetheless disturbed at the widespread use of force to suppress the demonstrations and also by the resort to violence by some of the demonstrators. The Australian Embassy in Belgrade has been asked to convey to the Yugoslav authorities the Australian Government's concern about several specific allegations of human rights abuse which have been passed to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade by the parliamentary group of Amnesty International. The Government supports the universal observance of internationally accepted standards of human rights and urges that those standards be observed by the Yugoslav authorities in their dealings with the unrest in Kosovo.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Is one of the consequences of Labor's high interest rate regime the fact that the Government must automatically pay by way of subsidy to Westpac Banking Corporation an additional $17.5m for every one per cent interest rate increase under the defence service home loan arrangements? If so, in view of the precedent of these subsidies to Westpac by the Government, is the Government considering other assistance to offset the additional costs to thousands of other Australian home owners?

—Under the agreement with Westpac, the Commonwealth subsidy is tied to the prevailing rate of interest. That is in practice no different from the pre-existing arrangements under which loans were made at a rate of, I think, six and seven-eighths per cent, I think it was-that was the rate charged the borrower-and the Commonwealth borrowed directly from the marketplace to provide the loans. So under both regimes, although there would be different timing effects, the Commonwealth was underwriting interest rates above six and seven-eighths per cent.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and refers to the recent report entitled Canberra's Environment by Dr Gary Scott, which the Minister launched earlier this week. Does the report indicate that Canberra is under significant threat of air and water pollution from vehicle emissions, solid fuel heaters and high sediment levels in lakes and rivers? What action will the Federal Government take in response to Dr Scott's suggestion of a joint Federal-Australian Capital Territory (ACT) long term environmental plan to deal with this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that on any reading of that report one could make the statement that Canberra's environment was under a significant threat. As a general point, if honourable senators read that report they will see that the opposite is probably true-Canberra has an environment that most of the bigger Australian cities would be proud to equal. But the report does highlight that on some days, even in a place like Canberra, particularly during the winter, lead pollution from motor cars equals that of Sydney. That is an alarming point. There are also problems with the waterways here on occasions and they have been the subject of some investigation in recent times.

ANSWER.PARA: A long term environmental plan for the Australian Capital Territory would primarily be the responsibility of the new ACT Government rather than the Commonwealth. So we shall not interfere with its no doubt great efforts to achieve that in the comparatively near future. The report entitled Canberra's Environment is recommended reading for the citizens of Canberra and for as many people here as are able to afford the time. I hope it offers a blueprint for how we might look at the environment in other cities and work from there.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the Minister's comments on Melbourne radio yesterday when he took the same position on Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines as the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport and Communications; that is, they should not be owned by the Government. In particular, I refer the Minister to his following words:

QUESTION.PARA: It's very difficult, I think, to find reasons why in the 1980s and 90s, government should own airlines. They don't anywhere else hardly and why we should be in that position I don't quite understand.

I ask the Leader of the Government: Given the strong support of Mr Willis, Mr Hawke and him for the Government to sell the airlines, why did Government senators yesterday vote against a motion which endorsed this position?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have in front of me the motion which was before the Senate, but if it was moved by the Opposition I assume that it was defective.
—Would you like a copy of it?
—Sit down. I am answering the question.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Does the honourable senator want to turn this into a clown place? He stands up at his seat and waves documents. He should behave himself. I do not have the document before me, but I understand that if Senator Alston moved it it would probably be defective in some respect.

ANSWER.PARA: I stand by the views I expressed yesterday on radio, which Senator Alston quoted. But in so far as he identified earlier in this question my position as being identical with that of Mr Willis and Mr Hawke, I am not sure that that is correct. I do not believe that I said that. Senator Alston has perhaps failed to grasp the fact that many of these issues have a degree of complexity about them which is not susceptible to a simple solution. As attractive as the honourable senator might find simple solutions, they are not readily available to people.

In so far as Senator Alston quoted what I said yesterday, I stand by that statement. As I have said in the Senate on previous occasions, there are very different views within the Government on this question. Hopefully this will be resolved by a committee which is examining those issues for the Government at present. When that is done, if we reach a particular conclusion about it we will implement it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's failure to be aware of the form of words used, I remind him of the urgency motion which stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The need for the Government to ensure the future of Qantas and Australian Airlines by their sale to the public, as suggested by the Minister for Transport and Communications and supported by the Prime Minister.
In view of that refreshing of his memory, I ask him how he would have voted if he had been here yesterday? Can he explain why the Government voted against that urgency motion?

TALK.START.PARA: —The first reason why the Government voted against that motion is probably that we do not regard it as a matter of urgency. Of course the Opposition regards it as a matter of urgency. Having slept on these issues for 30 out of the last 40 years when in government and done nothing about them, they are suddenly a matter of urgency for the Opposition. It is urgent because it thinks that a political point can be made out of it at this particular time. I answered the question which was the substance of what Senator Alston was trying to get at earlier on. I answered the question when I said that the Government is having a committee examine these issues. When that committee determines its conclusions--
—A great cop-out.
—Senator Boswell is talking about cop-outs. What is he talking about? It is a disgrace the way he has changed his position in parliament in recent weeks. It is intolerable.
—It is not a matter of urgency! We understand. Let them go bankrupt.

—It is not a matter of urgency. Senator Lewis, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, gave us a speech this morning. He thinks that all the economic problems of this country will be fixed up by a rash of sales. It is probably what Senator Alston thinks too. We do not believe that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance in that capacity and also in his capacity as Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware that certain Australian public companies have made arrangements so that their shareholders can choose between receiving franked and unfranked dividends? What are the effects of this practice on investment in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of one company that has sought to establish such a scheme, that is, Elders IXL Ltd. I understand the reason for that is that Elders does not pay enough Australian company tax to fully frank all of its dividends. The reason for that is not necessarily anything shonky but that Elders derives a substantial part of its income from overseas investments. Under the scheme which Elders either has established or plans to establish, Elders will pay a differential dividend rate with a higher rate being offered on unfranked dividends than on franked dividends.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the effects of that policy if the imputation of franked dividend benefits were not available to superannuation funds would be that superannuation funds would have a very clear incentive to invest in companies which paid unfranked dividends or, offered the choice of unpaid dividends at a higher rate, dividends earned by investment in overseas businesses.

Imputation benefits to superannuation funds are therefore essential to ensure that the life savings of Australian workers go towards investment in productive Australian industries and the provision of jobs for Australian workers and their children in the future rather than in investment in overseas businesses. There are some other elements of this that I will not go into at this stage. At some later stage I may make the Senate aware of them and of some of the other arrangements or rearrangements which are currently taking place or which are planned to take place in the ownership structure of Elders IXL.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EMPLOYEE OF THE MINISTER FOR EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING

DEBATE.TITLE: SHIPPING AND WATERFRONT INDUSTRIESGOVERNMENT BUSINESS ENTERPRISES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I make two statements on behalf of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) entitled (a) Reform of Shipping and the Waterfront, and (b) Implementation of Government Business Enterprises: Reforms and Telecommunications Pricing. I seek leave to incorporate the statements in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statements read as follows-
REFORM OF SHIPPING AND THE WATERFRONT

The House will be aware that the Government has been developing a comprehensive program for reform of the shipping and waterfront industries. I am pleased to be able to advise the House today of the measures we will be taking to implement these major elements of microeconomic reform.

Through various reports commissioned by this Government, it is now common knowledge that Australia has been poorly served by its shipping and waterfront industries. The gross inefficiencies which have been allowed to develop in these industries have restricted our economic growth, reduced our living standards and impaired our capacity to develop export markets. In part, our balance of payments difficulties are directly attributable to the acute inefficiencies in these key industries in the export chain. The reforms I am announcing today will dramatically transform these industries. They will lead to quantum increases in efficiency over the next three to five years and will in turn enable our industries, which depend on sea transport, to become more flexible and more efficient.

Most of all, our reform package is practical, based on commonsense and developed through consultation. It is not based on abstract theory or ideological dogma. It is a practical agenda for cooperative and effective reform which will reap maximum long term benefits for the industries, their customers and, indeed, all Australians.

The structure of our inquiries reflects our commitment to consultation. The Shipping Reform Task Force, which we established to investigate the scope for developing new reform initiatives, was chaired by Mr Ivan Deveson, Managing Director of Nissan Australia, and comprised senior representatives from shippers, ship operators, the unions and government. The report was agreed by all members and released on 20 April.

We also asked the Inter-State Commission, an independent statutory body within my portfolio, to report on measures to reform the waterfront. During its inquiry the Commission took evidence from stevedoring industry employers and unions; commercial operators; Federal and State interests; and importers and exporters. The Commission's report was released on 6 April. In proposing a detailed strategy for reform, the Commission recommended an in-principle agreement between Government, waterside unions and employers as a central element of its plan. It has therefore been necessary for the Government to hold intensive discussions with industry parties to ascertain their views before finalising its position.
Shipping

Our work on shipping builds on earlier reforms introduced by this Government. In 1984, in response to the report of the Crawford Committee on Revitalisation of Australian Shipping, we introduced taxation incentives which led to new ships coming into service in 1984 with crews as low as 26, well below crew levels for such ships of an earlier generation which were in the low to mid-30s.

The Crawford scheme represented a critical turning point for the industry. It introduced a pattern for reform with ship owners and unions working together in a constructive way, for users and the economy as a whole. It made possible the establishment in 1986 of the Maritime Industry Development Committee (MIDC), representing ship owners, unions and the Government which, in turn, initiated a radically new approach to operating Australian ships using the concepts of multi-skilling, broadbanding of jobs and the integration of functions.

The MIDC initiatives resulted in crew sizes on new ships being further reduced, for example from 26 to 21 on a dry bulk carrier. There are now five ships operating in the Australian fleet with MIDC crewing levels and a further 15 ships are on order. These reforms have been achieved in a period of unprecedented industrial harmony in the shipping industry. In 1982, 4.1 per cent of ship time, or 1,593 ship days, were lost through industrial disputes. Last year only 0.2 per cent or 72 ship days were lost. This dramatic change has been brought about partly by the reduction in demarcation disputes through union amalgamations and partly by the industry's determination to improve its efficiency and public image.

The shipping reform task force, which recently reported to the Government, has proposed a three-year reform strategy which will not only close the competitive gap between Australian shipping and its Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) counterparts, but will also lead to further efficiency improvements after 1992. The Government has accepted the task force proposals and will work with the industry and its users to implement the reform strategy.

At the heart of this strategy is a program for reduction of the size of crews on existing ships. This is a major step forward which, taken together with the Maritime Industry Development Committee initiatives, will transform the efficiency and competitiveness of Australian flag shipping over the next three years. These crewing initiatives will save a total of $80m in crew costs by mid-1992 and at least $50m per year thereafter. They will reduce the average crew size on major trading ships from 29 at present to 21 over the next three years. When we came into office the average crew size on such ships was 33. Initiatives taken by the Government will therefore reduce average crew sizes by 36 per cent in less than a decade.

The Government will support this recrewing program by contributing up to $24m of the estimated $80m required for voluntary early retirement schemes for the 1,000 jobs which may be lost over the three-year reform program. This contribution will ensure that shipowners can quickly pass on to users the benefits of crew cost savings.

To recrew pre-MIDC ships, we will expand the skills upgrading programs currently in place. The Government will fund up to half the cost of retraining seafarers required to operate such ships, up to a total of $5m over the three-year program. With existing training programs it will be possible to reduce crews on the most modern ships to 17 or 18 before mid-1992. To reduce crews even further it will be necessary to integrate officer functions; that is, to train officers in both navigation and engineering skills. The Government will work with the industry to design and introduce the necessary training courses before July 1990, so that suitably trained personnel will be available by 1993. This will allow Australian ships to operate with crews of between 14 and 16, or even less. The magnitude of this achievement can best be illustrated by looking at the crew sizes on dry bulk ships; the mainstay of the Australian fleet. Such a ship, introduced in 1983, would have had a crew of 32. A decade later a new dry bulk carrier will be able to be introduced into service with a crew of 16 or less; at least a 50 per cent reduction.

The task force also recommended the abolition of first-class air travel for seafareres; adoption of measures to reduce waste in victualling; development of a more efficient and, therefore, less costly compensation system; re-examination of study leave arrangements; and further development of dispute settlement procedures. The Government strongly supports the implementation of these measures, which would further reduce costs and cut the crew to berth ratio by about 10 per cent.

Shipping is a highly capital intensive industry and the fiscal regime is therefore critical to ensuring continued investment. The current fiscal regime for new ships of 7 per cent taxable capital grants and accelerated depreciation, introduced in support of the MIDC scheme, puts Australian shipowners in a broadly comparable position with their OECD counterparts. To provide a stable framework that supports the reform strategy for the industry, the Government has decided to extend the current fiscal regime for new ships for five years from the scheduled expiry date of 30 June 1992. Also, the 7 per cent taxable grant will now be available until 30 June 1992 to cover the cost of any necessary modifications to existing ships for operation with smaller crews.

Under the present fuel excise arrangements, 26 per cent of the excise on marine diesel is hypothecated to land transport development programs at an approximate cost of $3m a year and, therefore, directly subsidises competing modes of transport. The Government accepts the task force's argument that this is an unfair burden on coastal shipping and has agreed to rebate the hypothecated component of the excise from 1 July 1992.

Since the 1920s successive governments have maintained a cabotage policy which requires that coastal cargo be carried in Australian controlled and crewed ships, whenever possible. This policy has not prohibited foreign flag ships from the coast. Where no suitable local ship is available, permits are issued for single voyages to allow foreigners to enter the coasting trade. In the 12 months to the end of March 1989, 38 permits were issued allowing a half a million tonnes of coastal cargo to be carried in this way.

The cabotage policy was carefully examined by the shipping reform task force. No member recommended its withdrawal but it was suggested that changes be made to the application of the permit system to increase its flexibility. The task force pointed out that almost all major maritime nations have a cabotage policy, including our leading trading partners, Japan and the United States. The only exception to this is the United Kingdom, although even there legislation imposing cabotage restrictions has been recently passed, but not proclaimed.

Governments almost everywhere consider that coastal shipping is part of the domestic economy and that it should be treated no differently from other domestic transport sectors. The Government agrees with the task force that the permit system should be made more flexible and has decided that new guidelines will be issued for the operation of the permit system. These will apply to single voyage permits and will also include the use of permits for continuous trading which, although allowed for under the Navigation Act, have not been issued for 20 years.

These continuing voyage permits, which can be issued for up to three years, will improve efficiency and competitiveness in the coastal shipping market in a number of ways. For example, small, irregular shippers, particularly those operating from remote locations, will be given greater choice when undertaking coastal voyages. The risks associated with new trades will be reduced because the use of continuing voyage permits could establish viability. This will encourage the development of new raw materials processing opportunities. When existing raw materials processing is experiencing an upsurge in demand, the continuing voyage permit process could be used to supplement local coastal tonnage to ensure that short term needs are met from domestic sources. The continuing voyage permit system could also be used by shippers to improve the overall efficiency of their shipping through promoting a greater integration of coastal and international trading. For example, an Australian shipper might relinquish part of its coastal trades to foreign ships in exchange for greater access for its shipping in international trades. In this way both Australian and foreign flag ships could minimise their ballast voyaging, thus benefiting both domestic and international users of Australian raw materials through lower freight rates.

These examples illustrate ways in which the changes to the permit system will provide greater flexibility and hence benefit shippers. Providing a better deal for shippers has been a key objective of the Government, which has been concerned to ensure that the efficiencies resulting from crew reductions and the other benefits of the reforms announced tonight are passed on. The Government will therefore ask the Prices Surveillance Authority to inquire into and monitor coastal shipping rates. If, nevertheless, it becomes clear over the next three years that shippers relying on others for their coastal shipping are not benefiting from reform through lower freight rates, the Government will give serious consideration to including price as one of the criteria used when assessing permit applications.

There are three areas where the task force did not reach a final position but where the Government considers that further action is desirable. The first of these is trans-Tasman shipping. When the closer economic relationship between Australia and New Zealand was reviewed and renegotiated in the middle of last year, both governments agreed that it was vital to pursue measures to reduce the costs of shipping across the Tasman. In trans-Tasman shipping, onshore costs represent 50 per cent of total costs-routes are short, cargo volumes are low and port visits are frequent. In addition, shippers expect continuing high and stable service levels. Both governments therefore agreed that reduction of waterfront costs is essential to reduce the cost of trading across the Tasman. High priority was also given to the introduction of low cost, more efficient vessels. The shipping needs of fledgling and specialised trades were put at risk because of the high costs of Australian and New Zealand shipping.

The waterfront and shipping reforms which I am announcing and reforms which are being introduced in New Zealand will have a substantial beneficial impact on trans-Tasman shipping costs. In addition I will be holding discussions with the New Zealand Government to determine the scope for further reductions in trans-Tasman shipping and waterfront costs prior to the achievement of free trade between the two countries on 1 July 1990.

The second area where the task force did not reach a final position involved company employment for ratings. Unlike the waterfront, there has been little consideration of the issue. In any case the lack of company employment has not impeded recent, major changes to work practices on ships. In fact, both shipowners and unions acknowledge the value of the engagement system and recognise that, even with company employment, some use of supplementary labour would be required to overcome occasional shortages. Nevertheless there may well be advantages in moving to company employment and this issue should be kept on the longer term reform agenda. Finally, there is the towage industry. I will be referring to further reform in this area later in the statement.
The Waterfront

Twenty years ago containerisation was introduced to Australian ports. It fundamentally changed the face of the waterfront. The number of cargo handling waterside workers has reduced from 21,000 in the years before containerisation, to a little over 5,000 now. Between 1965 and 1985 the amount of non-bulk cargo handled by each waterside worker increased from 1,000 tonnes to over 5,000 tonnes a year. Despite these large increases in labour productivity the fact is we have not kept pace with our overseas competitors. The last major set of changes to industry arrangements was in 1977 but these did little to improve the performance of the industry, which has remained grossly inefficient. Apart from the changes forced on the industry by technological developments, both employers and unions on the waterfront have failed to adapt to meet the demands of a fiercely competitive world.

The Inter-State Commission has found the waterfront industry in urgent need of fundamental change. It is right. It is characterised by ineffective management and poor work force motivation, introspective industrial attitudes, high costs, endemic unreliability, poor response to user needs, abuse of monopoly power and a pervasive lack of competition. This is not a situation that has developed recently-it is how we found the industry when we came into office. Soon after coming to office the Government therefore brought the industry parties together through the Webber task force to identify the causes of waterfront inefficiency and unreliability. In response to the issues raised by the task force the Government in 1986 directed the Inter-State Commission to examine all aspects of the waterfront and develop an integrated plan to improve its performance.

The Commission has pointed the way toward thoroughgoing reform of the waterfront. The Government accepts the fundamental thrust of its findings. Reform will be complex and contentious but it is essential to our economic well-being that it be achieved. Success will depend on allowing the competitive forces of the marketplace to operate more freely, and on active cooperation between the major interests. Competition and cooperation are hallmarks of our reforms.

The Government will be pursuing change in three broad areas in line with the Commission's recommendations: the stevedoring industry where there will be a fundamental change in employment arrangements shifting from the current practice of industry-wide employment to enterprise-based employment for stevedoring labour; port authorities, where the Government is pursuing with the States, and the Northern Territory measures to improve the efficiency of port authorities and services they influence; and measures to create a more competitive commercial environment.

The Inter-State Commission made recommendations on a range of other issues, including improvements to land transport access to ports, documentation procedures and the introduction of electronic data interchange to the waterfront industry. The Government has accepted the vast majority of the Commission's recommendations in these areas and will be pursuing them in consultation with relevant parties.

Central to the Commission's proposals for the stevedoring industry is the negotiation of a three-year in-principle agreement between the Federal Government, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, stevedoring unions and stevedoring employers on restructuring the stevedoring and international container depot operations. Following detailed consultation with industry parties the Government has concluded it should be possible for the industry parties to negotiate an in-principle agreement acceptable to the Government. This will be the foundation for the achievement of substantial waterfront reform. As proposed by the Inter-State Commission, the Government is providing the industry parties with up to three months to negotiate this agreement. Provided there is an agreement satisfactory to the Government we will be prepared to commit up to $154m on a dollar-for-dollar basis with employers towards the costs of redundancy payments, training, retraining, skills audits and job redesign projects. We are prepared to allocate this money as an investment in the future. The costs involved are substantial, but there is a critical need for change in this vital sector of the economy. The benefits envisaged by the Inter-State Commission of at least $620m per annum in terms of cost reductions and improved reliability are essential to our export competitiveness.

The central elements of the Inter-State Commission's proposals for the in-principle agreement involve the transfer of employment responsibilities to individual enterprises. This will improve competition, enhance employer-employee relationships and reduce costs to the shippers. But in moving to enterprise employment we must ensure the work force has an adequate level and mix of skills and that its working environment motivates employees to accomplish their tasks effectively. Regard must also be had to the high proportion of older workers in the industry where the work force has an average age of over 50 years. We have therefore accepted the Commission's recommendation that rejuvenation of the industry requires a special retirement and redundancy scheme coupled with a recruitment program to bring trained workers into the industry. This will involve 3,000 existing employees leaving the industry over three years and the recruitment of 1,000 new employees no older than 30.
The Government believes that a satisfactory agreement will need to include firm commitments from the industry parties on the following matters:

1. The introduction of enterprise employment arrangements into the ports of Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Fremantle within three years. Employment arrangements in Adelaide will need to be consistent with the principles of enterprise employment.

2. Flexible supplementary work force arrangements must be developed on an enterprise basis for major ports consistent with the Commission's recommendations. Compatible arrangements will need to be agreed to for small and intermediate ports.

3. Awards and agreements must be restructured consistent with the structural efficiency principle of the 1988 national wage decision. This will enable improvements in work organisation designed to increase productivity, efficiency and reliability through the negotiation of specific implementation agreements.
4. Employers are to provide, on a dollar-for-dollar basis with the Government, $0.5m for workplace restructuring projects to facilitate agreements on changes to work patterns and arrangements.

5. New employees are to be recruited directly into individual enterprises with recruitment in the first year being in accordance with existing industry procedures. In subsequent years each enterprise should determine the recruitment procedures to be followed in consultation with relevant unions.

6. Consistent with the Commission's recommendations current industry arrangements regarding compulsory redundancy for existing employees are to be retained. Arrangements for compulsory redundancy as a last resort for all new recruits are to be allowed at the end of the three year implementation period.

7. Employers and unions must commit themselves to develop and support industry-based training schemes and enterprise-based training programs. The development of the programs and schemes should ensure they are appropriate to the needs of the stevedoring and international container depot industries, linked to the introduction of new job structures through retraining of existing employees, and related to the recruitment program.

8. The Federal Government will provide up to $8m for improving training facilities, the training of new recruits and the retraining of existing employees to facilitate job restructuring. Employers will be required to provide a matching amount.

9. A one-off early retirement-redundancy scheme for the next three years is to be established based on the entitlements recommended by the Inter-State Commission. In negotiating the in-principle agreement parties will need to develop arrangements to more specifically `target' redundancy offers to meet the needs of the industry. Supervisor categories will be covered by these arrangements and this should facilitate reduction in excessive layers of supervision.

10. Employers are to provide up to $145m on a dollar-for-dollar basis with Government to fund the early retirement-redundancy offers. The Government is prepared to facilitate the collection of employer contributions through statutory levy arrangements for a period that is demonstrated to be necessary and subject to the levy rate not exceeding present combined statutory and industry levy rates for this purpose. It is expected that the levy would apply for no longer than three to four years.
11. The parties must accept that permanent inclusions of stand-down provisions in awards is a matter to be pursued through normal Industrial Relations Commission processes.
12. The parties must make a commitment to develop and adhere to agreed disciplinary and dispute settlement procedures to improve industry reliability and efficiency.
13. They must also agree to arrangements to enable the effective contracting out of maintenance work where it is more efficient than in-house facilities.
