14. The Government will be phasing out the existing cross-subsidisation of stevedoring labour costs in small ports through statutory levies over three years. The parties will therefore need to commit themselves to introduction of measures to improve the efficiency of small and intermediate ports through revised employment arrangements including enterprise employment, commercial port labour pools and use of port authority labour.
15. Constraints that limit competition in international container depot operations must be removed.
16. Where stevedoring employees are employed in association with the loading and unloading of bulk vessels employment arrangements will be in accordance with efficient operational requirements.

17. Finally, agreement by the stevedoring and international container depot unions must agree to rationalisation of union coverage at small ports, international container depots and bulk terminals. Agreement is to be reached through consultations under the auspices of the ACTU.

A firm timetable for progressive implementation of specific elements is an essential requirement of an in-principle agreement. Government assistance will be provided only when specified objectives within the timetable have clearly been achieved. Conditional on the conclusion of a satisfactory in-principle agreement, the Government will also provide up to $100,000 towards the conduct of a special study for the development of safety proposals for the industry, $250,000 for union research staff to assist unions in the implementation of the in-principle agreement and $100,000 towards consultants for skills reviews.

The second broad area where the Government will pursue reform is in relation to port authorities and their roles in the waterfront industry. The operations of port authorities are matters of direct State and Territory responsibility and we will be seeking to pursue reform in this area in cooperation with the States. I wrote to State and Territory Ministers on the release of the Inter-State Commission's report asking that they give early consideration to the Inter-State Commission's recommendations. I will be meeting with them soon to discuss their reactions and what actions they propose to implement the proposals.

The Government endorses the broad thrust of the ISC's recommendations in relation to port authorities. It is clear that there is room for substantial improvement in their performance. Port authority managements need to operate at maximum levels of efficiency. Port pricing practices need to be modified to reduce cross-subsidies and reliance on cargo based charges. The Government is convinced that port authority efficiency will be best achieved by commercialising their operations; that is, Government port authorities should be put on a business-like basis as far as possible-along the lines of the reforms which the Federal Government is currently implementing with regard to its own business enterprises. Because of their monopoly powers port authority pricing is a particular area of concern to shippers and shipowners. The Government agrees with the Inter-State Commission's recommendations aimed at ensuring greater transparency in port pricing and a closer relationship between costs and services provided. This issue will be receiving close attention during my discussions with State and Northern Territory governments. Port authorities can play a central role in encouraging a more competitive environment in ports for such services as stevedoring and towage operations through leases and licensing arrangements. The Government believes that port authorities should be taking a more effective, pro-competitive approach than they have in the past in these areas.

The Trade Practices Commission's role in this industry will also be enhanced. The Government will ensure that the TPC has the additional resources and backing necessary to apply the Act to those areas identified in the ISC report. The most important of these are the international container depot and towage industries.

The Prices Surveillance Authority can also play an important role in monitoring prices and ensuring that the benefits of changes in the waterfront industry flow through to their customers, the importers and exporters. The Government will therefore be requesting the Prices Surveillance Authority to monitor prices in the waterfront industry with particular attention being given to the stevedoring, international container depot and towage industries. Formal surveillance or inquiry processes will be put in train if necessary.

The Inter-State Commission found on the basis of evidence given to it and research undertaken by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics that the towage industry is not competitive. The Bureau concluded that harbour towage charges were high, tug utilisation low, crew sizes high by comparison with other countries and there was a lack of competition between tug operators. There is clearly room for major improvement in this industry. The shipping reform task force called on the towage industry parties to develop a reform strategy for the industry and report to the Government within three months. The Government will expect it to produce major improvements in line with those proposed for commercial shipping. Furthermore, in my discussions with State and Territory Ministers I will be examining ways to improve competition in the towage industry, such as the introduction of licensing by port authorities to encourage greater competition. Additionally the Government agrees with the Inter-State Commission's recommendations that the Trade Practices Commission should consider reviewing the authorisations that it has granted in relation to towage operations at a number of ports to assess whether these continue to be in the public interest.

The Government believes that implementation of the radical reforms which I have announced for the waterfront industry will bring about the restructuring necessary to generate the large productivity improvements predicted by the Inter-State Commission. In our view, these prospective productivity increases would be further enhanced by the introduction of profit sharing or employee share ownership schemes. The joint ventures initiated by the Waterside Workers' Federation in some small ports have highlighted the efficiency gains to be achieved by profit sharing arrangements. Such schemes would also reinforce the concept of enterprise employment by promoting closer identification by waterside workers with their enterprise and its financial viability.

The comprehensive program I have just outlined will bring substantial and highly beneficial change to the waterfront industry. It offers benefits to the customers, the industry participants and the nation. In line with the Inter-State Commission report, the program's achievement rests substantially on the cooperation of the parties. If, however, that cooperation is not forthcoming, the industries should be under no illusions about the Government's firm commitment to achieve significant waterfront reform. I will report back to Cabinet within three months on the results of the negotiations on the in-principle agreement. If a satisfactory agreement is not achieved, we will pursue alternative measures to change these industries structurally.
Implementation of Shipping and Waterfront Reforms

As I have already mentioned, the Shipping Reform Task Force and the Inter-State Commission both recommended three-year implementation periods for the shipping and waterfront reform strategies. They also recommended independent authorities to oversee the detailed development and implementation of these reform packages. The Government has accepted this approach and will shortly establish the Shipping Industry Reform Authority (SIRA) and the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority (WIRA) which are to run for three years. Both will bear major responsibilities of overseeing and monitoring the day to day implementation by the industries of the reform plans that have been agreed to by the industry parties and by the Government. I expect both authorities to work co-operatively with the industry parties to meet the agreed objectives. Disbursement of Government restructuring assistance by the authorities will be contingent upon achievement of strategy targets. Reform will have to be carried through in a systematic and comprehensive way.

The first task of the Waterfront Authority will be to supervise the negotiation of the in-principle agreement. The Authority will also monitor other industry negotiations in order to ensure that they are consistent with Government requirements for an in-principle agreement and prepare for an immediate start to reforms once an agreement is signed. It will also ensure that the arrangements for recruiting new entrants will conform with Government requirements.
Australian Maritime Safety Authority

To further enhance efficiency and contain costs to industry the Government has decided to establish an Australian Maritime Safety Authority. The Authority, which will replace the Maritime Operations Division in my Department, will administer the standards and procedures for the construction, equipment and safe loading of ships; the qualification and training of crews, the provision of marine navigational aids and the complementation of anti-pollution measures. Such an Authority will be more responsive to industry needs, while remaining properly accountable to Government. The Authority will be controlled by a board with membership drawn from industry and Government to bring appropriate management skills to the conduct of these important commercial and safety functions. The Authority will be largely self funding through user charges payable by the industry. The cost of providing and maintaining marine navigational aids is already fully recovered through light dues. Similarly, the costs of the national plan to combat oil pollution are paid for by a levy on commercial shipping. The Shipping Registration Office recovers over 80 per cent of its costs on a fee for service basis and is expected to achieve full cost recovery by 1990-91. Charges are made to recover the costs of marine survey, except where the surveys are for regulatory purposes. The Authority would also continue to provide a seamen's engagement system as long as the industry wanted it. The Government's aim is to bring the Authority into being by 1 September 1990.
Light Dues

The system of marine navigational aids provided by the Australian Government for the safe and efficient movement of vessels in Australian waters is paid for by light dues charged to commercial users. Traditionally light dues have been paid at a single rate per net registered ton. This is the practice for light dues around the world. The rate is currently 53 cents and has remained unchanged since 1983. Following representations from certain sectors of industry, the Government has reviewed the basis for payment of light dues and the formula used to set the rate for individual ships. It has decided that there is a case for providing relief for some of the largest vessels. The new formula provides for a sliding scale of charges by tonnage ranging from 63 cents to 33 cents per net registered ton. This will lead to a reduction of dues for large vessels of about 20 per cent and has been achieved without imposing any large increase in fees for the smaller vessels. To illustrate this point, a small coastal vessel of 200 net registered tons will pay only $20 per quarter more, while a large bulk carrier of 72,000 net registered tons will pay $6,900 per quarter less. Ships in the middle tonnage range will experience no change.
Conclusion

These measures represent the most wide-ranging package of reforms ever introduced for Australia's waterfront and shipping industries. They establish a firm basis for continuing reform. On the basis of the findings of the Inter-State Commission and the Shipping Reform Task Force, these measures will greatly increase productivity and create a more competitive environment in our shipping and waterfront industries. They will reduce costs to our exporters and import competing industries, will create new job opportunities and will bring benefits to all Australians by ensuring a more competitive economy. Such improvements are not simply desirable; they are crucial to our future economic well being. Australia has paid dearly for the benign neglect of those opposite who, during their three decades of postwar Government of this country, allowed these industries to become a burden on the nation and a barrier to economic progress. The reforms I have outlined today will ensure that these industries will have a far more positive impact on the economy in the years to come. I commend the reforms to the Senate.
Government Business Enterprises
GOVERNMENT BUSINESS ENTERPRISES
REFORM STATEMENT

My portfolio contains 10 major government business enterprises (GBEs) operated by the Commonwealth. They are Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines Ltd, Australian National Line (ANL), Australian National Railways Commission, Telecom Australia, Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC), Aussat, Australia Post, the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA), and the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC). These latter two enterprises were established last year to radically restructure safety regulation, the provision of aviation services and related infrastructure. During the past six years the Government has systematically worked to put the operations of its transport and communications enterprises on a sounder financial footing and to make them more efficient, more flexible and more businesslike. We have given that task a high priority because of the strategic importance of the GBEs in the Australian economy. It is not a task that we have only recently started. Throughout the Government's three terms we have focused on micro-economic reform, including deregulating the financial system, reducing levels of protection and reshaping the GBEs. In our third term we have given greater prominence to micro-economic reform and accelerated reform of the GBEs.

The eight GBEs-excluding the Civil Aviation Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation-are important in their own right. They account for over 9 per cent of total public sector employment. They take up more than 15 per cent of all Government investment-which comes to more than two thirds of the investment by the Commonwealth Government. Their revenues equal 19.7 per cent of Commonwealth Government revenues, and their expenditure is equal to 18.7 per cent of Commonwealth spending. Their assets are worth over $22 billion and government investment in the enterprises, through loans and equity, amounted to in excess of $8 billion as at June 1988. Moreover, the GBEs are of strategic importance to every other sector of the economy. They are an essential part of the economic infrastructure on which efficiency gains and export efforts in other sectors of the economy depend. Reforming the GBEs is integral to our micro-economic reform agenda because those reforms have a multiplier effect on productivity and competitiveness throughout the economy. They help to determine the speed and efficiency with which goods and services can be exchanged, markets can be developed, trade can be expanded, information can be processed and decisions can be made in every industry in Australia.
Streamlining the GBEs

We have progressively modernised and streamlined the GBEs. The work on reforming the GBEs started early in the life of the Government with essential capital injections for the government airlines, Qantas and Australian Airlines, and for Australian National Line. The Ministerial statement on guidelines on Government statutory authorities and GBEs operations of November 1987 placed the reforms in a comprehensive policy framework. This framework was further consolidated in another ministerial statement of May 1988 on re-shaping the transport and communications GBEs. These reforms are now being implemented on a number of fronts, including exhaustive overhauling of legislation, new regulatory arrangements, revaluation of assets, calculation of community service obligations, the preparation of detailed corporate plans and the setting of financial targets for all GBEs. The Government has now put in place coherent and comprehensive change to the GBEs. The changes are coherent because they are all aimed at making the GBEs more enterprising and more businesslike. They are comprehensive because they affect every aspect of the GBEs structures and functions. This statement explains more specifically what these changes to our GBEs are designed to achieve and reports on the benefits which are now flowing to the economy and to the community generally.
Objectives
All the changes to the GBEs are designed to serve the same critical objectives. These objectives are:
to enable the GBEs to perform more efficiently and effectively, on a commercial basis, in an increasingly competitive environment;
to make the GBEs more financially viable, so that their demands on the Budget are reduced and they have a secure financial base from which to expand and diversify their operations;
to focus the Government's involvement in the operations of the GBE on their strategic direction and financial accountability-put simply, to shift the emphasis from inputs to outputs; and

to ensure the GBE provide substantial and growing benefits to the community, including through a strong emphasis on quality and service, fulfilling the designated community service obligations, where appropriate, and prices that have been constrained in various ways.

We have not imposed change according to some ideological bureaucratic blueprint. In each GBE, the reforms made have been specifically adapted to the particular service the enterprise is providing, the market it caters for, the competition it faces, the assets it holds, the investments it has made, and the returns it has been able to deliver. The changes have been pragmatic and flexible. We have taken pains to make sure that in each case we have adopted the most effective approach to achieve reform.

The process of reform is not yet complete but the policy framework we have established will ensure that the GBE will always remain responsive to the need for change. But our achievements have already been substantial and thorough. They are achievements on which all sectors in the Australian economy can build in the years ahead. Those changes will facilitate and accelerate the structural adjustment on which our future competitiveness-which means, among other things, our ability to create jobs and to maintain our standard of living-will depend.
Financial Base

The GBEs are now financially viable and have a solid base for future growth. When we came to office, Australian Airlines, Qantas and the Australian National Line were grossly undercapitalised. They had been starved of equity capital and their scope for future development was severely restricted. At the outset we took decisive action to provide the injection of equity so badly needed, which allowed the airlines to take advantage of the tourist boom and the massive growth in air traffic which came with it. In 1983, Australian Airlines had a paid up capital of only $40m and $25m of that had been injected only in the very last days of the Fraser Government. The Airline's debt to equity ratio was over 90 : 10, which imposed a severe burden of high interest payments at a time of declining business in the airline industry. In the two years 1981-83, Australian Airlines's losses amounted to more than three-quarters of what had been its paid up capital. This situation was completely untenable, and was immediately addressed by the Hawke Government through an equity injection of $90m in our first Budget. That made the Airline financially viable and put it on a competitive basis. It has not looked back.

Profits earned by Australian Airlines since 1945 when it was established from all sources amount to $176m. Eighty per cent of this amount, $143m, has been earned since 1983. Since 1945 its dividends to the Commonwealth have amounted to $66m of which $28m has been paid in the last two years. In 1987-88, Australian Airlines earned $1.1 billion in revenue for an operating profit of $66.6m before tax. After tax, and extraordinary items, that amounted to a return on equity of 21.5 per cent. The Airline has been able to expand and diversify its operations, and to improve the quality of its service. None of that could have been done without the Government's early financial support.

The improvement in the performance of Qantas is also striking. The Hawke Government has provided Qantas with an injection of $60m in capital, more than two-thirds the amount that had been provided in all the previous 37 years in which the Airline had been operating in government hands. Since 1947, when the Commonwealth acquired all of the shares of Qantas, the company has earned profits from all sources amounting to $564m, of which a staggering $485m, or 86 per cent, has been earned since the Hawke Government came to office in 1983. A similar picture applies to dividends. Since 1947 the company has declared dividends amounting to a total of $137m, with $92m out of this amount being paid since 1983. In the 15 month period ending 30 June 1988, Qantas earned revenue of $3.9 billion, for an operating profit of $272m before tax and a 11.6 per cent rate of return on assets. Obviously these indicators of Qantas's performance within the environment created by the Hawke Government are quite spectacular.

In the case of the government-owned railway, Australian National, government reform has again resulted in a significant improvement in performance. In our term of office, Australian National's call on the Budget for funds has been cut by 63 per cent in real terms. In 1987-88, for the first time, Australian National recorded a small operating surplus on its commercial freight operations. We have gone further than any State government in giving our railway a commercial charter and its performance in the past few years has been unmatched by any other publicly owned rail system in the country.

A similar picture emerges with the Australian National Line, where we inherited an enterprise which was effectively bankrupt. ANL, in 1983, was a debt ridden, heavily subsidised loss maker, without any clear functions or direction. It is not that now. We increased ANL's equity base by $160.5m, to correct its undercapitalisation and high gearing. It has since implemented a rationalisation program which has involved hard decisions about the sale of some ships and termination of some services, and its performance has improved significantly. ANL has recorded a profit in each of the past four years and, in the next few weeks, it will be bringing forward a corporate plan designed to enable it to trade effectively in future years.

For the legislated monopolies, Telecom Australia, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission, Aussat Pty Ltd and Australia Post, profitability is not by itself an appropriate measure of performance. Other factors, such as service performance standards, real decreases in prices and levels of capital investment, are important performance indicators. Taking all these measures together, the GBEs are performing well by international comparisons. To enable better measurement of financial performance in the future, we are vesting, for the first time, a proper capital structure in Telecom and Australia Post. Also our complementary telecommunications policy reforms contain mechanisms for monitoring many of the non-financial performance measures.
Corporate Structures

The communications GBEs have been given the commercial structure necessary for them to deal with the challenges of increased competition, continuing technological change, and new demands and opportunities in the marketplace. Telecom and Australia Post have been converted from commissions into statutory corporations. Each has been restructured along modern lines, and established with a board of directors. Aussat has been given scope for expanding and diversifying its activities. OTC was transformed into a public company in April 1989 and now trades as OTC Ltd with a better capital structure.

Australian Airlines was set up as an incorporated company in April 1988. Australian National's Act was further modernised to give greater emphasis to the commission's commercial charter. ANL will be converted into a public company in July of this year. It was unnecessary to change the incorporated company status of Qantas Airways Ltd, as it already suited its commercial environment.
Strategic Direction

The Government's involvement in the operations of its GBEs is now largely confined to two basic strategic management controls-the discipline and accountability of a forward looking corporate plan, and of an agreed financial target. Corporate plans set strategic directions for the enterprises. They establish the business priorities that enterprises will use each day in guiding their decisions. They provide the Government and the enterprises with a clear sense of direction and a clear awareness of their common purpose and shared interests.

This has created a context for more innovative and creative commercial decisions. It is reflected, for example, in Qantas's acquisition of a minority share in Air New Zealand, in Telecom and OTC's successful bids for international contracts, in Telecom's initiatives in value added services in the telecommunications field, in Australia Post's work on electronic mail transmission, and in Australian National's continued exploration of opportunities for increased efficiency in inter-system railway operations.

It is essential that the community's assets are used in the most effective way by the GBEs. The setting of financial targets gives a basis for measuring their performance. The targets can include the rate of return on assets or shareholder funds, lump sum aggregates or profitability measures related to turnover. In making these assessments, we are taking into account past earnings, industry competition, the opportunity cost of capital, the cost of meeting community service obligations and the performance of similar private sector companies. No single indicator has been arbitrarily imposed on all the GBEs.

A prerequisite for setting financial targets has been the revaluation of GBE assets. That task will be completed by 1 July, with the exception of Australian National, the assets of which will be revalued over a five-year period. We have also had to assess the financial value of community service obligations. In Telecom's case, that task is being undertaken by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics under my portfolio in cooperation with the enterprise, and is now near completion.

In all cases, decisions on the financial target are a matter for extensive discussion between the Government and the enterprise. The targets are being set at a level which will oblige the enterprise to improve its performance and, in doing so, to ensure that the Australian people receive full value for the money they have invested in the GBEs. We will have an interest in making sure that these enterprises use their great resources as efficiently as possible, and that taxpayers-like shareholders in any business-obtain a proper return on their investment.
Loosening Other Controls

The Government has removed a large number of day-to-day controls on the GBEs. Most of those had outlived their usefulness and inhibited the taking of commercial decisions. The controls, which covered such matters as opening bank accounts, letting contracts, major purchases and construction programs, are now a thing of the past. At the same time the Government is loosening up a number of strategic controls. The enterprises have recently been given greater autonomy and independent responsibility in managing their industrial relations arrangements. Most of them have also advertised for, and appointed, chief executives under new terms and conditions which include new employment arrangements involving the abolition of tenure and more market related remuneration.

Yet in this regard it should be noted that the extent to which remaining strategic controls can be relaxed must take account of the macro-economic context in which we are operating. The interaction between macro-economic settings and micro-economic reform will continue to affect the timing and scope of further changes to government controls.
Community Service Obligations

For the GBEs, as for all other businesses, profits and return on assets are critical indices of performances. But they are not the only indices we use in assessing the performance of Telecom and Australia Post, which perform important community service obligations (CSOs). A CSO is a service that the enterprise is obliged to perform in the interests of the entire community, in circumstances where an enterprise acting solely commercially would not provide the service. Hence we have ensured that all Australians can have access to the high quality telephone service we have built up. Likewise, we have guaranteed that standard letters will continue to be carried at a uniform tariff within Australia.

The Government will retain control over the CSOs through the ministerial power to direct variations to the strategies and policies to be followed by Telecom and Australia Post in carrying out their CSOs. We have defined these obligations more clearly through new legislation. Provision has also been made for the corporate plans of Telecom and Australia Post to include the strategies and policies they intend to pursue to fulfil those CSOs. In addition, their annual reports will include an outline of these strategies and policies. We are breaking new ground in measuring the extent of the CSOs. The GBEs will be required to give an account of them.
Telecommunications Efficiency Gains

All members of the community will benefit from the greater efficiency of our GBEs, in the ways already specified and through lower prices. Telecom has recently implemented a $100m per annum cut in subscriber trunk dialling rates, and OTC has also announced a $50m annual reduction in tariffs. A three-minute phone call between Brisbane and Perth now costs only 55 per cent of what it cost when the Government came to office. Increases in standard postal charges have been kept well below the rate of inflation.

In the case of telecommunications services, we are now going further to ensure that efficiency gains flow through to every consumer of the service provided. That has meant determining new price control mechanisms. As a result, we will be applying price cap regulation as well as setting target rates of return for two of our telecommunications carriers and infrastructure providers, Telecom and OTC. Our aim has been to combine the price gap and the rate of return targets so that the carriers are pushed to achieve further gains in efficiency in delivery of services. Consumers will gain directly, and the whole economy will gain indirectly, from real price reductions for a basket of standard services and improvements in service efficiency generally.

The price cap will operate for three years from 1 July. After examining available productivity gains, and the various factors which influence the rate of return targets for the carriers-Telecom and OTC-we have set the formula for that period at Consumer Price Index minus 4 per cent. The price control arrangements also include ways of ensuring that proposed price increases for specified non-standard services will be subject to scrutiny by Austel, our new independent regulator. At the end of this statement I will be seeking leave to table a detailed account of the price control arrangements.

Our formula means that, overall, consumers of the standard telecommunications services are guaranteed to benefit from substantial real price reductions in each of the next three years. Efficiency gains will enable the carriers to meet the financial targets which have been set. The 4 per cent figure may be increased in subsequent years to take account of a different mix of rate of return requirements, increases in available productivity gains and greater efficiencies resulting from technological change.

We are making major complementary changes to the regulatory arrangements in telecommunications. More market segments are being liberalised. For example, customer equipment and value added telecommunications services are open to full competition. The activities reserved to the carriers-Telecom, OTC and Aussat-are more clearly defined in legislation. Telecom will no longer be the industry regulator as Austel will take over this task. Under legislation currently before the Parliament, Austel will be charged with a number of functions including protection of carrier responsibilities, protection of competitors from unfair practices of carriers, protection of consumers from unfair practices, promotion of efficiency of carriers and technical regulation of the industry.
Conclusion

Reforming the GBEs would achieve only limited results if it were not synchronised with other micro-economic reforms. I have referred already to our thorough-going review of the telecommunications policy framework. A package of reforms on the waterfront and coastal shipping is the subject of a separate statement which I have already made today. Those policy steps complement other moves already taken in the transport and communications portfolio including the termination of the two airlines policy; liberalised liner shipping arrangements; the new national arterial roads category of the Australian Centennial Road Development Program focusing on roads of economic significance; steps towards nationally uniform weight and speed limits for interstate road vehicles; and liberalisation of international passenger and freight charter flights. In addition, the Civil Aviation Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation will soon be subject to the same GBE reform process as other enterprises in the portfolio.

Our approach has been flexible and pragmatic. We have deliberately chosen the best way, which means the most effective and equitable way, to set the GBEs up to do their business. Our approach is, therefore, quite different from that of the Opposition which, during its terms in office, did virtually nothing to reform, or even to maintain, the GBEs. They were content to let these enterprises operate in an unbusinesslike way, producing minimum returns on capital and insufficient levels of customer service. As for the future, the Opposition has nothing to offer except a doctrinaire, ideological commitment to privatisation.

We have placed the GBEs at the cutting edge of micro-economic reform. We have pursued reform of the GBEs in the firm conviction that the upgrading and reshaping of our public enterprises will greatly assist Australia to become more efficient and more competitive in world markets. We are demonstrating that government enterprises can be efficient, even dynamic, and can compete strongly with the private sector. I commend the GBE reforms to the House.
New Price Controls for Telecommunications Services

A principal objective of the Government's micro- economic reform agenda is to improve Australia's competitiveness through greater efficiency. This is being achieved in the telecommunications sector by applying rate of return regulation and price-cap regulation to two of the country's public telecommunications carriers and infrastructure providers, Telecom Australia and OTC Limited.

The policy intention is that the combination of the price-cap and rate of return targets will encourage the carriers to achieve further gains in efficiency. Consumers and the economy generally will benefit from the real price reductions and gains in efficiency.
Price-Cap Formula

The new price controls will commence on 1 July 1989 and be administered by the new independent regulatory body, the Australian Telecommunications Authority (AUSTEL). The price-cap will regulate prices charged by Telecom and OTC for specified reserved services by limiting average price rises to a minimum annual percentage below the rate of inflation (CPI minus X).
Price-Cap Controls

The price-cap will operate for three years. Carriers will need to inform AUSTEL of proposed tariff changes and show how these conform with any relevant determinations issued under the Telecommunications Bill 1989 by the Minister for Transport and Communications. The carriers will not be allowed to implement the tariff changes unless informed by AUSTEL that the proposed changes conform with any relevant determination. The Government intends to direct AUSTEL to notify carriers on this matter within 28 days of receiving the proposed tariff changes.
The Value of X

The Government has decided that X, in the CPI minus X formula, will be set initially at 4 per cent per annum. This has been decided after consideration of the available productivity gains in the telecommunications enterprises and of factors affecting the carriers' rate of return targets. By setting X at 4 per cent, consumers and the economy generally will benefit from real price reductions each year. At the same time, the real gains in efficiency will enable the carriers to generate sufficient revenue to achieve their target rates of return.
Rate of Return Targets

Telecom's and OTC's rate of return targets for the three year period are being developed within the context of their corporate plans. The plans will include values for capital expenditures, borrowing requirements, taxation assumptions, the impact of asset revaluations, changes to their financial structures, and variations in operating costs.

Additionally, as part of the general reform package for government business enterprises, the carriers will be required to make dividend payments of a certain order to the Government. The dividend will be determined in part by the level of profitability, which itself may be affected by the level of X.
Determinants of X
The two major factors considered in the determination of X are:
(a) achievable cost reductions resulting from productivity growth and efficiency improvements in Telecom and OTC
(b) the setting of minimum target rates of return.

In determining the value of X, the Government considered estimates of achievable productivity gains in telecommunications services. Current studies of productivity measures in telecommunications enterprises suggest an available annual productivity increase of 3 to 4 per cent.

The Government also took into account the need for the carriers to improve internal efficiencies and to take advantage of available productivity gains. In this context, a value for X of 4 per cent per annum was judged appropriate. It will permit them to generate sufficient revenues to meet their rate of return targets, capital investment needs, income tax, required dividend payments and costs of community service obligations.

In setting the value of X, the Government also considered relevant work undertaken by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics, the Industries Assistance Commission and the Prices Surveillance Authority.
Future Values of X

The level of X will be reviewed by AUSTEL before the end of the first three years and the Government may increase it in subsequent periods given a different mix of rate of return requirements, increases in available productivity gains, and improvements in technological efficiencies.

AUSTEL will be responsible for arranging studies of the carriers' performance to provide a basis for setting the required productivity gains used by the Government to determine future values of X in the CPI-X formula. The studies will include comparisons of the enterprises' efficiency against their most efficient counterparts elsewhere in the world.
Application of CPI

The CPI figure from the previous financial year will be used in the formula. This will avoid difficulties associated with forecasting prospective CPI trends. In any financial year, Telecom and OTC will be permitted to increase average nominal prices by no more than the previous financial year's CPI less the reduction for X.

If the CPI-X figure is substantially negative (greater than one), the carriers will be required to reduce prices within the year. To prevent undue implementation costs, carriers will not be required to make immediate adjustments for negative outcomes of less than one per cent, and will be permitted to offset them against increases in later years.
Composition of Standard Services

Domestic services subject to the price-cap arrangements will comprise the standard monopoly services such as business and residential rentals and local and trunk call charges. Standard OTC services will be subject to a similar price-cap. For OTC, these comprise International Direct Dial and off-peak and operator-handled tariffs for various categories of countries for which OTC charges differential rates.
Weighting of Services

In applying the price-cap to an average of a range of standard services, the Government has decided to weight each service by its relative revenue contribution from the previous year. This approach avoids the need to forecast revenue growth for individual services or to implement retrospective adjustments.
Carry-Forward Arrangements

Annual carry-forward of unused allowable price increases will be permitted within the first three years to give the carriers flexibility to adjust their price movements during a period in which they will be undergoing financial restructuring and be subject to income tax payments in the 1991/92 financial year.

The carry-forward arrangements mean that the carriers will be allowed to retain an unused price adjustment entitlement from one year to the next, provided that in total prices do not increase in aggregate more than CPI minus X over the three years. The carry-forward arrangement will be reviewed by AUSTEL within the first three year period and a report submitted to Government before the commencement of the next price-cap period.
OTC Considerations

To allow for exchange rate and other international factors affecting OTC's revenues (eg, adverse movement in net payments to overseas administrations), the Government will establish special procedures for OTC. OTC will be able to request AUSTEL to report to the Government on the need to adjust the value of X for OTC in any one year where international factors affecting OTC's revenue require consideration.
In reporting to the Government on an OTC request to adjust the value of X, AUSTEL will be required to take into account an assessment of the productivity gains available within OTC.
Price Control of Non-Standard Monopoly Services

Prices for other than standard services will be a matter for commercial determination by Telecom and OTC in the first instance. However, the Government may use its power under the Telecommunications Bill 1989 to declare specific reserved services for the purposes of price control, whereupon price changes would become notifiable to AUSTEL and subject to disallowance by the Minister following a report by AUSTEL.
Determinations Under the Act

Appropriate determinations setting out the price-cap arrangements will be issued pursuant to the relevant parts of the Telecommunications Bill 1989. The Government expects the Bill will commence on 1 July 1989. A determination also will be issued for Telecom's connection fees and public telephone local call charges, requiring them to be scrutinised by AUSTEL and subject to disallowance by the Minister.
Motion (by Senator Button)-by leave-proposed:
That the Senate take note of the statements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —These statements were introduced into the House of Representatives last week and have already been the subject of considerable public discussion. They are statements about areas of reform which the Opposition regards as matters of very great urgency. We heard Senator Button in Question Time, just a few minutes ago, berating the Opposition because it regards matters such as this as matters of urgency. It seems to have escaped Senator Button and members of this Government that Australia is sliding ever deeper into a morass of debt, that the Australian people are feeling the effects of this through the extraordinary interest rates that they are paying and that there is vast dissatisfaction about the future which is now promised for this country under the policies which have been followed by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a drastic need for reform in areas such as the waterfront and coastal shipping and in the operations of government enterprises. I think one could sum up these statements by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) as saying that once again the Government is doing too little too late. What we have is an urgent need for reform. What we have from this Government is the lowest common denominator approach. It has gone just as far as the slowest member of the troop is prepared to move. As a result Australia will continue its slide into ever deeper debt and the sorts of matters which are of direct impact on the lives of Australians-interest rates in particular-will continue to be unbearable.

The simple reality of our economy was exposed by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). He said after the last round of debate in April that the problem for Australia was that we were consuming more than we produced. The fact is that these areas are areas where production is impeded and where we simply fail to achieve the production that is possible in Australia. They are areas of gross waste. They are areas of gross inefficiency. As a result they are areas which weigh heavily on our current economic failings. We had again during Question Time Senator Cook in one of his prepared statements talking with very considerable pride about micro-economic reform and its impact upon the mining industry. It is worth noting the response of representatives of the mining industry to the so-called reforms which we are dealing with today. Mr Lauchlan McIntosh, when asked to comment on the so-called reforms to coastal shipping and stevedoring in an interview just last week, said:

Well, we will just languish off and become more and more, a third rate country. We can't afford to do that. We've got great resources here, we've got some good people. We should have the technology and be able to build the ships, make them here and be able to use them on our coast. If we don't, other people will be processing our raw materials and adding value to them, rather than ourselves.

In that interview Mr McIntosh made the point that Australian resources are shipped overseas for treatment and have value added to them, to provide the wealth that this country requires, because it is far cheaper to ship them overseas than to ship them around our coast. That is a simple illustration of why this country is not creating the wealth that it could create and why our economic problems continue. The fact that this matter is regarded as urgent by the Opposition is indicated by the 12 Opposition speakers who have sought to take part in the debate. I think that the Government has allowed the balance of this afternoon for that debate. To facilitate as many senators as possible to speak, the time taken by most speakers will be shortened and I will not address the Senate for very long.

We are dealing with one of the fundamental defects in the Australian economy-one of those areas where we continue to strangle ourselves, where we continue to impede the production of wealth and, therefore, where we continue to impede our economic recovery. It is a very sorry record of failure when the representative of one of our leading industries refers to us as a third rate country. It is not a matter of the Opposition, in some narrow political way, attacking these issues and not having alternative plans. At the time of the April statement we tabled in the House of Representatives detailed proposals for reform in a number of areas, including those of coastal shipping and the waterfront.

It is not just a matter of engaging in partisan politics to condemn the Government's failure to come to grips with these matters. Commentator after commentator-users of these services-have all condemned the Government's proposals as totally inadequate. The Sydney Morning Herald, which over the years has been pretty even-handed in its treatment of the Government's economic policies, and indeed has often been full of praise for them, stated in a leading article following the release of the statements that Mr Willis's plan to reform coastal shipping `amounts to a huge bribe for minimal change'. The article went on to say:
Mr Willis's plan for the reform of waterfront seems hardly more encouraging. . . . Again there is to be a huge bribe for changes still to be negotiated.

So we have this too little too late approach-the lowest common denominator approach-and Australia suffers as a result. When one looks at what could have been done with coastal shipping, the difference between what is being done and the necessary changes becomes clear. The Opposition put forward a series of changes which would have introduced genuine pressure and competition in that vital area of Australian transport-an area which the Inter-State Commission (ISC) has identified as involving hundreds of millions of dollars worth of waste.

We find in the statement that trans-Tasman sea lanes-the scandal of the costly shipping between Australia and New Zealand, which is so inimical to our trade there-are not dealt with in any effective way. We find that the Government leaves Australian ships with a monopoly on the coastal shipping trade. There is no suggestion of the removal of cabotage which is the one guarantee that we would have of a genuinely competitive shipping service around our coast. The idea of enterprise employment has not been dealt with effectively. Instead, we find, again, that a system of pooled employment remains in force. That is, again, a formula for continued inefficiency. We find that the Navigation Act, with its strong emphasis on non-competition, has been left in place. In other words, there is no fundamental reform of our coastal shipping. What the Government has done has been to get together with the parties-those who have a direct vested interest in the operation of the system-and it has accepted the rate of change which is permitted by the slowest of the players. Quite simply, the Government has let this country down in this vital area.

The Government's approach to the waterfront is equally hopeless. The Government in this case asked the Inter-State Commission to give it a report which would deal with the area of conspicuous waste. The Inter-State Commission offered changes which it believed could save in excess of $600m per year-a $600m addition to our national wealth with a reduction of those unnecessary costs. It made the point that what it was putting forward was required to be done in a complete way. It made the point that a package of interrelated proposals needed to be undertaken. We as an opposition, who had a more radical plan for reform, offered our cooperation to the Government. In a statement which I put on behalf of the Opposition we made it clear that, notwithstanding the fact that we thought more needed to be done than the Inter-State Commission had proposed, we were prepared to go along with the Commission's proposals provided they were implemented in full by the Government. We said that we would facilitate the passage of legislation and that we would support the appropriation of the very considerable taxpayers' funds which would be required if the Inter-State Commission report is adopted.

The Government has gladly picked up the suggestion that further taxpayers' funds should be applied to this industry, on this the thirteenth occasion that it has been investigated and where changes have been recommended. The Government intends to put hundreds of millions of dollars of taxpayers' funds into redundancy arrangements and so on, but the Government has squibbed on the vital issues of ensuring that there is genuine competitiveness and employment at the enterprise level, instead of pooled employment, and that some of the more ludicrous union coverage arrangements are dealt with in an effective and efficient manner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't someone describe this as empty posturing on your part?

—The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce asks whether this has been described as empty posturing. Let me say that many of those who are affected by this have made it very clear that they regard the Government as engaging in empty posturing with respect to the reform of both coastal shipping and--
—It was a charge directed at you.
—Let me remind the Minister, who is at the table, of the view of those who are affected by these so-called reforms. For example, the National Farmers Federation--
—It is all very well to state the problem. How about the solutions to the problem?

—Again, the Minister at the table, who has shown himself congenitally unable to deal with any problem seriously when he is on the defensive, and who yesterday had to go back against his own words and beliefs on matters such as the deregulation guidelines, seeks to interrupt this debate because he knows that this is a third rate attempt by this third rate Government to deal with a genuine problem of which he, as a Minister, is fully aware. When the reports were released the National Farmers Federation said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government appears to be unwilling or afraid to impose reform on the waterfront and maritime unions. It has been frozen into inactivity.

In my press release, when I offered the Opposition's support to this paralysed Government, I did not say that it was frozen into inactivity; I said that it was a paralysed government. That has been proven true by subsequent statements. The National Farmers Federation made it quite clear that the reforms announced by the Government are totally inadequate. It made it quite clear that with respect to New Zealand the reforms have not been undertaken. In the same way, the Australian Mining Industry Council, through its Executive Director, Lauchlan McIntosh, has made it clear that adequate reforms have not been undertaken and the problems have not been solved. A group which is directly concerned, the Australian Shipping User Group-a group that was put together under the auspices of the Federal Government-has strongly endorsed the direction for waterfront reform proposed by the ISC and has welcomed the Opposition's stance on this matter. I quote from what that group wrote to us:
I welcome your recent offer of bipartisan support to the Government if it implements a genuine program of waterfront reform based on the Inter-State Commission's recommendations.
Like you, ASUG recognises that no one likes every element of the ISC's plan, if considered in isolation . . .
It went on:
. . . we believe any watering down on the substantive components of the package could place in jeopardy the entire program for waterfront reform.

Look at the program that was put forward by the Inter-State Commission. The key part of the program was that it would guarantee a movement to a genuinely competitive situation. There was to be an in-principle agreement between the parties which would cover all of the essential elements of the agreement. We find that the Government is committed only to those elements of the plan which involved the expenditure of taxpayers' funds and the placing of new burdens and obligations on employers. It is totally unable to produce a commitment to those parts of the plan which involved the assumption of obligations by the trade union movement and, in particular, by the Waterside Workers Federation. The Minister at the table, Senator Button, knows that it is a simple fact that if a container is loaded in a depot which is controlled by the Waterside Workers Federation, a very substantial cost premium is paid for that privilege.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with that.

—The Minister says that he agrees. I give that as an example of the sort of difficulty which the Government has not come to grips with. We find that instead of having an agreement which commits us to change in those vital areas-the provision of permanent stand-down in waterfront awards, for example-there is nothing but a promise that the matter will receive some sort of future consideration. Where we need to have changes in respect of union coverage of depots, we get nothing but a promise from the Government to give that further consideration. There is a need to arrange for the withdrawal of the Waterside Workers Federation from loading bulk ships, but there is no commitment on the part of the Government. The simple fact is that the Government has simply squibbed on all of those things which present difficulties for it with its own constituency.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not a package of reform measures. This is simply the latest saga in a series of changes on the waterfront which have always produced too little too late and which have not produced a continuing competitive environment which facilitates continuing change. This series of responses on the part of the Government is a matter of very great disappointment to the Opposition. We believe that Australia has been sold short. It represents a substantial contribution by this Government to the on-going difficulties of the Australian economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis), when announcing on 1 June the Government's micro-economic reform package on the waterfront, commented that through recent reports commissioned by the Government it was common knowledge that Australia has been poorly served by its shipping and waterfront industries. What a gross disappointment that it has taken him so long to come to this rather pedestrian conclusion. Had his Government bothered to ask Australian exporters-indeed, the community at large-it would have discovered without commissioning lengthy reports that this was much more than mere common knowledge. It is sheer lunacy that Australia's industries have tolerated such a debilitating disease which has attacked its heart for so long.

SPEECH.PARA: In several speeches in this place over the past 18 months I have identified the inefficiencies and rorts on our waterfront which cost our exporters dearly. The Hawke Labor Government now belatedly acknowledges that such gross inefficiencies have retarded our growth, reduced the living standards of ordinary Australians and seriously damaged Australia's export capabilities. These facts have not gone unnoticed by millions of Australians involved in industries which have had to stand by and watch the tactics of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia which has unscrupulously masterminded the almost complete destruction of Australia's waterfront. Its actions have sent this nation back decades. It comes as no surprise that this Labor Government belatedly feels compelled to create the impression that it is bringing the Federation into line. Both the Inter-State Commission's report, released on 6 April, and the report of the shipping reform task force, released on 20 April, were unified in their findings that the requirement for urgent reform and restructuring on the waterfront was critical if Australia was to haul itself into the twenty-first century.

The Government boasts that current micro-economic reforms follow on from its 1984 measures in response to the Crawford Committee on Revitalisation of Australian Shipping. The Government failed to mention that the maritime industries have weathered over a dozen investigations, reports, commissions, inquiries and examinations in the last 40 years. Almost as soon as one draws to an end, another is commissioned. Yet the disgraceful situation still exists, virtually intact, crawling at a snail's pace towards the year 2000.

With regard to coastal shipping, the Government has done nothing more than endorse the report of a task force dominated by Australian unions and shipowners. But that report falls far short of the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission to allow competition from foreign ships in the coastal trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you have done that?

—This statement confirms the Hawke Government's complete inability to address the essentials of micro-economic reform. The Minister asked whether we would have done that. He ought to know from reading our policy that over a period that will occur under the next coalition government.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the waterfront, the Government has completely failed to address the contentious issues of bulk handling, stand-down clauses, smaller ports and container depots. Despite its intended multi-pronged restructure of the waterfront and shipping industries, the Government's proposals fail to create competitive environments in either of these industries. Especially in the area of coastal shipping, cabotage will remain quite intact. The coalition's plan for its elimination over a five-year period is well documented. The Minister ought not have needed to interject to ask that question a few moments ago. The Government chose to reject our offer of bipartisan support on this issue.

The coalition has also indicated its intention, which was reinforced a few moments ago by the remarks of our leader, Senator Chaney, to repeal all sections of the Navigation Act which impinge on industry productivity and efficiency, only retaining those which relate to environmental and safety aspects. The Government has chosen, to its peril-and sadly, also, to the nation's peril-to neglect addressing two of the key measures recommended in the Inter-State Commission's report-the provision of stand-down clauses in waterfront union awards and the removal of Waterside Workers Federation coverage of employees in smaller ports and container depots.

Some cuts in crews and increases in efficiency have already been achieved in respect of Australian ships. However, the Government's proposal that total crew requirements for a new Australian vessel be 37 men falls far short of the efficiency of similar vessels in Europe which operate with just 22 men. The Industries Assistance Commission has already presented compelling evidence that the lack of effective foreign vessel competition in our coastal trade is crippling key Australian industries. So why does the Government have to wait for yet another three years before again considering the introduction of foreign vessel competition?

Recently I asked Senator Button what the Government intended to do about the illegal union practices in the trans-Tasman trade which have cost Australia several wheat sales to New Zealand. As far as I am aware, not only has the Minister so far failed to provide an answer to that question but also the Government has failed in this statement to initiate any action on that front of the trans-Tasman trade.

Meanwhile, on the waterfront, acknowledged as the key stumbling block to more efficient shipping, the reform process has barely started. It may be that over the last 20 years since the advent of containerisation the number of waterside workers has fallen by 75 per cent to around 5,000. Despite each worker handling over 5,000 tonnes a year, Australia's position on the international competitive ladder remains unchanged. Our ports remain among the most inefficient in the world. It is about 12 years since the last set of reforms were introduced on the waterfront and these did next to nothing to effect any efficiencies in performance.

One look at the image that the waterside workers has is sufficient to realise why inefficiency has survived for so long. Thirty-three per cent of Waterside Workers Federation members are over 55 years of age. There has been no recruitment in Sydney or Melbourne since 1975. In my own State of South Australia, Port Adelaide has not recruited since 1967 and in Hobart only 10 members have been recruited in the last 33 years.

Upon the release of the Inter-State Commission's report, both Bill Kelty and Tas Bull, the Waterside Workers Federation General Secretary, claimed that the recommendations were industrial relations nonsense. Down the track somewhat, when all Australians see that the Hawke Labor Government is unable to deliver the goods on waterfront reform, it will be judged by business, industry and the community at large to be the dismal failure that it is.

The Inter-State Commission's central recommendation, that the present industry pool system of employment be replaced by a system whereby workers are employed by individual stevedoring companies, would bring efficiencies to the system, but the waterside workers claim that this is impractical. Of course, it is not impractical. The Waterside Workers Federation is about preserving the union's role in the industry even if an enterprise-based employment system is developed. Such a situation would merely serve to hold back labour efficiencies for the stevedoring companies.

The Inter-State Commission also proposes that fluctuation in labour needs should be met by a pool of supplementary labour in major ports. But, again, the Waterside Workers Federation wants to decide who will be a member of that group. It wants to appoint retired wharfies, retired seamen and, if necessary, workers from port authorities. What good would retired wharfies be? Does the union want these retired souls to return after they have received their golden handshakes to further rort the system?

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been receiving golden handshakes all their lives.

—Indeed, as Senator Stone says, they have been receiving hand- outs and golden handshakes all their lives. If the Government does not take the initiative, as this statement shows it is not prepared to do, that situation will continue. If the Government caves in to the union's demands, all we will see is retired employees coming back into the system to further rort it.

SPEECH.PARA: Another recommendation in the report of the Inter-State Commission is that 3,000 of the present wharf work force be pensioned off over the next three years with an extremely generous redundancy scheme, and that an additional 1,000 new recruits be trained. We are not throwing these waterside workers to the wolves. As Senator Stone said, they have received golden handshakes in past periods of redundancy, and an extremely generous golden handshake is envisaged in the Inter-State Commission report. Therefore, there can be no excuse for not implementing the recommendations in the report. The Government proposes to provide up to $145m, shared with the industry on a dollar for dollar basis, to fund this early retirement redundancy offer. It has also agreed to provide up to $8m for improving training facilities, the training of new recruits, and the retraining of existing employees to facilitate job restructuring. Of course, on that dollar for dollar basis, employers will be required to match the Government's financial input.

The Government, no doubt at the behest of the Waterside Workers Federation, has failed to implement the Inter-State Commission's recommendation that there should be special stand down provisions for the waterfront and that the union should not cover certain workers, including those at smaller ports with an integrated labour force and workers handling bulk cargoes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why shouldn't they be dealt with by the Commission like every other area?

—I am about to come to the point. The reason it should not be handled in that way is that the Inter-State Commission found that employers need quick access to stand-down provisions for the effective settling of disputes to ensure that the unions comply with agreements. The Government has left this to the Industrial Relations Commission process, as the Minister has just interjected. That is an entirely unsatisfactory approach, because it reinforces the role of the industrial relations club just when it ought to be fading away. Recent earnest posturings by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) cannot but lead one to speculate that the unions have already won on this issue. It is certain that the unions will use their continuing industrial muscle to achieve further advantage, which in the past has been characterised by the introduction of restrictive work practices.

SPEECH.PARA: Back on the waterfront, where the real damage filters down to other industries, it has been obvious that overmanning, outmoded work practices, political strikes and ineffective management have cost this country some $2 billion per year. Let me remind the Senate that the work practices issue is not the only issue on the waterfront; another is political strikes. We all remember the strikes that were engendered over the issue of Fiji not all that long ago. They had nothing to do with workers' conditions and benefits. Such practices have cost Australian farmers $130m a year, or about $800 per farmer, on grain exports alone. It is about time these shoddy practices were outlawed, but the Government's mealy-mouthed approach will not do the trick. Australians have learnt to their disgust that it is they themselves who end up paying all the way along the line, from the poor competitiveness of our country's exported goods and services to decreasing productivity and reduced human endeavour.

By failing to implement the key recommendations of the Inter-State Commission report on the waterfront, the Hawke Labor Government stands condemned for allowing exorbitant waterfront costs to continue. Although the coalition believes that the Inter-State Commission's recommendations themselves fall short of some of the dramatic changes required on the waterfront, it recognises that they offer hope for a major improvement. We therefore offer the Government bipartisan support in implementing those recommendations. The Minister's statement clearly demonstrates that the Government has rejected that offer. It is largely ignoring the Inter-State Commission. All we will see is another three months of procrastinating committees and reviews, and probably very little action. The Australian people deserve better than that, and they will show this Government only too plainly that they deserve better when they throw it out and elect a coalition government at the next election-a government which will fulfil its commitment to implement the changes required on our waterfront and in coastal shipping.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating this afternoon the two ministerial statements by the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Ralph Willis, put down last Thursday in the other chamber, entitled, Reform of Shipping and the Waterfront and Implementation of `Government Business Enterprises: Reforms and Telecommunications Pricing'. I propose to speak more to the first of those statements than to the second. Having in mind the long list of would-be speakers, I intend to contain my remarks to a much shorter compass than I would normally wish on a subject of this importance.

SPEECH.PARA: These statements follow a long lead-up period and a series of promises from the Government as to a major package of micro-economic reforms. At the time the Treasurer (Mr Keating) brought down his so-called economic statement on 12 April, he and other Government spokesmen indicated that the total absence from that statement of any reference to micro-economic reform would be rectified during the month of May, when the Government would make a major statement upon that matter. We were asked to contain ourselves in patience until it did. When we received this so-called major package last week it was found to be a totally damp squid. It was, as the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) said in opening this debate, too little too late. Apropos that comment by Senator Chaney, I want to draw the attention of the Senate to some recent comments by one or two commentators who have given their views as to Australia's present economic state. The Opposition has been hammering away at this for as long as I can remember. On 1 June Mr Robert Haupt wrote in the Sydney Morning Herald about what he called the need for a sense of crisis to be generated in Australia if we are to begin to cope with the problems besetting us. He said:
But what do we find in our current economic crisis?

Certainly our sovereignty is already compromised, for we are at the point where the world is taking charge of our affairs. Our freedom . . . is already compromised. Our security depends, in the end, on maintaining our relative economic position: It-
that is, our security-
is not now compromised, but history shows that weakened nations invite domination by powerful neighbours.

All this and no sense of crisis! Why? The first part of the answer is our old friend, wishful thinking. Mr Micawber, it must be remembered, was dispatched to live in Australia. He may still be here, in some modern-day incarnation, in which case he is undoubtedly serving on the bench of the Industrial Relations Commission, a body dedicated to the idea that something is bound to turn up.
He also said:
The first treatment for a patient who will not acknowledge that he is ill is a stiff dose of the truth.

Ever since this Government came to office, particularly in its current term since the election in July 1987, it has denied the Australian people that stiff dose of the truth. That stiff dose of the truth is needed to generate the sense of national crisis which can be the only basis for actions which are commensurate with the magnitude of that crisis, as reflected in our monthly balance of payments deficits, our quarterly debt figures and the other matters we debate in this place from time to time.

For years the Opposition and private commentators have urged major measures of micro-economic reform, including, above all, reform of the labour market. Just over three years ago I and some other gentlemen formed a body, the H. R. Nicholls Society, which was solely dedicated to reform of the labour market. In the process, it was dedicated to reducing the present grossly excessive power of trade unions, including their highly privileged position which they enjoy at law. The Society was dedicated to changing the manner in which we go about setting wages and salaries and other conditions of employment in this country. Its objectives did not come from any feeling of animus towards trade unions as such. They are perfectly legitimate organisations and people are perfectly free to join them. However, they have become the greatest single threat to the continued existence of Australia.

At that time, as was no doubt predictable, the trade unions themselves reacted with fury to the fact that someone had set up a society, a debating club, devoted to attacking their excessive powers. Their chief journalistic stooge at the time was Miss Pamela Williams, who wrote for the Business Review Weekly; she is now an industrial relations correspondent for the Australian Financial Review. At that time she wrote in the Business Review Weekly a magnificent hatchet piece entitled `The Union Busters'. Her theme was taken up by the then Special Minister of State, the Hon. Mick Young, in a notorious appearance on a Channel 9 Sunday program in, I think, September 1986 when he promulgated and propounded the term `the New Right'. It was taken up also by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), another friend of the trade union bosses. In his normally urbane manner, he described us as economic troglodytes and political illiterates, or some other of the well-chosen phrases which always trip so sweetly from the Prime Minister's lips.

At that time the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union financed a vicious smear campaign against the individuals who were associated with the H. R. Nicholls Society, and against some other individuals whom they chose to lump in but who were not associated with that Society. The Australian Council of Trade Unions began planning a fighting fund, which I think was for $1 1/2m or $1 1/2m, to launch a propaganda campaign-it did not call it that; it called it a public relations campaign-to vilify what the ACTU called the New Right, and in the process to attempt to scrub up the appalling image of the trade union bosses, an image reflected in every public opinion poll ever taken in this country. The last poll I saw showed that some 83 per cent of people in this country agreed with the proposition that trade unions have too much power. I add that 55 per cent of trade union members themselves agree with that proposition.

You might say, Mr Acting Deputy President-although I know you are very tolerant about these matters-that perhaps I should begin to relate this section of my remarks to the ministerial statement before the Chair. I propose to do so, as I have quite fully had that point in mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure you are coming to it, Senator Stone.

—I am coming to it right now. I wanted to lay the ground before doing so. The relevance of it is that it is the bane of trade union power which constitutes the barrier to all progress in micro-economic reform in this country, including progress on the part of the Government, assuming that it wants to make progress in this area. I am prepared to concede that at least some Ministers in the Government want to make progress in this area, but in that process they continue to run into this insurmountable roadblock; I should say that it is insurmountable by the Labor Party. We had a classic example of that in the statement before us this afternoon, which was put down last week in the House of Representatives by the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider the waterfront. As other speakers have noted, we have had a first-class report by the Inter-State Commission on the subject of the waterfront. It has taken a very long while to arrive and has been very much strung out in the process. On its publication, the report was described by the General Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia, Mr Tas Bull, as being totally unacceptable. He was backed up by none other and no less a figure than Mr Bill Kelty, the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It is true that in the course of the past 20 years or so the Waterside Workers Federation has undergone a very steady loss of membership. Before containerisation came into this country it had something over 21,000 members; today it has a little over 5,000. That is a fact which people like Mr Tas Bull and others before him and others in other trade unions always neglect. New technology will always beat monopolies. It is beating them in the labour market. That is why a few years ago the ACTU brought an action in the High Court in order to bring the process of technological change under its control and under the control of its friends in that moribund body previously called the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission but now known as the Industrial Relations Commission. It has undergone a name change, but it is still the same moribund body.
