If we want to see the kind of destructive effect of the way we go about industrial relations and therefore the ultimate need for micro-economic reform in these matters, we might turn, for example, to page 102 of the report of the Inter-State Commission on which it reports on a coal terminal study. Because of my self-imposed time constraint, I do not have time to go through it in detail, but I will quote a few points from the report of the consultants who were engaged to undertake that study. They identified a number of arrangements which were having an adverse effect on the performance of our coal loading terminals as follows:
the level of manning at the New South Wales terminals, which is substantially greater than that at the Queensland facilities;
the level of manning at terminals owned and operated by the Maritime Services Board-
the New South Wales Maritime Services Board-

which is significantly greater than employment levels at privately owned Newcastle facilities (even though the throughput at the public facilities is less than that at the privately operated terminals);

the large number of unions representing New South Wales coal employees, which inhibits agreement between employees and management; the enforced use of gangway watchmen and hatchmen, which appears to have been maintained as a result of historical practice rather than as an operational or safety requirement of contemporary bulk shipping;
restrictive work practices (for example, minimum working hours and wage requirements at Balmain) . . .

And so on. The list is endless. That is the problem that the people of Australia are confronting when they seek to undertake micro-economic reform in this country. The problem simply has to be surmounted.

I close my remarks by referring to a paper delivered to a recent conference of the H. R. Nicholls Society held in Canberra in late February of this year. The conference was entitled `No Ticket, No Start, No More'. The paper was delivered by Mr Joe Thompson, who, in an earlier incarnation, was for many years the General Secretary of the New South Wales Branch of the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia and subsequently a Labor Party member of the Legislative Council of New South Wales. I think he has now retired from that position. I hope I do not have that fact wrong. Mr Thompson gave a paper to that conference which was remarkable, particularly coming from the quarter it came from. He began his paper by saying:
Australia is in an economic mess of great magnitude and unless firm and positive steps are taken this country has a very bleak future indeed.
Paul Keating's statement to the effect that we are fast becoming a `Banana Republic' is not only true but in many ways an understatement of the real position.

One area in drastic need of major surgery is our system of Industrial Relations. Without a doubt, we have the most self destructive system in the free world and this includes Great Britain which is now in the process of ridding itself of many of the restrictive practices, which led to the extinction of so much of that country's manufacturing industry.
I do not have time to quote Mr Thompson in full, but he went on to say:
To put it simply, the so called benefits of the Accord-
that is, the accord between this Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions-
have been little more than a mirage and have actually worsened our economy in the longer term.
With the failure of the accord imminent it must be obvious that we cannot continue to rely upon a system of industrial relations which has failed.
The time has arrived for no further reliance on a compulsory arbitration system and move to a system of direct negotiations with employers at industry or enterprise level . . .
This would enable agreements to be made between both parties, which would apply to that industry or enterprise only and flow-ons to other sections of industry should not occur.
I seek leave to incorporate Mr Thompson's paper in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The paper read as follows-
SUMMARY OF SPEECH DELIVERED TO THE H. R. NICHOLLS SOCIETY CANBERRA 24.2.89
By Joe Thompson
Mr Chairman, ladies and gentlemen. Australia is in an economic mess of great magnitude and unless firm and positive steps are taken this country has a very bleak future indeed.
Paul Keating's statement to the effect that we are fast becoming a ``Banana Republic'' is not only true but in many ways an understatement of the real position.

One area in drastic need of major surgery is our system of Industrial Relations. Without a doubt, we have the most self destructive system in the free world and this includes Great Britain which is now in the process of ridding itself of many of the restrictive practices, which led to the extinction of so much of that country's manufacturing industry.

Initially, the setting up of a legal type system, to set minimum or award rates, by a court did have a beneficial effect and overall was, at that time, in the national interest. We were spared much of the excesses of serious labour disputes, which in many countries, particularly the United States, led to bloodshed and violence to a degree never experienced in this country.

However, Australia's conciliation and arbitration systems both at State and Federal levels are now no longer working in our best interests and it can be argued that they are the cause of much of our economic problems.

We are now on the verge of a major national wage blow out, the effects of which will ultimately be felt by the whole community and cause further damage to our fragile economy. This in turn will lead to further government economic restraints with most of the hardship being placed on those in the community least able to afford it.
To put it simply, the so called benefits of the Accord have been little more than a mirage and have actually worsened our economy in the longer term.
In the short term, the major winners of the accord have not been the ordinary trade unionist but has been the employers, and in the longer term, neither employer or employee have really gained.
With the failure of the accord imminent it must be obvious that we cannot continue to rely upon a system of industrial relations which has failed.

The time has arrived for no further reliance on a compulsory arbitration system and move to a system of direct negotiations with employers at industry or enterprise level, with a single union having complete coverage and negotiating exclusively on behalf of those employed in that industry. In other words a single Industry Union.
This would enable agreements to be made between both parties, which would apply to that industry or enterprise only and flow-ons to other sections of industry should not occur.

This would mean that there would be no lowest common denominator as we have in Australia now and obviously some industries or individual enterprises, would, depending on economic or other circumstances, have varying pay rates and other conditions.

With a single union having complete coverage for an enterprise or industry, it would be in their interest to ensure that the enterprise prospered, as this would lead to stability and greater rewards in the future.

Incorporated in a legally binding contract between union and company, should be a no strike/no lockout clause and most important, an agreed method of settling disputes during the life of the contract.

This Industrial Relations System has been in operation in both the United States and Canada for many years and is now rapidly spreading to the United Kingdom. In that country the British Electoral Trades Union has been expelled from the British Trade Union Council, for entering into an agreement for one union coverage of a major section of the British Newspaper Industry.
A number of other unions however, have also signed single industry agreements, most of which include some type of no-strike clause.

The pressure to enter into single industry union agreements has now become so strong, that the T.U.C. has been obliged to now state that before a union enters into such a contract, it must advise the T.U.C.

There can be little doubt, that irrespective of the attitude of the T.U.C., it is only a matter of time before a system evolves, of which the cornerstone will be a single industry union negotiating for the whole business.
The instability and irresponsibility of much of Australia's Trade Union Movement, cannot be allowed to continue, particularly as we are now no longer insulated from the rest of the world.
A typical example of the irresponsibility of some sections of our trade unions, can clearly be seen in the recent strike at CSR in Victoria.

Four major unions and a number of smaller unions, served a wage demand upon that company and the dispute which followed led to serious national consequences on our confectionery and food processing industries.
That a company, employing less than 400 people in its sugar processing plant, would have at least seven unions, highlights the need for an industrial relations system of single industry unions.
The majority of unions in the dispute were in maintenance with no real interest in the sugar industry.
If the factory was to close permanently, they would have little difficulty as maintenance tradesmen, in gaining another position and the effect on their respective unions would be negligible.

Attempts to gain sugar supplies led to the Federal Government deciding to lift a long standing embargo on the import of sugar and this in turn, led to the Queensland Government protesting at this decision, as they felt that it could lead to problems for that states sugar industry.

The combined unions at CSR, treated the Arbitration Commission with contempt and defied their orders, particularly in relation to picketing, and it was only the threat of civil action which really led to the settlement of the dispute.

The CSR dispute is a classic example of the type of industrial anarchy which crippled so much of British industry and the reason why many British companies are demanding and getting single industry unions with a contract of employment.
Britain is now coming into line and adopting an industrial relations system, comparable to most other nations in the free world.
It is vital that we revitalise our manufacturing industry and ensure that extraction and allied industries can compete in International Markets.

Our current reliance on our rural industries to earn export income is extremely dangerous. A major national drought, which occurs with monotonous regularity in this country would be extremely serious in view of our disastrous balance of trade figures.
Put simply, we allow our present chaotic industrial relations system to continue at our peril.

Finally, union amalgamations, will they assist in bringing some stability to our industries? The answer is a very positive NO! with little doubt that they will worsen the position and lead to better and bigger industrial disputes.
The proposals are for amalgamations across the whole broad spectrum of industry, which would defeat the concept of Single Industry Unions.

Imagine what would happened with an amalgamation between the Storeman and Packers Union and the Transport Workers Union. This super union would have an interest in almost every enterprise in the nation and could bring Australia to its knees, with little more than a telephone call.

Existing amalgamations proposals have a number of similar propositions and must be viewed with grave concern. No doubt the ACTU would become stronger than ever, but there is little doubt that in our national interests, it would be disastrous.

Australia's future lies in having a responsible system of industrial relations based upon a single industry union concept and a freely negotiated Contract of Employment between the employer and the union.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HAINES
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to confine my remarks in this debate to the question of government business enterprises (GBEs) and the Government's penchant for privatisation. Events during the last five or so years have indicated quite clearly to the Australian public that there is not a great deal of difference between the policies of the Labor Government and those of the Liberal-National Opposition when it comes to a range of economic matters. These matters include deregulation of the financial sector which has taken place and has been enthusiastically supported by everybody in this place except the Democrats. There were significant benefits promised from deregulation of the financial sector. We were told that competition would be increased, the entry of foreign banks as part of this deregulatory system would mean greater competition, services would increase, consumers would have a wider range of financial institutions to service them, and costs would go down as competition not only increased the number of services available but also meant the price of those services would be reduced. Nothing of the kind has happened.

SPEECH.PARA: The only beneficiaries of a deregulated financial sector have been the banks and, in particular, their shareholders, as interest rates have risen and bank profits have reached record levels at every six-month period to the point where Australia's three banks form the second most profitable banking sector in the world. No attempt is being made by this Government to place any restrictions on them. When the Commonwealth Banks Act was before this chamber, some 18 months or so ago, and the Democrats tried to amend it so that the Commonwealth Bank of Australia would be unable to charge the same fees as private banks were charging to small account holders, that amendment was defeated by a combined vote of the Liberal-National and Labor parties who were not prepared to restrict the Commonwealth Bank in any way from its de facto privatising activities of which we have seen so much in the last five years.

The Government and the Opposition have enthusiastically embraced the concept of foreign ownership-something that is of great concern to many Australians who perceive that in both the short and long term Australians as a whole will not benefit. Earlier this year, with the support of the Liberal and National parties, the Government passed legislation which further relaxed restrictions on foreign ownership in all areas with the exception of urban real estate. Of course, the damage has already been done in that area. We are now seeing the farm being sold off in a very real sense. I was disappointed that National Party senators who had expressed concern about overseas control of our been industry were not prepared to support a Democrat amendment for a register of foreign ownership in this country to enable us to have some idea of who owned what and who sending what income back home. Had that happened, we would have been able to take action before the floodgates opened entirely. Unfortunately, that has not occurred.

In addition, we have seen corporate welfare burgeon under the current Labor Government with the support of the Opposition parties while social welfare has suffered severe cutbacks. Last year company tax was cut by 20 per cent at a time when many of the major companies in this country were paying little or no tax at all. Indeed, Alan Bond said in an interview in the Australian Financial Review late last year that while his company was paying less than one cent in the dollar this financial year, it would pay nothing in the next financial year. Despite that a majority of members of this Parliament were still prepared to further cut company tax. In depleting its Consolidated Revenue the Government has had to take other steps to keep the domestic surplus at the high level demanded of it by international financiers. The only way the Government could do that, since it was cutting tax receipts, was to cut expenditure. Progressively over the past five years cuts have been made in the health, education and social welfare areas. The low income earners in this country have been forced to bear the brunt of the Government's deregulatory policies, part of which is its enthusiastic support for privatisation, in the main areas covered by the statement of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) today relating to the airlines, Telecom Australia and Australia Post.

It is quite extraordinary that in his GBE reform statement-I question the use of the word `reform', since by and large that is supposed to mean that a benefit occurs; we need to ask to whom does the benefit occur-the Minister lists those major government business enterprises that come under his control: Qantas Airways Ltd; Australian Airlines; Australian National Line; Australian National Railways Commission; Telecom Australia; Overseas Telecommunications Commission; Aussat Pty Ltd; Australia Post; the Civil Aviation Authority; and the Federal Airports Corporation. In his statement the Minister said:

During the past six years the Government has systematically worked to put the operations of its transport and communications enterprises on a sounder financial footing and to make them more efficient, more flexible and more businesslike.

I question why he or anybody else would argue that selling off the farm automatically makes it more efficient, more flexible, more businesslike and puts it on a sounder financial footing, particularly in areas such as the airlines, Telecom and postal services in a country like Australia where cross-subsidisation is almost essential if some people are not to be dealt with very badly. The statement continued:
It is not a task that we have only recently started.
It most certainly is not. It has been going on ever since the Australian Labor Party won government. He continued:
Throughout the Government's three terms we have focused on micro-economic reform, including deregulating the financial system-
I have pointed out how badly that has dealt with the average Australian and average Australian families-
reducing levels of protection and reshaping the GBEs.
He continued:
In our third term we have given greater prominence to micro-economic reform and accelerated reform of the GBEs.

Somehow or other Mr Willis, along with his Labor Party colleagues, thinks that this has helped. To decide whether there has been any benefit we need to ask: Where is the end benefit to the user? Essentially, there is no end benefit to the user, if by using the term `the user' we are talking about the Australian public, the Australian taxpayer. The big winners in all of this have been the big corporations. As I have said before, we have seen increased bank profits and reduced services and we have seen increased costs to the public. Certainly there seems to be no restraint with regard to the pricing policies of Telecom Australia and Australia Post in recent times.

It is amazing then how far we have come from the days when Sir Robert Menzies ridiculed the idea that the Commonwealth Bank should pay tax. He thought it was a ludicrous suggestion. How much more ludicrous would he find it if he were here to see a Labor government putting forward just that sort of proposal? Now we expect our flagships, such as the Commonwealth Bank, Qantas, Australian Airlines, Telecom and Australia Post, to be tax gatherers and to be market competitors instead of market regulators-to get out there and be hatchet people instead of assisting those who are in need.

I think it is worth while looking at some comments made by a Minister in a previous Labor Government delivered quite recently to a conference in Victoria. The former Minister, Clyde Cameron, was speaking at a conference of the recently amalgamated Australian Telecom Employees Association and the Australian Telephone and Phonogram Officers Association-the telecommunications unions-in April. He said:
Only a few weeks ago, Mr Hawke made noises which suggest that he, at any rate, may still be toying with the idea of selling Australian Airlines and Qantas.
This may not be done in one fell sweep. It could be done in stages. Stage one, could be to continue the crazy practice of compelling the public to pay taxes to itself by taxing its own enterprises.

The next stage could be to deliberately starve them of capital by refusing them the rights enjoyed by Alan Bond & Co. to borrow funds for capital expansion. And the final stage could be to then pretend that the Government is left with no option but to sell.
He went on to say:

Or, it could be to short circuit all three stages in so far as Australian Airlines is concerned, by appointing a Chief Executive who will `co-operate' with its competitor instead of engaging in active competition with it. There are more ways of killing a cat than choking it with butter!

Mr Willis, in his statement, pointed out that there were some major important elements with regard to our GBEs. They account for over 9 per cent of total public sector employment; they take up more than 15 per cent of all government investment; their revenues equal 19.7 per cent of Commonwealth Government revenues; their assets are worth over $22 billion; and these are the things on which we are apparently cheerfully prepared to spend public money building up only to flog them off to the private sector. Over the last few years we have spent money in building up, with capital injections, the Government airlines-Qantas and Australian. Having spent oodles of taxpayers' dollars on getting them efficient, well-resourced and with the most up to date equipment, we are looking at selling them off to the private sector which, inevitably, will make a windfall gain in this area.

There is a lot of rhetoric and, I would have thought, a fair amount of hypocrisy in both the Government's and the Opposition's attitude to privatisation. There is certainly a lot of rhetoric. Despite the rhetoric, when push comes to shove-and there is a fair amount of pushing and shoving in all this-there is no such thing as a private company that operates only on its own resources. Private companies in Australia have their hands out to the Government-and that means the taxpayer-all the time. They are constantly in receipt of assistance from Consolidated Revenue, and that means they are in receipt of assistance from the taxpayer. The obvious one, of course, is the tax deductability of all sorts of things. We have now reached the point where we actually allow Australian companies to borrow huge amounts overseas, push up our foreign debt in doing so and then write off the interest costs against their tax liability, often reducing that to zero, and depleting Consolidated Revenue as a consequence which means that the Government must then cut its expenditure to the more needy.

As if that is not enough, we give direct subsidies to some of the biggest companies in the country whenever they bleat or threaten to close down part of their system. In the last few years we have given hundreds of millions of dollars to the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, to the oil companies and to the banks in direct subsidies when they threaten to close the steelworks, or not raise Bass Strait oil, or push up interest rates on home loans. This Parliament, by a majority vote, has allowed the Government to hand over hundreds of millions of dollars worth of taxpayers' funds under threat from those companies. It seems to me that those sorts of threats are neither more nor less acceptable than the wildcat strikes by unions that we hear people on the Opposition side of the House complain about so much.

So it seems that the Democrats are the only party in this Parliament that supports public enterprises; that sees the value of public expenditure; and that does not tailor economic policies to please international bankers and investors. We seem to be the only party here that acknowledges that people in outlying areas, on farms in isolated areas, in small towns in outback Australia, are entitled to have their telecommunications system owned by the Government-which means by them and other taxpayers-in order to maintain cross-subsidies.

Does anybody here seriously believe that, if we sell off Telecom, Australia Post or Australian Airlines, people in disadvantaged areas will continue to get those sorts of cross-subsidies? Of course not! Private sector companies are in business to make profits and to please their shareholders, which is why the banks are looking enthusiastically at even higher profits. We will see increased telephone charges to people in isolated areas; increased postal charges to people in isolated areas; decreased services to people outside the major population areas; and, most certainly, a diminution of transport services to people outside the main population areas. Sure, the east coast run will be met by both Australian Airlines and Ansett, no matter who owns what. The Melbourne-Sydney, Sydney-Brisbane and reverse flights are the big income earners. I wonder how the people in Darwin and Adelaide and in more isolated areas will feel when, instead of having a choice of airlines because one is government-owned and recognises its obligation to provide a service to outlying areas, they find that they get one service a day, if they are lucky. This is the problem with getting overly enthusiastic about government business enterprises which will end up in the hands of the private sector. If we want to maintain in a country of 17 million people equal services at similar prices to unequal groups of people we have to acknowledge that the Government has a role to play and it must continue to play that role.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we have heard a vitriolic outburst by honourable senators opposite who are totally anti-union. Admittedly, Senator Stone agreed that unionists have a right to exist as long as they do not exert too much influence and as long as the employer tells them what to do. Senator Chaney said that the Government had done too little too late. What a hypocrite!
—Order! That term is not to be used in this chamber when directed at an honourable senator. I ask you to withdraw it.

—I withdraw it. I will put it another way. In my view what Senator Chaney said was totally untrue when one considers the facts. Senator Chaney accused this Government of doing too little too late. For 23 years, to 1972, the Liberal-Country parties were in government. The Australian Labor Party was in government for three years, from 1972 to 1975. For another eight years after that the coalition formed the government of this country. It was either too incompetent or too afraid to do anything about reorganisation. Whilst I, with my trade union background and views, may not support all the Government's activities, it did float the dollar-something that the Liberal-National Party Government never would have done. It deregulated the banks and brought in competition-something that the Liberal-National Party Government wanted to do but was never game to do. Certain government business enterprises are now corporations and are able to operate freely in the commercial world, subject to State laws in terms of public accountability, through balance sheets and other means.

SPEECH.PARA: We have deregulated the wheat industry. The Chairman of the Australian Wheat Board commented the other day that he thought deregulation would open up great opportunities for the wheat industry and the Wheat Board in the future-opportunities that previously were not available. We took the embargo off sugar. People in the sugar industry are now saying that they will be able to do well. They did have a problem in the past but they recognise that now we have given them some tariff protection things will go well. Honourable senators should compare our performance with the inactivity of the Opposition, except when it bashes and fines unions, creating all sorts of friction and obstacles to change in the trade union movement, including changes in work practices.

The Opposition's attitude to the restructuring of the waterfront is `To hell with the unions. Let's crush them. Let us take some workers, some members of the trade union movement, in isolation, put them down and then deal with others as we come to them'. In my view there is no question that there is a need to reorganise and restructure the waterfront. The waterfront employees are aware of the need. Developments over the years have seen a reduction in the number of waterside workers from about 25,000 to about 6,000. Gradual changes were made to the system. We had bulk carriers for sugar, coal and iron ore. Then we had containerisation.

The waterfront employees had to live with those changes. In many cases they lost their jobs, with no compensation. It was said that what was done was in the interests of the community, to reduce prices. Statements were made that these mechanisation changes had to occur because waterside workers would not work hard enough. Such statements were stupid and foolish. Such changes were taking place worldwide. The changes were inevitable. They were sensible in terms of reducing costs. They should have been directed towards reducing prices for people in the community. As I said, significant numbers of waterside workers lost their jobs over that period.

We are now talking about reorganising and restructuring the waterfront. The trade unions and the Australian Council of Trade Unions have led the way in recent times on this question. They came up with the idea of training, retraining, career paths and the restructuring of awards. In return, they wanted increased wages for the members of those unions and workers under awards. The increase in wages was about 6 1/2 per cent. If the unions had pursued the same path they had pursued in the past, the consumer price index increase would have been about the same amount. It becomes obvious that, even though wage increases go with restructuring, the cost will be minimal, if not nil.

What will the result be? Restructuring will open the gate for all sorts of new methods of organising industry. The benefits to employers over time will be tremendous. Some employers are short-sighted. They say `We want something concrete that we can see next week'. That is their failing. It has always been their failing. Unlike the Japanese, if they make an investment they want a return on it in six or 12 months. The Japanese are much wiser in that regard. They consider that, if the return on an investment takes two or three years, as long as that investment will be ongoing and useful to them, that is what they want. Being short-sighted is ridiculous and stupid. We are talking about the restructuring that needs to take place. I have talked about some of the results of changes.

The way members of the Opposition speak, one would think that the trade unions and the workers put into place an organisational plan or pattern under which the waterside workers operated for all those years. Nothing could be further from the truth. The organisational plan or pattern was put in place by employers, by companies. In the old bull gang days during the Depression, when people-who were very hungry-turned up in large groups, the foreman stevedore would say `Okay, you with the black hat on, you with the shorts' and he would give that person a day's work. They were there because they needed the money. Their children were hungry. There was no consideration by the foreman stevedore as to whether they were good workers or how much they needed work. His consideration was how he could get the most for the least amount of money. One could not lay a criminal charge against him for that, but one could hardly call it moral.

From those beginnings the waterside workers fought and struggled to get the sorts of conditions and protection they have won over the many years since. Some could say that there have been times when they went on strike when they should not have. But that could be said about any union in this country. It could be said about any union that not everything it has done has been right. But Senator Stone has no right continually to attack the trade union movement as though all it wants to do is to destroy the community and not care about the economy or the interests of the community as a whole. Nothing could be further from the truth.

Trade unions were set up to look after the interests of people in particular enterprises and industries. Therefore, they serve that need. There are people who say that the trade unions have a responsibility to the community. I say now-I have said it many times-that they understand that but they have to weigh their responsibility to the community against their interests and the interests of their families. Would it be fair for waterside workers to give up their livelihood and go on the dole, if they were lucky, in the interests of the community? Everybody would say `That is very nice; it is great' and forget about them. The community as a whole does not particularly care about them unless the role that the waterside workers have played is brought home to them in some way. So waterside workers want some reasonable compensation for job losses, as many others have wanted in the past. For some years there has been in place a scheme whereby people who have retired from the waterfront have been given compensation by way of redundancy packages. Admittedly, in this instance, quite a large amount of money is involved; about $140m will be contributed by the Government and the waterfront employers. But that is a once-off payment. The Inter-State Commission's report talks about savings of $600m-odd a year. To me that is a pretty good bargain. This matter is being processed in a human, kindly and thoughtful way so that people get some compensation.

The waterside workers put out some material recently, which I think I have quoted before in response to being blamed for everything that is inefficient on the waterfront, they make the following point:
Other countries have invested more heavily in sophisticated machinery and computerisation . . . we often work . . . on cramped wharves with antiquated equipment.

Is that the fault of the waterside workers? Are they expected to turn up at work with a tool box that contains a forklift and a crane? I think not. It is the fault of the employers. The waterside workers have had to carry on in those circumstances and do the best they can.

Senator Chapman made the point that all the Labor Government wants to do is protect unions' rights and prevent the efficient use of labour. That statement is totally without any force in terms of material to back it up. As I have said before, the Accord provides for a stable wage situation and a centralised system; it provides for education and retraining; it provides for restructuring; and it provides for a safe and proper work environment. It is an economic document for the future; a document which has been put together by agreement between people who want to see the community prosper.

One of the things that must be in the minds of waterside workers and any other fair-minded person in the community is, when these changes take place, as they surely will, who gets the benefit? Do we want to make shipowners richer? Do we want to make the stevedoring companies richer? Do we want to make users richer? I think not. I think the benefits should go to all of those sections, in the proper amounts, but mostly to the public by way of cheaper goods. Of course the Labor Government wants to protect the rights of unions. Nowhere in democratic countries are workers not entitled to be reasonably served by organisations which look after their interest.

Trade unions, as Senator Stone said, are legitimate. Surely trade unions which actively pursue and defend the interests of their members are as legitimate as tame cat unions which do very little because they are so afraid. Senator Stone made a point about how powerful the unions are and how they have the ability to influence their members to withdraw their labour. But he should be aware that members of unions who strike suffer the loss of considerable income. No person with any brains would want to become involved unnecessarily in any dispute. In 99.9 per cent of cases, a strike is a last ditch stand to try to protect or maintain a position, or make a reasonable gain.

Anybody who believes that great power resides with the unions should talk to a non-union member who has been sacked by an unscrupulous employer. Anybody who does that will find out very quickly that in many cases the union is fairly impotent when it comes to recovering wages to which that person is entitled or getting his job back. The great power lies with the employers and their organisations. If one has to apportion blame for the threat posed to this country in recent times, it must rest with the employers' organisations, certainly not the trade unions. The attitude of the trade unions has been to share, as much as possible, the wealth created in this country amongst the most people and those who are disadvantaged.

Senator Stone talked about the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) campaign of information and education as though it were an evil plot. I know it would be difficult to inform people that the Liberal Party is a great organisation which should be supported at the next election. People are too smart and well-educated for that-they read a lot more and understand the issues. The ACTU, through its campaign, is trying to come to grips with educating those people who do not understand the way it operates. It is obviously intended to involve as many people as possible in policy-making and carrying out programs, many of which are not associated with industrial action but with developing ideas and reaching cooperation and consensus with employers. In many cases, the benefit is mutual.

Senator Stone, again in a derogatory manner, talked about the accord. As I said, the accord seeks to take this community into the future in a much better way by providing a greater capacity to create wealth, which can then be shared in all manner of ways, such as social programs, education and health, which are required by the community. A community might have a good balance of payments, a balanced budget and a good rating with Moody's. But it is very clear to me that a country is not prosperous if some of its people are in need, poorly educated and not properly looked after by way of health care. Everybody in the community must share the wealth that is created. There must be a capacity to share those services and consumer goods. That is obviously the direction in which we should go.

Senator Stone was quite injured in respect of attacks on and criticisms of the New Right. The New Right does not suggest anything new. It only wants to take us back 100 years to a time when the employer was able to dictate wages and conditions to employees who lived in fear that they would lose their jobs, be unable to feed their families and have to send their children to school barefoot and hungry. The New Right is nothing new, it just wants to go back 100 years, and it appears that Senator Stone is one of the greatest advocates of that. The mess he made of the dispute involving an iron ore company in the West was plain for all to see. His method of defence was to attack a decent, proper trade union official, Jack Marcks, who did a wonderful job, in spite of the company, of resolving that dispute. The Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis), in his statement, said:
. . . reform package is practical, and based on common sense and developed through consultation. It is not based on abstract theory or ideological dogma.

The fact is that unless we get the cooperation of the unions on the waterfront, reform will not be achieved. If reform is forced on them, the system will work very badly. People in the community will observe what happens and will be educated. No doubt, they will support the position of the waterside workers.

However, I make it clear that if the waterside workers want to sit on their hands and say, `We have had a system which has worked this way for all of these years and we are not going to change it at all', they have got a problem. My understanding, from talking to the General Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation, and looking at the material the Federation has produced, is that that is not the position. The union wants to see changes. It wants to see the community advantaged but it is not prepared to see its members crushed and disadvantaged in a totally unfair way.

The Minister talked about crews being as low as 26. This is well below the levels of earlier generations, which were probably 35 or 36. That reduction of about one-third has come about as a result of discussions between the shipowners and the unions. I was at a committee meeting where a representative of shipowners indicated that the shipowners were happy about the current industrial situation. There has been a tremendous reduction in the number of disputes because of that sort of cooperation. I have talked often with seamen and their representatives who have said to me, `Look, we have given a lot already and we are prepared to give some more, but you can't leave us without a feather to fly with. You can't leave us naked. You have got to do this in a gradual way to enable us at least to keep conditions and wages which are reasonable'. That is unlike the attitude taken by many people who would like to see them working on rust buckets with inappropriate wages and conditions. People argue that there should be competition from overseas shipping lines, that foreign ships should be given a free go. No country allows that.

The Seamen's Union of Australia and the shipowners have never said that foreign ships cannot operate on the coast. Situations have existed whereby overseas ships have, by cabotage agreement, worked on the coast. The Minister's statement suggested that this practice will be extended where local ships cannot be provided.

The Government will contribute up to $24m of the estimated $80m required for voluntary early retirement schemes. In a short number of years that will be covered and the savings will be of such a magnitude that that money will be recovered-and much more as well. Over time on the waterfront there has been an increase in the tonnage handled by individual waterside workers from 1,000 tonnes to 5,000 tonnes a year. That is pretty good. It is true that it is not as good as the figures for other countries, but I refer back to the remark I made earlier about the lack of proper equipment and proper organisation by employers. Waterside workers cannot be blamed for the situation at all. They have done their best. I am not saying that in the process every waterside worker who has put on a pair of working boots has slaved his heart out from whistle to whistle. I guess waterside workers are like everybody else. I do not see everybody here working 24 hours a day, either. Waterside workers have done a job and have increased their capacity by five times. That will go up much more with the new organisation.

One thing that concerns me about the statement-and I disagree with the Minister on this matter-relates not only to the waterfront but to industry in general and the general right of people to work. I refer to the suggestion that 3,000 existing employees take a redundancy package and 1,000 new employees no older than 30 be recruited. Are we saying that people over 30 years of age in this country should go on the dole or have no rights to employment? Are we saying: let every other employer employ them, but not the waterfront? If that is the case, why should not every other employer say, `We want no-one over 30 either.'? What a disaster. In my view, any new recruits should be selected on the basis of their ability to be trained in the industry and do a job that is reasonable and proper.

I say that to all employers. It is not uncommon now to see advertisements in the press saying, `People 40 years and over, please do not apply'. People who sell goods and services do not say to an 80-year-old customer with a walking stick, `We cannot sell you our services because you are over 40'. They do not mind 80-year-old people if they can make a profit out of them, but they want to employ all the young guys. Next they will be organising a 100-metre sprint to see who gets the job. I think that is quite wrong. I hope the Minister and the Cabinet will reconsider that position.

In terms of changes, we need to give workers the right to help make decisions on the job. That is occurring now in Mackay, where there is a joint partnership between the waterside workers and a stevedoring employer. It is working very well. We must introduce industrial democracy to give workers the right to participate in on-the-job decisions and to have an input into management decisions. Not all of the skill, ability and intelligence resides in those at management level. Many of the problems we have had in this country over many years-and still have-arise from the incompetence of middle management and the fact that managers have never been properly trained and are, in many cases, unsuitable.

The statement goes to the question of port authorities in State areas, where it suggests that there should be a more competitive environment and that improvements should be made. I think that that is an intelligent thing to do and the way to go. It also says-and this goes back to what I said a moment ago-that the proposed changes offer benefits to the customers, the industry participants and the nation. It states that, as set out in the Inter-State Commission report, such achievements rest substantially on the cooperation of the parties-and it does. In my view-and I close on this-if this reorganisation results in no benefit to the community at all, if we do not get cheaper goods or get goods more quickly and in a better fashion, it will not have been carried out in the proper sense. I know that this reorganisation will assist the community overall by way of our economic position and macro-economic changes, and that is very good, but it should mean that people in the community get their share of the benefits of these changes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the ministerial statements by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) relating to shipping and the waterfront, government business enterprises and telecommunications pricing. Senator Burns, for most of his speech, was talking about distant history-way back in the dark period compared with the 1990s, which is what we are looking at. He was talking about periods before the First World War and the period of the Great Depression in between the two world wars. But the present economy has been so mismanaged by the Hawke Labor Government that, from 30 June 1983 up to the period for which the latest figures have been published, our net external debt has increased from $23 billion-which we owed at 30 June 1983, when the Hawke Government had been in office for a few months-to $103 billion. That means money down the drain-a deficit. We are going down the drain this year at the rate of about $17 billion. That represents an increase of nearly 350 per cent during the Hawke Government's reign. What governments were doing in relation to the economy and privatisation prior to the Hawke Government coming into office is distant history. The situation in this nation has so changed under the mismanagement of the Hawke Government that we now have to look at a totally different set of circumstances. We have to take every available opportunity to change the economic climate of this nation. On the question of the foreign debt, let me refer to an article by Mr Ross Gittins in the Sydney Morning Herald today. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: So the basic cause of the build-up in foreign debt is that for years we've been importing more than we've exported, and borrowing to cover the difference.
That puts the situation very simply and clearly so that people can understand it:
. . . for years we've been importing more than we've exported, and borrowing to cover the difference.

We have now reached the stage under the Hawke Government where, frankly, the economy is like a passenger train travelling at full speed with the throttle stuck wide open on the wrong track, the crew members having gone back into the dining car where they are eating and drinking with the passengers while Mr Willis, this Minister, is playing on his fiddle. We need to explore every avenue to change the economic climate of this nation. These ministerial statements were the Government's opportunity to demonstrate that it meant to do that in these areas. It has failed. It is a case of too little too late. Mr Gittins also said:
Obviously, the way to slow the growth in our foreign debt-
one notices that he is talking only about slowing it down because we are in such a bad way that we cannot turn it around at this stage-
is to reduce the size of the current account deficits which add to it. But how? There's nothing we can do to reduce the interest we've contracted to pay on our existing debt.
And here is the significant part:
All we can do is reduce our imports and increase our exports.
I repeat that because it is so important:
All we can do is reduce our imports and increase our exports.

To do that we have to take every opportunity-as I have now said for the third time-that presents itself. That will include tax reform. Certainly we have to do something about our taxation system. It will include deregulation to get rid of the regulations which are hindering opportunities for entrepreneurs and businesses to develop. It will include some privatisation. At one stage during Question Time Senator Button accused me of thinking that privatisation was the sole answer to all of our problems. I said this morning-and I say again-that there is no simple golden key that can be put into a lock and turned to fix it. All these things have to be taken into account. Privatisation is one of the areas where they ought to be considered.

We need greater efficiency, greater productivity and, in particular, the benefits which we would gain from competition. Privatisation is all about introducing competition rather than government manipulation of monopoly markets for the benefit of government business enterprises. We need to produce more of better goods and services at cheaper prices. Australians would then buy Australian rather than imported goods. They would buy Australian goods not out of loyalty or something of that nature, but simply because our goods and services would be cheaper and better than foreign goods. That should be the aim of the Government. What we desperately need to do is produce more of better goods and services at lower prices, backed up with better services and spare parts. If we can improve our productivity and our quality at lower costs, as I say, not only will Australians buy more Australian goods but so will foreigners. In other words, we would be able to export more. We would then achieve what Mr Gittins is saying in this article: `All we can do is reduce our imports and increase our exports'.

Perhaps I may digress briefly. There are those who worry that this talk about productivity, efficiency and competition will create environmental problems. That is a debate for another day. The core problem in relation to environment around the world is related more to population and to poverty than to productivity, efficiency and competition. The world's population and poverty problems are the chief causes of the environmental problems.

Given the magnitude of Australia's foreign debt and the balance of payment problems, the strategy spelt out by the Minister for dealing with Australian ports and uncompetitive domestic shipping services is totally inadequate. As Senator Chaney said, it is too little too late. These papers fail to communicate any sense of urgency. Senator Burns was talking about the Government having to fix up the waterfront and taking, perhaps, two or three years for some agreement to be entered into. We do not have two or three years. The Minister has acknowledged that:

. . . Australia has been poorly served by its shipping and waterfront industries. The gross inefficiencies which have been allowed to develop in these industries have restricted our economic growth, reduced our living standards and impaired our capacity to develop export markets. In part, our balance of payments difficulties are directly attributable to the acute inefficiencies in these key industries in the export chain.
The Minister said that, not the coalition parties. He went on to say:
The reforms I am announcing today will dramatically transform these industries.

What nonsense that was! There have been 11 reports on the waterfront since the end of World War II, each of which has identified the rorts and the cost to the nation. The Government has now entrusted the fate of its waterfront reforms to the Waterside Workers Federation, the stevedoring companies and the Australian Council of Trade Unions-rorts and all. They will have three months to negotiate details of an industry plan and then three years to put it into place. The Minister has said, `What I have said today will reform it all'. What nonsense! When he tabled these reports, what he really said was, `Look, you've got three months to try to work out the answers to the really tough questions'. There are a lot of tough decisions that have to be made here. The Minister has not taken any of those tough decisions. He has not made any decision about anything, other than to defer it all for three months while people talk about it and then for there to be three years in which to implement it.

The key recommendations of the Inter-State Commission have been rejected. The Government has refused to grasp the nettle and accept the Inter-State Commission's recommendations as an integrated package. Instead, the Government has decided to reward efficiency by offering a carrot. It is some carrot-at the cost of the taxpayers of Australia. Stevedoring companies will be provided with $154m of taxpayers' money for redundancy payments, training, retraining, skills audits and job redesign projects, while the union gets $250,000 for union research staff to assist in the implementation of the in-principle agreement and $100,000 towards consultants for skill reviews-or, should I say, for bribery. That seems to me to be a far more appropriate description of these monetary hand-outs in this package.

Even if the scheme comes to fruition, it will not solve the problem. There is no provision to remove the waterside workers' monopoly and no provision for new companies to enter the stevedoring industry. Both are essential if genuine competition is to be generated. While some cross-training may take up to the maximum of the three years envisaged by the Inter-State Commission, much could be done now. There is no valid reason why depot arrangements should not be freed up speedily. There is no valid reason why differing State requirements should not be speedily resolved. There is no valid reason why stevedoring companies should not attack the unacceptable levels of theft and pilferage of cargo now. There is no valid reason why work force and work practice restructuring should not be introduced now. There is no valid reason why barriers to competition resulting from container depot agreements and arrangements should not be removed now. There is no valid reason why enterprise employment arrangements should not replace industry-wide employment arrangements now. There is no valid reason why the manning levels for harbour tugs should not be rationalised now. There is no valid reason why pilotage exemption requirements should not be standardised now. All these things should and could take place now. Of course, there will be the need for some restructuring and cross-training. That might take longer. Redundancy arrangements must be handled sensitively. But this package recommended by the Inter-State Commission should be implemented forthwith.

On government business enterprise reform, the Government fell in a great heap in relation to any business enterprise reform when, over the weekend, Minister Willis made it perfectly clear that the only solution for the provision of adequate capital for Australian Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd would be privatisation. But yesterday afternoon in this chamber Australian Labor Party senators repudiated the Minister and his support of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who had supported Mr Willis on this, by joining the Australian Democrats and voting against our urgency motion which called upon the Government to ensure the future of Qantas and Australian Airlines by their sale to the public, as Minister Willis had suggested. As I say, yesterday Labor senators refused to accept that resolution of the Senate and so indicated that there is nothing in what the Government is talking about in that area of privatisation and the introduction of competition. The Minister has clearly indicated in these statements that he has engaged in a cosmetic exercise in rhetoric that has little substance. The objective appears to be to attempt to bluff people into believing that the Hawke Government has significantly reformed Government business enterprises. But to the credit of the media-and it is not often that I praise the media-they have not been fooled by this rhetoric. They have probed these statements of the Minister and found them wanting.

It is about time that this Government started to do things. In 1987, Mr Hawke said that micro-economic reform-which means greater efficiency, better production and better quality-would be the keynote of the third Hawke Government. In fact, the Government has done very little indeed in relation to micro-economic reform. It has introduced a few surface changes; it has changed the nature of government business enterprises so that they appear to be companies or they are incorporated under the Companies Act instead of being statutory authorities; it has added the word `Limited' to their names; and it has given them a board of directors instead of appointed officers to manage their affairs. All of that has been rhetoric. Very little has had anything to do with the introduction of competition, efficiency and greater productivity in some genuine attempt to get this country out of the terrible mess it is in by increasing our exports and reducing our imports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Government's implementation of government business enterprise (GBE) reforms and the telecommunications pricing statement tabled in the Senate on 1 June, almost a week ago. Prior to the tabling of that statement the Australian community was certainly entitled to have high expectations because we had been fed an unremitting diet which involved constant promises of micro-economic reform, as my colleague Senator Lewis says, almost as the centrepiece of the Government's third term strategy. Yet now, especially in view of its very limited response to the problems of the waterfront, we could say that micro-economic reform is dead in the water under this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to speak specifically about the new price controls for telecommunications services. Again, I think it is regrettable that the media's approach to date has been fairly superficial. For example, the headline in the Courier-Mail was `Three-year plan to keep rises below inflation'; the Australian had a similar heading, `Telecom has prices pegged for three years'; and the headline in the Sydney Morning Herald was `Cap put on phone prices', as though this were some form of significant discipline upon Telecom Australia. In reality, it is an elaborate charade to mislead the public into believing that Telecom is about to embark on some genuine price restraint. The fact is that according to the Industries Assistance Commission, Telecom's total factor productivity over the last decade has averaged 5.4 per cent per annum. Telecom has revenue coming out its ears. It has an enormous capacity to withhold any price rises at all. As evidence of that I think one has only to look at the feverish efforts made last year to come up with some fancy creative accounting techniques in order to keep the net operating profit figure below $1.3 billion. It ultimately came in at $776.2m, but I think anyone would have to say that that was a significant understatement of the real position.

It is clear that the dramatic changes that are taking place in telecommunications technology provide ample opportunity for any carrier to pass on significant cost savings to consumers. Yet here we find the Government providing little more than a token gesture. It is not surprising, therefore, that some Telecom officials should be virtually elated about the result. Telecom's director of corporate pricing, Mr Graeme Ward, is reported as saying that he was confident the company could limit overall rises to less than 3 per cent next year. He stated:
It is not a totally unreasonable result at all.

That is a magnificent understatement because quite clearly Telecom is absolutely delighted that it has got way with such a low figure for `X'. In fact, Telecom had the temerity to argue to the Government that `X' should be set at around 3 per cent to 3 1/2 per cent. I think it was only the public pressure that has been brought to bear on the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) in recent weeks that has induced him to even get the figure up to 4 per cent. But when one has regard to the fact that British Telecom had its figure set by Oftel, Austel's equivalent regulator, at 4.5 per cent after it was discovered that 3 per cent was far too low, one can see that what we have here is a very generous figure indeed-a really cosmetic exercise with the Government's election prospects in mind which suggests that somehow telephone charges will not rise as much as the consumer price index; nor should they-not by any figure at all. I have certainly suggested that a minimum figure for `X' under the price control formula should be at least 5 per cent and I think that again is being generous to Telecom.

But where this statement really goes off the rails and verges on the dishonest is in its gross departure from the 1988 May statement on telecommunications tabled by Senator Evans. In that statement the Government made its position clear based on a report provided to it by a task force of experts which had spent some nine months considering the new pricing formula. That task force made it abundantly clear that it was necessary, almost by definition, for a price cap to apply to all monopoly services. Although I do not have it in front of me now, I can recall reading a speech by Senator Walsh last year in which he said just that. He had been to the United Kingdom and had become a convert to the virtues of privatisation. He even went so far as to say that before he went there he thought that privatisation was simply about revenue raising, but having looked at the position he realised that it was all about efficiency. He then proceeded to make some fairly generous observations about the merits of the case and even went so far as to offer the Opposition some gratuitous advice about how it could best implement its privatisation strategy.

I do not think anyone in the country now is under any illusion that Senator Walsh is an advocate of the present Government's policy in relation to government business enterprises. Senator Walsh has made his position abundantly clear-he is neither for nor against public enterprise. He prefers to judge the issues on the merits and, in many instances, he takes the view that there is no justification for maintaining such enterprises in government hands. But he did say that where there was a monopoly, a price cap was the only way in which to restrain a monopolist from imposing what would otherwise be exorbitant prices. After all, by definition, competition is designed to ensure-in fact it has the effect of ensuring-that any service provider who charges more than the market is prepared to bear and above long run average cost prices will find that a new entrant will come into the market, undercut that pricing structure and thereby attract business away from the high price alternative. That is what happens under a competitive system. Of course, it is the opposite under a monopolistic system where there is no incentive to keep prices below any form of long run average cost because, by definition, a monopolist does not have to worry about what the market will bear. Telecommunications services are virtually `price inelastic'-in other words, the consumer will pay virtually anything for the service because he has no choice, nowhere else to go. That is why it is so critically important that there is some discipline and sanction on the prices that a monopolist can charge.

The task force and the Minister's May statement made it abundantly clear that if one thing was essential in price cap formulas, it was that the price cap should apply to all monopoly services. Yet that is the very thing that does not happen under the Government's recently announced policy. That makes a farce of the whole exercise. It enables Telecom simply to judge the figures to allow for very significant reductions in subscriber trunk dialling rates which are more than justified, but also allows for offsetting increases in local call charges which may well not be justified and which deserve the thorough scrutiny of the Australian Telecommunications Authority, Austel, and certainly of the Australian community. By lumping some monopoly services but not all into the basket we will not be in a position to make the sorts of judgments that need to be made. All the monopoly services should be there but they are not. These include leased circuits, integrated services digital networks, public pay phones and first phone monopolies. This latter one because it is a protected area has very significant consequences for the costs of connections which are obviously very inflated. Public switched voice, data text, video and cellular mobile services are not included either. So what is the point of a price cap that applies only to some monopoly services. The answer is very little indeed.

The other very significant recommendation of the task force and one that was accepted by the Government was that it was necessary to ensure that the benefits of efficiency changes are equitably shared among customer groups. With that in mind, the task force made it clear that it was essential that there be two separate baskets, one for residential users and one for business users, so that there would not be a confusion and that there would indeed be transparency which would enable the consumer to see precisely what price increases operated in what areas. Again that distinction has been deliberately obliterated and ignored by the Government in the new regime. That makes it clear that it is, as I have said before, an elaborate charade to mislead the public into believing that Telecom is about to embark on some genuine price restraint. The reality is that it is business as usual for Telecom. It is certainly the end of any serious genuflection in the direction of micro-economic reform. It is clear that the Government is not interested in restraining any real price increases as far as Telecom is concerned. It is a tragedy that what held out so much promise has delivered so little. There will clearly be an enormous responsibility cast upon Austel to somehow try to get back into the game and to exercise the discipline and restraint that the Government has manifestly not been prepared to impose at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Beauty is in the eye of the beholder. So is effort, so is fairness, so is balance. The best loved solutions are simple ones. That alone does not make them right.

SPEECH.PARA: The waterfront must be made more productive. The Opposition solution is to make those employed on the waterfront work harder, to make them surrender conditions, to make them accept enterprise employment. It would strive for a single union cover, giving common entitlements across the industry. This, it argues, would strike the happy balance between the need for greater productivity and fair working conditions. This strategy, it is suggested, would solve the problems on the waterfront. It is a simple solution. It is not the right one. The issue is complex.

The waterside is crucial to our well-being. The more productive it is, the better our living standards. To attempt to do this by simply laying sanctions on the work force is futile. A strategy based on cooperation between management and workers and between users and providers of waterside services is the answer. There are examples of where this has already been achieved. Orchardists in the Shepparton district complained about the handling of fruit in the port of Melbourne. Union officials met them. They discussed the problems. Some arose from work practices. The union responded and the problems were resolved. Others arose from different causes, for example, poor documentation. The farmers accepted that. Good relations grew up between the two groups to the benefit of both.

There are sheds on the Melbourne wharves where containers holding cargo for separate receivers are broken up. This area was losing money. The union proposed an incentive scheme. It worked magnificently. The stevedores processed more cargo. The workers received more wages. Incentives are good within limits. Those limits are safety; reasonable wages; proper conditions; and civil management. Incentives which ignore them engender a harsh, even brutal, workplace.

Workers are entitled to safety. There is an example of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and Port Waratah Stevedoring Co. Pty Ltd removing the speed limit for heavy vehicles at Western Port wharf. They hoped to increase productivity. A dispute followed. It was settled in favour of the work force. Before the speed limit operated, a heavy vehicle had caused a serious accident at the wharf. In my time as a common law barrister, I noted that too many waterside workers suffered too many injuries. To ignore issues such as safety in this debate is wrong.

The conditions waterside workers now have are hard won. Prior to 1967 their employment was not secure. A day's wages depended upon their being chosen from a pool. There was limited mechanisation. Work was physical and harsh.

The Waterside Workers Federation of Australia was born in savage times. The harsh struggle between labour and capital 100 years ago set a context which soured industrial relations on the waterfront for decades. To ignore history is to court disaster. Reforms have and will come to the waterfront if done with understanding. Without that, the way is bleak. Cooperation, not coercion, should be the mechanism for change. This is the thrust of remarks by Mr Ivan Deveson, Chairman of the Shipping Reform Task Force and Australian Shipping Users Group, to the Australian Chamber of Shipping on Wednesday, 31 May 1989. Mr Deveson is also managing director of Nissan Australia. He had this to say:

I must say at the outset, that I have no doubt, the various parties in the shipping and waterfront industries are now, more than ever before, talking about the right things-our language is changing-everyday language now includes words like exports, quality, international competitiveness, rationalisation, co-operation, reliability, restructuring and training. There is an underlying dynamic quality contained in this language.

I might add that Mr Deveson's language is the language of optimism and conciliation. It is not the language of pessimism and conflict which unfortunately has been the feature of the Opposition's contribution today. It is also perhaps worth quoting another passage from Mr Deveson's speech. He said:
However, ASUG-
that is, the Australian Shipping Users Group-
also recognises that changes cannot be made overnight. It would be unfair to expect a rapid change to a new environment without preparing the way. For example, the ISC-
that is, the Inter-State Commission-
has recommended a change to enterprise-based employment-something that is very normal to all of us. But it is very new to the waterfront. As the Chamber-
that is the body that Mr Deveson was talking to-

succinctly pointed out in its second submission to the ISC `the achievement of enterprise employment may have to evolve rather than emerge in the short term'. It will be difficult for some to make a change to this new environment. They will need new skills and training to make this transition. In this, I include both management and employees.

Waterside workers will accept change. They have accommodated mechanisation. They have accepted containerisation. In 1975 they surrendered an attractive wage formula to enter the wage indexation scheme then introduced. Had they not done that they would now be earning about $90 more a week than they are. The Government's path to reform is along the road of consultation. It accepts workers, management and users of maritime services as responsible citizens. It wants a cooperative Australia.

The Opposition has proclaimed the macho path to reform. It is grand in rhetoric. Were it to act on its battle cries, turmoil would follow. Fortunately, though mighty in word, it is meek in action. Were it ever to enter government, that reality may be the best contribution it can bring to a decent humane society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eighty years ago the two richest countries in the world per capita were probably Australia and Argentina. I do not want to pursue the disastrous Argentina collapse any further except to point out that it was the inevitable consequence of industrial populism and attempted autarky-that is, to be economically self-sufficient through trade protectionism. We must fight these whenever they surface in Australia, as they do periodically. We too have suffered a decline in the last 80 years but we have handled things much more sensibly than Argentina. Of course, our average standard of living has risen a lot over the years but not as fast as that of many other countries. We have not done nearly as well as we could and should have done. Instead of being top of the first division we are now down in the ruck of the second division.

SPEECH.PARA: What has gone wrong? Eighty years ago we were rich because of agricultural and mining exports. We are still highly efficient in both of these. Per capita, we are still probably the most efficient primary producers in the world. The trouble is that while we were rich we permitted the development of protected and inefficient manufacturing and transport sectors. The attitude at the time was, `Okay, they are inefficient but we can afford them'. The political and social turmoil of trying to fix them was not thought to be worth it while we could afford them. But we cannot afford them any more. The terms of trade have changed dramatically. In the developed world people no longer think of starvation but of luxury, or at least luxury by the standards of 80 years ago. Cars, television sets, refrigerators, video recorders and so on are regarded as essentials. The result can be seen in the terms of trade. The manufacturing exporting countries are doing very well. The primary producers are doing poorly and the mineral exporters not much better, except for gold and, to some extent, oil.

In these changed circumstances, we are living far beyond our means. The world does not owe us a living. In the last six years we have borrowed $80,000m overseas to support our current standard of living. We are like a family living on higher purchase-a family living far beyond its means, as we are. Eventually, the hire purchase bills come in, and our bills are coming in now. We are now the third most indebted country in the world, having just overtaken Mexico, and we are still borrowing overseas at the rate of $17,000m a year. Since we started this debate our overseas debt has gone up by $5m.

Under this Government we have got ourselves into the most appalling economic mess. It is not only our indebtedness, of course, although the interest on that is starting to take a frightening part of our export earnings; it is more the fact that we are in such a mess after a prolonged period of good prices for our exports, which will not last. It is a matter of astonishment to the rest of the world that we are in such a mess when things should be going unusually well for us. The trouble lies essentially with the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who has a curious habit of seizing on one fashionable economic tool, half understanding it and then brandishing it as if it was the solution to all our economic problems. Mr Acting Deputy President, do you remember the J-curve? We do not hear much of that any more. Then the Treasurer got onto deregulation, which is good in itself, except he made it unworkable by failing to deregulate a key element of the economy-the labour market-which made his further efforts at deregulation ineffective and possibly worse than useless.

The Government has given up almost all of the old methods of controlling the economy, but it has not given market forces a chance to be effective. All that the Government has left is interest rates, and that is a very blunt instrument indeed. Using high interest rates to control the economy not only inflicts hardship; it discourages investment. By holding the Australian dollar artificially high, these high interest rates make our exports and import replacements uncompetitive and, therefore, discourages investment even more. As I said, the economic corner into which this mismanagement by the Treasurer has got the country is appalling. Mr Keating was runner up for the title of World's Worst Finance Minister in 1986. The winner, by the way, was the Finance Minister of Egypt. I think that in 1989 Mr Keating will undoubtedly win the title and win it so easily that they will not even bother to name a runner-up.

How do we get out of our mess? The first thing we must do is hold down our consumption until we can justify it by our production. What does this Government do? It grants us tax cuts and wage rises which will increase our consumption and imports. The argument for this ridiculous policy is that the community demands it. That is not surprising after all the Treasurer has been saying about the economy. We remember Mr Keating saying two years ago, `Our Government is winning on inflation, it's winning on interest rates, it's winning on growth, and it's winning on the most important thing of all, the current account deficit and our external debt'. That was Mr Keating two years ago. Last February, just over three months ago, he said, `We're still winning on the continuing structural change in the economy, on its growth and on its strength'. That was Mr Keating three months ago. It is no wonder people want to share in all this illusory wealth.

The community should be told the truth. We are living beyond our means. The world does not owe us a living. We must restrain consumption until we are producing more efficiently. The key to that is productivity. Yet at a time when the urgent economic need for this country is to improve its productivity, our productivity has actually been going down at a time when the productivity of our competitors has been rising.
