This is the ultimate economic crime of this Government. It has been fiddling around with temporary measures and temporising tactics and bland statements instead of tackling the real problems. The most pressing problems of our productivity are in our shipping industry and our waterfront.

The Government's action on shipping and the waterfront is typical of the way it has carried on with the rest of the economy-too little too late. We cannot afford to fiddle around until the mid-1990s to solve these problems. As an Englishman said in another context, there is not a week, not a day, not an hour to be lost. We are living recklessly beyond our means. The problem is that there is a tendency in major political parties to be afraid of the political consequences of taking the necessary decisive actions and to pretend that things will get better on their own if we leave them alone.

Living standards will not suddenly rise without any serious effort on our part. We urgently need both the Government and the Opposition to agree to tackle the really serious economic crisis that faces us, to refrain from political point scoring and to agree on urgent measures necessary now-this month, this day-to get us out of the accumulated mess of recent years. We must tackle things by, for example, cancelling the absurd tax cuts and wage rises scheduled for the coming year. We must encourage savings by introducing a consumption tax and thus hold down our international debt until we can become more productive. It will take leadership, but it must be tried in the national interest. Otherwise we will hand on a terrible legacy to the next generation.

What has happened to our coastal shipping is a classic case of the ruthless exploitation of a monopoly. This monopoly-in this case a labour monopoly-has, like all monopolies, done its best for its members at the expense of the rest of the community. The consequence has been that the only coastal cargoes now carried by sea are those for which there is no other feasible method of transport-bulk cargoes and Bass Strait and Christmas Island traffic, for instance. This is a perfect example of a natural monopoly. The costs to the Australian community are very high. We are a large country with our major centres of population and production on our coastline. For the efficient development of our manufacturing industry, economic and reliable coastal shipping is essential-and that we certainly have not got.

Examples of the effects of the high cost of coastal shipping are all too numerous. I will mention only a few of the glaring cost differentials caused by our inefficiences. By any measure, there would be undoubted savings to Australia if cabotage-that is, the reservation or our coastal trade to Australian flagships-were removed. On the basis of spot rates, the savings to Australia would be of the order of $140m a year, or about 19 per cent of our total freight bill. Many of the individual freight rate comparisons could realise savings well in excess of 20 per cent. In some trades savings could even exceed several hundred per cent, which suggests that small and irregular shippers could gain access to much cheaper shipping if cabotage were relaxed.

We are now in the ridiculous situation where it is cheaper to ship phosphate to Australia from Florida in the United States of America or from Morocco than to ship it from Christmas Island to any port in Australia. The freight rate of cement clinker from Japan to Darwin is $12 per tonne, whilst the freight rate in an Australian ship from Adelaide to Darwin is $17 per tonne. If one happens to use the River Torrens it will cost $29 per tonne. Shipping newsprint from Hobart to Japan costs $144 per tonne, but the same shipment to Perth costs $168. All this is because of the excessive high costs of Australian shipping. The cost differences in liner shipping are even more bizarre. Shipping foodstuffs and general merchandise from Melbourne to Burnie, across Bass Strait, costs 11 times more than from Melbourne to Singapore, 13 times more than to Hong Kong or 16 times more than to Italy.

The problems and the inefficiencies of our coastal shipping are closely linked with the appalling state of our waterfront. Our ports are widely and justly regarded as the most unreliable and inefficient in the developed world. Improving their performance is essential for our recovery from our present economic crisis. If one goes around Asia one finds the main news about Australia relates to our shipping and waterfront strikes. Those are the main aspects that affect those countries. If we are unreliable suppliers buyers look somewhere else and we lose contracts. The rest of the world does not owe us a living. There is absolutely no physical reason why output rates at major container terminals in Australia should not equal European rates, instead of our terminals being half as productive as those in Europe and only 40 per cent as productive as most Asian ports. What stops us is poor management, outrageous work practices and ridiculous operating times. I repeat: the world does not owe us a living.

Not only is our productivity low by international standards but it is getting worse. An Australian National Line representative told the Inter-State Commission that three years ago 168,000 containers were handled in one year in Port Botany. Today that has fallen to 115,000, the lowest volume of containers handled since Port Botany opened. Why is productivity in container handling so poor? One reason is that there is a common practice known as `job finish' whereby the employees nominate beforehand the number of containers that will be loaded or unloaded in a particular shift. Once the nominated number of containers has been processed the employees leave work, regardless of how much time is left in the shift or whether or not work remains to be done. Another reason is our appallingly poor crane performance. Work practices on the wharves are such that cranes stop operating during meal breaks. Cranes stop to change drivers. The result is that in Melbourne one crane handles 13 containers an hour; in Sydney one crane handles 14 containers an hour; in New Zealand one crane handles 21 containers and in Hamburg the figure is over 22. We are running the same equipment about half as fast as people in other countries.

The average time taken to load a grain vessel is also considerably in excess of our competitors. Take a 30,000-tonne barley shipment, for example. In the United States loading would normally be completed in three to four days. In Australia, at the rate of 3,000 tonnes per day, it takes nine days. We have to add another four days for so-called lost days. That brings the total loading time to 13 days. That is compared to three to four days in the United States. Of course, the cost is passed on to the public. The combination of all these coastal shipping and waterfront problems can be seen in the absurd situation of a container being taken by road across Australia when, in a rational transport system, it should certainly go by sea. The container does not go by sea because the consignor is looking at cost and reliability, neither of which is provided by our present maritime system.

Let us look at coastal shipping first. Although we are looking only at coastal shipping, it must be remembered that the conditions which a union monopoly manages to extract in coastal shipping flow over into international shipping, rendering it uneconomic to the extent that 96 per cent of our overseas trade is carried in foreign flag ships. The only reason as much as 4 per cent is carried on Australian flag ships is that foreign conferences welcome the presence of high cost Australian flag ships because it enables them to jack up the conference shipping rate and thus make extra profits.

What must we do to make our coastal shipping economical? We must reduce our crews to the level of countries as affluent as or more affluent than we are. We must adjust our conditions-leave, accommodation and so on-to similar levels. I am not talking about flag of convenience ships but the ships of countries richer than we are. We must introduce competition, above all, because competition is the key to efficiency. We must have company employment and multiskilling. We must have greater productivity on board ships so that ships are not unnecessarily held up in ports for routine maintenance tasks that could and should be performed at sea.

How far has the Government gone in meeting these needs? There is a program in the statement of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) for a reduction in average crew sizes from the present 29 to 21 over the next three years. It is always over time. At the end of the process these crew sizes will still be 25 per cent higher than the manning levels of similar ships crewed by, say, Germans or Norwegians. It is worth remembering that the cost of each crew place is $150,000 per year. To have a reduction in crew numbers does take some time because we have to multiskill the people concerned. That cannot be done overnight. This Government is going about this process very slowly-much too slowly in view of our economic crisis. As I said, even at the end of the process our crews will still be 25 per cent higher than those of comparable foreign ships. The Government has not even begun to tackle the high cost rorts, such as the extraordinary leave entitlements our seamen have-338 days leave for each year worked compared with 226 for a French seaman, 216 for an American, 176 for a West German and 141 for a Norwegian. If leave provisions alone for Australian seamen were brought into line with our Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) counterparts crew costs would be reduced immediately by 30 per cent.

The Government is also not doing anything about the extraordinary accommodation conditions on board ships that the monopoly unions have been able to extort. It costs $1m extra to fit a Swedish or West German ship to Australian standards-$50,000 extra per crew member. The Government also does nothing about the notorious rort over sick leave reimbursements. A seaman who has been sick for more than seven days is entitled to an extra seven days wages after he has recovered. Many unfit and useless seamen are retained because of the extraordinary provisions under the Seamen's Compensation Act. Because of the overgenerous benefits to be gained under the Seamen's Compensation Act, it is cheaper to keep a totally useless seaman in the seamen's engagement system or on board than to try to retire him.

The Government does nothing about the extraordinary travel entitlements-first class air travel for all seamen. It is worth noting that, rather than working on a voyage basis, which other countries' seamen do, our seamen work on a six-week basis. When their six weeks are up they have to be flown home-first class, of course. A replacement crew has to be flown in-first class, of course-regardless of where the ship is.
Senator Tate interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —They should complete the voyage, Minister. One could go on and on with these rorts. None of them have been dealt with by the Government. It is not entirely the union's fault, of course. It has merely used its monopoly position in an entirely predictable way. Equal blame rests with management which has given in rather than resisting, knowing that it can pass the costs on to the Australian public.

SPEECH.PARA: But most serious of all, the Government has done nothing to introduce competition or to involve the work force in the success of their enterprise. Company employment is absolutely essential for this-but the Government will not move on that. I would like to see company employment combined with some type of profit sharing so that the employees are involved in the success of their enterprise. But what about competition to eliminate the monopoly exploitation by trade unions? There are, in my opinion, only two answers to this question. The Government has made a typical timid non-answer by considering the possibility of extending the permit system-that is, single voyage permits and permits for continuous trading, which have not been issued for 20 years-which allows the occasional use of a foreign flag ship on our coast under very restricted circumstances. But this will not achieve very much. What we must do is amend the Navigation Act to allow foreign flag ships from OECD countries of a level of prosperity equal to or superior to ours-there is no suggestion that we will allow substandard flag of convenience ships to operate on our coast-to provide proper competition. We could do this if we had foreign flag ships on our coast. The consequent benefits would come to the Australian people. This has some disadvantages in that foreign ships would not benefit our balance of payments as much as Australian shipping would if it became efficient by international standards.

I would also like to see us develop a system where there is a single enterprise union in each shipping enterprise, and each enterprise would, of course, be competing with the other shipping enterprises. This would bring about a great change in our industrial system. But if we do not change the system drastically and rapidly, the only solution will be to allow foreign flag ships to compete on the Australian coast. We cannot afford to continue as we have been going.

The Government's plans for coastal shipping are timid and far too slow. It talks about things being better by the mid 1990s, but what will happen in 1991, 1992, 1993 and 1994? There is an $80m scheme for voluntary early retirement of surplus seamen from our Australian flag shipping. This is a very generous scheme, and we should be getting a great deal more for it than we are. We cannot go on as we are. We must be much more urgent in pressing towards what must be done.

I would like to turn briefly to the waterfront, which is a more serious problem than coastal shipping, because it affects not only our internal productivity, but also the competitiveness of our exports. The problems of the waterfront are deep-seated and longstanding, and much of the blame rests with the employers who have agreed to absurd exploitation by the waterfront unions, knowing that they can pass the costs on, ultimately, to the Australian public. What do we need from the waterfront? First of all we want our ports to operate with workers using equipment at least as efficiently as those in the ports of other comparable countries. We want no demarcation disputes. We want no hold-ups because of events unrelated to the waterfront, such as riots in Beijing or demonstrations in South Africa. As I said, the world does not owe us a living. If we have stoppages for those causes, we are the sufferers. It is our foot which will be shot.

To achieve these obvious requirements we must come back to the three fundamentals of efficiency: first, competition; second, a single union in each workplace; and third, the involvement of the work force in the success of their enterprise. We have none of these at the moment. In some countries it is possible for ports to compete with each other-Hamburg versus Rotterdam, for instance-but in Australia this really does not work. If we wish to have competition on our waterfront, it must be within the port itself, that is, enterprise based.

How well do the Government's conclusions meet the problem, and do they have sufficient urgency? I think the answer must be no on both counts. There are some good things in the Government's conclusions. Perhaps the most important is the shift from the deplorable system of industry-wide employment to enterprise-based employment for stevedoring labour.

I was surprised and pleased to see that the Government also adopted enterprise-based employment for the necessary casual labour requirements. But on one very important area of the work force, the Government wimped. It is very important that there should be an elimination of union control over entry into stevedoring, but the new employees recruited in the first year of the new program will be selected by the Waterside Workers Federation, as they always have been.

We have to lower the age and improve the physical fitness of the work force, and the Government has agreed to a very generous retirement scheme which can be justified only if the economic benefits are achieved. Three thousand redundant waterside workers, who have been paid very generously for many years for not doing very much, are to be paid $154m for taking early retirement. This is a very generous scheme, and I think we need more for it than we are getting.

The Government has done nothing to create a single union in each workplace. In fact, it has encouraged the continuation of the present Waterside Workers Federation Australia-wide stranglehold. It is not obvious that any of the Government's proposals will overcome the difference in efficiency between Australian and overseas terminals, which at present is at least 60 per cent, except for a timid reference in the Minister's statement to multi-skilling to reduce these demarcation disputes.

It is not only the waterfront that affects port conditions. It is also the general running of a port and its towage services. We are told that the Minister is going to examine ways-again over time-to improve competition in the towage industry. What has he been doing for the last six years while this crisis has been developing? Ports must be put on a more competitive basis now. We must also reduce the deplorable union control of the operations of our container depots. I note that the Government says in its statement that it will endeavour to reach agreement through consultations under the auspices of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. I wish it luck.

There is no time in this debate to deal with all the deficiencies of our waterfront, so I will just mention a few more of the problems. We need to lower manning rates and to eliminate featherbedding on the waterfront. What is the Government planning to do? Nothing. We need to eliminate restrictive work practices. What is the Government planning to do? Nothing. We need to increase productivity, especially crane productivity. What is the Government planning to do? Nothing. We need to eliminate the levies on shippers for long service leave, sick leave and so on. What is the Government planning to do? Nothing. I think one must say that the Minister has tried hard to get some improvement in shipping and the waterfront without offending any of the unions involved. The problem is that the difficulties, rorts, and standover tactics are so deep-seated that such a timid approach will not be successful, or at least will not be successful within the time frame we need. The Minister should remember the maxim-the boldest measures are the safest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join this discussion on the ministerial statement on the reform of shipping and the waterfront. First, I would like to refer to the progress and benefits of shipping reform. Senator Lewis, for example, referred to the history of the industry. I believe that recent history has shown quite clearly that progress has been made and that benefits have arisen from that. Unfortunately, a number of Opposition senators spoke in a very hysterical way.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to go back to the pre-Crawford fleet and remind honourable senators that the crews before 1984 numbered in the high 30s and that there was a rigid segmentation of shipboard functions. There was no pre-sea training for ratings until 1982. It was probably a condemnation of the industry that it was such a long time before that developed. Under the Crawford scheme between 1984 to 1988 crews on new ships fell to 26. Of course there were taxation incentives for shipowners which very seldom is mentioned but which was significant during that time. More recently the Maritime Industry Development Committee scheme in 1988 changed considerably the face of shipping. Crew numbers on new ships fell to 21. Multiskilled ratings became the basis of the industry and the team approach eliminated demarcation, with union amalgamations and a general cooperative movement on ships. There were revisions of catering arrangements and the broadbanding of jobs. Literally a new social environment was created on ships and there have been capital grants and tax incentives. That is very recent and a great jump ahead in shipping. We now have the task force package for 1988-89 and onwards, with the crew numbers on new ships falling to 17 or 18 and a reduction of crews on existing ships because of multiskilling. Developments in that area and the implementation of a redundancy scheme have been referred to. In addition, there is the issue that was just referred to by Senator Hamer, the increased flexibility of the permit system.

That is the short history in recent times; it is a history of progress. It means benefits that assist competition in domestic industries; it creates employment; it develops work force skills; it provides tax revenue; it improves defence security; it improves the quality and efficiency of shipping services; and it improves the balance of payments. They are just some of the benefits.

This is in the context of an industry that has, since the advent of this Government, reduced the time lost through industrial disputes. In listening to some Opposition senators one would think that there is great anarchy in the maritime industry. In 1982 the number of ship days lost as a percentage of time lost was 4.1. In the following years it has been 0.4 per cent, 0.1 per cent, 0.1 per cent, 0.2 per cent, 0.3 per cent and, in 1988, 0.2 per cent. There is no industrial disruption in the shipping industry because people in that industry realise that moves are being made to stabilise it and provide career employment.

Of course, I can go further than that. The first Maritime Industry Development Committee ship came into operation in 1988. This year, the BHP tanker, the Iron Gippsland, is trading internationally. The Australian Searoader, an Australian National Line car carrier, is trading internationally. There are three small Western Australian State ships with a crew of 11 on each and the N.W. Sanderling, a large liquefied natural gas export carrier, has engaged a crew and will soon carry the first of our gas exports to Japan, with shipping and the contract under the control of the export consortium. That means that cost insurance and freight and the benefits of these are retained in Australia rather than added to our outgoings. Six other ships are planned for introduction shortly, including coastal bulk carriers, a trans-Tasman bulk container ship and an Antarctic vessel. That is the positive side of Australian shipping.

It is against that background that Liberal and National party senators have argued to go back to the past. They are particularly concerned to introduce ships of convenience into our interstate shipping. The Seamen's Union has indicated that it regards this as the equivalent of the Kanak labour that was imported into rural Australia. In other words, the principle is one of exploiting poor people from, say, Indonesia, the Philippines or other developing countries, by bringing them, with their standards of living and employment standards, in ships of convenience onto the Australian interstate coastal shipping run and trying to undermine the conditions of Australian seamen.

Only a fortnight ago we had an example of the sort of ship and the sort of system that the Opposition must have in the back of its mind when it argues for these flags of convenience. An article in a Wollongong newspaper headed `Cargo Ship's Safety Gear Found Defective' states:
The captain of a cargo ship with useless lifeboats and fire-fighting equipment was gaoled for 12 months when he appeared in Wollongong Local Court yesterday.
`One cannot imagine a more serious death dealing situation,' magistrate John Seberry told Captain Teodoro Licas.
`It seems not one piece of emergency equipment would have been available in an emergency and it is still not unusual for ships to go down in this day and age.
`It was impossible in this situation for any crew members to use the lifeboats and they would have had to rely on the grace of God to be rescued,' Mr Seberry said.
The breaches included the failure to provide in a fit and ready condition lifeboats, inflatable life rafts, fire-fighting equipment and emergency lighting.

That is an example of the sort of ship that the Opposition attempts to foist on the Australian maritime industry. We have to remember that these are the sorts of flag of convenience ships which some people would seek to use to undermine our existing system and reduce its standards. It is a quite stupid idea that we could try to invoke what is virtually a guest working system into our shipping. Even worse, an average of one in 100 of these ships goes down as a result of skimping on basic safety systems. That is a complete example of the foolishness of the proposal that we should allow these people to be exploited in Australia. I understand that it was a recommendation of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC). I have no great confidence in the IAC. It is another typical example of the IAC making a decision that does not take into consideration all aspects of the needs of an industry when it makes a recommendation.

We have had great cooperation from the people in the industry in changing the way in which they have done things. We have a three-year program of change for shipping and the waterfront. We need an atmosphere that will allow people to change within the shipping industry. I agree that it is staid in its ways and has to have compensating change, but that change has to take place in a process of cooperation and what has been described as a negotiated consensus. I believe that is the way to do it.

I do not intend to speak at great length today about the waterfront because Senator Parer, who will also speak in this debate, and I are regular competitors in the field, but I am very pleased with developments in this area. I remember Senator Chapman getting very excited about the waterfront because the Inter-State Commission proposal on supplementary labour was not accepted. On the last occasion on which I spoke, I said that I thought that it was a foolish recommendation. I pointed out that not one of the 280 submissions that were presented to the Inter-State Commission put forward that proposal. It came out of thin air. The Government has rightly rejected it, as have the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the trades and labour councils in the various States. I am pleased that the Government has rejected it. Without going into great detail, the package that has been designed for the waterfront is to include a training program to accommodate new recruits, the support of a career structure, the provision of increased skill acquisition and job flexibility, the reclassification of jobs consistent with a career structure, the establishment of an industry training facility, and the implementation of the company based productivity incentive schemes. These are all positive things, as is the enforcement of the safety code on the waterfront.

The final report which we now have allows both phases of the maritime and waterfront industries to restructure. The compensation to be provided means that people in this industry have the opportunity for adjustment. In some cases they will be able to retire. It will enable the modernisation of the industry to go ahead in three years' time. I have every confidence in the negotiations that will take place between the unions under the auspices of the ACTU to produce another industry plan for change which will provide for the industry to be more efficient than it has been in the past. As I said at the outset, I believe that the progress that this Government has made in this area is something to be proud of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the statements by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) entitled Reform of Shipping and the Waterfront and Implementation of Government Business Enterprises: Reforms and Telecommunications Pricing. I intend to concentrate on the waterfront. Initially, I remark on the speech made by Senator Childs. He said that he would be opposed to flags of convenience being used by ships on our coastal shipping routes. Our coastal shipping industry is probably beyond repair. It is used only when there is no other option. We already have what I would call ships of convenience plying in Australia-they are called trucks. It boggles the mind that the cost of moving goods from, say, Melbourne to Brisbane by truck is substantially cheaper than by sea.

SPEECH.PARA: Our island continent, which is a major trading nation, is dependent on exports. The efficiency and productivity of our waterfront is vital for the well-being of every Australian. The Inter-State Commission (ISC), as a result of a very intensive and lengthy investigation, made specific recommendations. It is critical to note that in its conclusions, it stated:

. . . the Commission has been obliged to assess the evidence put before it by all parties and then to formulate an appropriate plan. Effective implementation of the plan and the achievement of both efficiency and equity depend on clear recognition that the plan comprises interrelated components. It is of critical importance-
and I stress these words-
for the parties to commit themselves to the total package.

A cursory reference to the Minister's response might lead one to believe that the Government supported all or most of the recommendations. A closer examination, as reflected by the vast majority of press comments, reveals that the Government fooled no-one. Many of the Inter-State Commission's recommendations requiring commitment from the unions have been watered down and are deliberately non-specific, while those requiring commitment from the employers and the Australian taxpayers are specific and costly. I do not think we should be in the position of blaming anyone for our situation. Everyone is at fault. We have to be realistic and look at the situation as it is and tackle it in the way in which the ISC has recommended.

I intend to speak in some detail on areas where the Government has failed to address the Inter-State Commission's conclusions: `It is of critical importance for the parties'-the Government, employers and unions; the parties specified in the ISC's recommendations-`to commit themselves to the total package'. There was not a priority list given by the ISC; there was a total package-take it or leave it. One area in which the Government has failed relates to the Inter-State Commission's recommendation that the Waterside Workers Federation (WWF) withdraw from coverage of off-wharf container depots. The reason for that was clearly spelt out. Where the WWF is used off-wharf, compared to where the WWF is not used, in stuffing and unstuffing containers the cost is more than double. The Minister's response to this significant recommendation for cost savings to make us more competitive is merely that the unions must agree to rationalisation of union coverage; a weak response which will achieve nothing. People such as Tas Bull know that quite well. They have been through similar situations a dozen times or more.

A key area for improvement in productivity on the waterfront is the abolition of crippling restrictive work practices and inflexibilities. The only response from the Minister to this recommendation is to refer to `improvements in work organisation'. Senators on both sides of this chamber are aware of what those restrictive work practices are. I have a litany of examples. Some were stated by Senator Stone. There is the `nick system' which everyone knows is alive and well. That occurs where two or more men are rostered to do the same job, or an invented job, and the spare wharfies nick off while they are on full pay. The employment of spare men is a common practice. In Brisbane, where I come from, two additional waterside workers are employed for each vessel. The spare men do no job and are not allowed to be employed even if a job arises during the shift.

Such practices have built up over a long time. Other similar practices include the employment of spare front-end loader drivers who are not used; and the employment of two drivers to operate a derrick crane which is designed to be operated by only one person. If fact, the crane has only one seat. Overmanning is rife. When there is a gang of 15 or more A registered waterfront workers, an amenities man must also be hired, yet he does not do any work because the cleaning up work is done by contractors. One of the most blatant examples is the employment of a first-aid man. This involves a permanent first-aid man who cannot work but who is a member of the Waterside Workers Federation. I could go on and provide other examples. Without the abolition of these archaic work practices-some of which, I would agree, had some relevance before the Second World War, before there was mechanisation-in this modern day and age and in the economic crisis in which we find ourselves, the whole package falls apart.

In the major bulk ports where there are modern installations, there is no need for WWF labour to load coal, iron ore, bauxite, grain and so on. In the majority of those ports, that labour does not exist; I agree with that. However, some superfluous employees remain in some ports, particularly in grain handling installations. The WWF has made it quite clear that it will not leave areas in which it has a foothold. I recommend that senators who have not already visited a grain loading port should do so to look at its operations. The operator sits in a cabin above the hold of the ship. He looks into and fills the ship's hold. Yet, there are ports where five, six or seven waterside workers are employed although they have nothing to do. If honourable senators look at such ports, they will see two men standing on the hold and looking into the hold; two men on the wharf; and a first-aid person who just sits on the wharf. These practices were relevant in the days when ships were loaded by men who hoisted bags of wheat over their shoulders. Today this practice is non-existent.
In regard to the practices surrounding the loading of bulk vessels, the Minister's response is as follows:
Where stevedoring employees are employed in association with the loading and unloading of bulk vessels, employment arrangements will be in accordance with efficient operational requirements.

What a wimpish response to something that is absolutely critical! The National Farmers Federation has stated quite clearly that the employment of these people who are not working represents a cost to its members of about $30m. The Inter-State Commission recommended preservation of no compulsory redundancy for existing employees but not for new recruits. There is another cop out. The Minister's statement binds employers to retain new recruits, at least until the implementation period, which is three years. In view of the sustained high interest rates-a result of the monetary policy employed by this Government-and a possible or probable recession, this is an impossible constraint on employers which does not apply in any other industry in this country that I know about.

The Inter-State Commission called for stand down provisions in awards. The Minister asked the parties to accept that this could be achieved through normal Industrial Relations Commission (IRC) proceedings. This is absolutely true. However, if the Government were genuinely seeking reform it would at least have committed itself as a party to that reform to support an application to the IRC. Yet again the Government has failed when it comes to the acid test. I remind honourable senators that this was a total package, not a priority list.

The Government, in its response, calls for the parties to negotiate a package of reform. I remind honourable senators that, at the instigation of employers, such negotiations were commenced three years ago in 1986. So far there has been no beneficial result whatsoever. Past experience would indicate that because of its entrenched attitude to hanging on to practices that were developed more than 40 or 50 years ago, the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia could not deliver on any agreement. I noted with interest the remarks by Mr Charlie Fitzgibbon, a former general secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation. I quote from his remarks. He said:

The task confronting Australia is to cure the system failures by stopping the archaic placement of labour, reducing the ratio of supervisory labour at the same time as reducing unneeded production labour.
Even the Minister, in the lead-up to his statement, agreed that this had to be done and I notice that speakers from both sides of the Senate have accepted that. Charlie Fitzgibbon continued:
It is true that continual demand for a greater slice of the cake has played its part in the Australian system.
I do not think anyone would disagree with that. He then said:
But the time has passed to think that the cake will always be there.

I think that should be sheeted home to people like Senator Burns who, because of their backgrounds, are genuine in their belief. Senator Burns made the point that the reason for the existence of the unions was to enable everyone to share in the wealth created. No-one disagrees that there should be a sharing of the wealth. But the difference between the case today and that of some 20 or 30 years ago is that we must have a bigger cake to share among a greater number of people; whereas the attitude of those outmoded thinkers seems to be that we should keep the same sized cake, or even a smaller one, and share it among a greater number of people. Mr Fitzgibbon also said:
The dedication to do one's best for a wage hardly exists any longer. We live in a different world, and industry must be tailored to that environment.
There is a sense of urgency about that which must be recognised. We cannot delay for much longer. Mr Fitzgibbon continued:
But the problems there are far from insoluble. It just takes good will.

If only we had that good will. With our continuing current account deficit-it is estimated that it will be a staggering $16 to $17 billion by the end of June-and with our net foreign debt of $103 billion we have an economic crisis on our hands which I believe is of frightening proportions. We need to become more efficient, more productive and more competitive on world markets, in exports and in import replacements. There is no question about the fact that high interest rates will eventually dampen demand for imported goods but that does not solve our inherent structural problem-our inability to compete, particularly in manufactured goods.

Notwithstanding all this, the Government shows no sense of urgency and, after intense negotiations over the past month between all parties on the waterfront, we are told that they were not negotiations at all but discussions. Three months have been set aside for negotiations to reach an agreement in principle and three years have been set aside for its implementation. If this Government's response is to be the basis for the in-principle agreement we will achieve nothing other than a payout by taxpayers of in excess of $150m for the most unproductive workers in Australia to clear out. Those words were used in an editorial in the Australian of 2 June.

Mr Willis has threatened the industry with what he calls `alternative measures' if restructuring is not agreed to within three months. With his unrealistic and quite wimpish response he, and this Government, might as well accept the inevitable and implement those measures immediately. We, in the Opposition, promised this Government bipartisan support if it grasped the nettle and moved to implement the total package of reform-but it had to be the total package. It was a sad day for Australia when the Government did not take up that offer. The Government, yet again, has failed the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Senate is debating two major statements from the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis). The first statement is entitled Reform of Shipping and the Waterfront and the second statement is entitled Implementation of Government Business Enterprises: Reforms and Telecommunications Pricing. I want to direct a few remarks to the first statement-Reform of Shipping and the Waterfront. On the first page of his statement the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The gross inefficiencies which have been allowed to develop in these industries have restricted our economic growth, reduced our living standards and impaired our capacity to develop export markets.

As the Minister has said that, I accept it, but I do not accept the rhetoric we have had in this chamber this afternoon-that all the blame for the economic mess we are in at the moment can be directed to the feet of the present Government. I do not think any person in the Australian community today would accept that that is the case. If there are inefficiencies-and I have no doubt that there are-in the waterfront and shipping industries of Australia, they have evolved over a period of years. Senator Hamer, who spoke earlier, drew an analogy between Australia and Argentina. Without debating the specific point that the honourable senator was making, perhaps I should also draw an analogy. If we are in a mess similar to that in Argentina perhaps the reason is that for the majority of the past 80 years both nations have been governed and controlled by conservative governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —What rubbish!

—We have been governed by conservative governments for the majority of that time. For 31 of the past 40 years the conservative parties-of which Senator Bishop is a member and a representative in this chamber-have been in office. That represents more than 75 per cent of that time. If there are inefficiencies in the shipping and waterfront industries honourable senators opposite also have to accept their share of the blame for that.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps the greatest blame that can be directed to people on the Opposition benches today and those who preceded them in the years we are talking about is that they did virtually nothing to bring about any reform in the industries we are speaking about. This Hawke Labor Government, which has been in office for only 6 1/2 years, already has the runs on the board. I will not detail them again because I do not believe in repetition merely for the sake of repetition. I believe that this debate is very important and I want as many honourable senators as possible not only from my side of the chamber but also from the other side of the chamber to take part in it. However, I will restrict my comments. I will not repeat the remarks of, or go through the figures cited by, Senator Childs, Senator Cooney, Senator Burns and other speakers from this side of the chamber. The figures are in the ministerial statement. I commend it to anyone in the shipping industry or involved in transport generally. The runs are on the board. They are in front of us. They have not been refuted by any speaker in this debate, so we will move on.

One of the runs that we have on the board, which is still not understood by those on the Opposition benches, is that we have been able-though it has not operated perfectly-to bring all sectors of the industry together. Page three of the statement talks about the Shipping Reform Task Force headed by an independent individual, a Mr Ivan Deveson, the Managing Director of Nissan Australia. The Task Force comprises senior representatives of shippers, ship operators, the unions and government. We have also established the Inter-State Commission, another independent statutory body. The Commission took evidence from the stevedoring industry employers, from unions, from commercial operators, from Federal and State interests, from importers and from exporters. We have the people concerned with the industry working together. As I said, things have not been perfect in every instance but at least we have been able to bring people to the bargaining table.

Judging by what previous speakers in the debate have said, one would think that blame for all the ills of the industry should be directed at the feet of the trade union movement, in particular the Waterside Workers Federation. The wharfies, as they are commonly known, have a strong union. It is a union that I admire because it has looked after its membership-as unions are established to do. People listening to the debate who were not informed of what has been happening in Australia would think that the wharfies, the Waterside Workers Federation, are an intransigent mob who would not shift or budge if a barge pole was behind them. That is not true. The Minister's statement gives clear evidence of the shifts that have taken place in the union. Senator Parer mentioned a number of individuals who are active in the union, such as Tas Bull. Tas Bull takes a strong position when fighting for his membership. I am sure that Senator Parer would accept that. Tas Bull does the best he can, just as Senator Parer in this chamber represents as best he can the interests that he is elected to represent.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is Australians.

—He is elected on the basis that he will represent a particular philosophy within the community, just as Senator Bishop is elected to represent her Party and New South Wales. Senator Parer's State is Queensland. Tas Bull and other members of the Waterside Workers Federation have given a tremendous amount of ground on their initial bargaining position when this Government was elected to office. I am sure that everybody-from all sectors of industry and in government-will accept that there has been an enormous shift.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said that I will not take an enormous amount of time on this matter, but let me make a point about efficiency. Efficiency is mentioned at the beginning of the Minister's statement. It has been mentioned ad nauseam in the debate this afternoon. There is an old adage that those who live in glass houses should not throw stones. If we, as good senators, are to talk about efficiency, let us examine how efficient we were in this place yesterday. Then we can throw stones. If we can say to ourselves that we are efficient and carry out our duties to the fullest extent, we can, in turn, cast stones at the shipping industry and the waterfront. A lot has been said about the cabotage policy. It has been with us, supported by successive governments, since the 1920s. It has been around for about 70 years, which Senator Parer would know. The Minister's statement reads:
The cabotage policy was carefully examined by the Shipping Reform Task Force. No member-
it was a multi-disciplinary task force representative of all sections of the industry-
recommended its withdrawal . . .
But there are detailed suggestions of how the permit system should be changed to increase flexibility. The ministerial statement continues:
The Task Force pointed out-
to my knowledge, this has not been mentioned in the debate so far, although I have not heard every speaker-
that almost all major maritime nations have a cabotage policy, including our leading trading partners, Japan and the United States.

Even Britain, under the great helmsperson, Margaret Thatcher, has a cabotage policy. It has just been legislated for, although the legislation has not yet been proclaimed. Even Britain has moved to protect its industry. Most nations see domestic shipping as part of domestic production and seek to protect it.

The previous speaker, Senator Parer, mentioned the conditions of seamen here and how they get to travel first class. I reckon that if it is good enough for senators and some senior staff employed by senators or by the Parliament to travel first class in Australia, it is good enough for seamen, who do vitally important work on behalf of this nation. Everybody in Australia ought to be able to travel first class.

I wish to comment on one other matter, which I did not pick up when I read the Inter-State Commission's report and previous reports on the vital issue of restructuring. Senator Burns this afternoon referred to one of the Commission's recommendations about the rejuvenation of the waterfront industry. Particular reference was made to the existing 3,000 employees leaving the industry over a three-year period and the recruitment of 1,000 new employees not older than 30. I had not thought about this matter in the terms in which Senator Burns raised it. I suspect that is the case with other senators and people in the community. I have joked with my children over the past few months that, after this year, I will be unemployable because I will reach the age where few employers are willing to take a person like me on. I will be 45; over 45 and one is not wanted. Senator Burns asked whether we were shifting the age limit for people. Are we saying that, in the future, people over 30 will not be able to handle a new career?

This matter needs to be looked at again by the Government, the Task Force, the unions and the industry. From my limited knowledge of the waterfront-and I have worked on the waterfront in the ship repair industry-there are many people in the industry who could quite conceivably carry on until they are 60 or 65 years old, such is the technology at work on the waterfront in Australia today. Certainly many people in Australia who are 35, 40, 45 or 50 could embark on a new career. One does not necessarily have to be below the age of 30 to embark on a new career or even to have some new thoughts and ideas. New ideas are not restricted to people who are younger than 30. Senator Stone, when he was long past the age of 30, changed his career. I suspect that the vast majority of honourable senators changed their careers after they passed the age of 30. Different demands are made on senators than on people who work on the waterfront. Not a great deal of physical demand is made upon us as representatives of the people. I suspect that the degree of physical demand made on people in the waterfront industry is not the same now, as we approach the 1990s and the 2000s, as it was 20, 30 or 40 years ago.

I could quite easily use up the full 15 minutes allocated to me, but this is a very important debate and I will restrict my comments to those I have already made. I will listen with interest to the remaining comments, not only from the Opposition benches, but also from Government senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —In the interests of parliamentary productivity sought by the good senator who spoke before me, we have agreed to curtail our remarks and keep them brief on this occasion. As previous speakers have said, we are discussing the two reports from the Honourable Ralph Willis, Minister for Transport and Communications, concerning the reform of shipping and the waterfront and, more particularly, the implementation of government business enterprise (GBE) reforms and telecommunications pricing. It is that part of the second report dealing with government business enterprise so-called reforms with which I would like to deal very briefly now.

SPEECH.PARA: The starting point is that the Government seems to be interested in creating a myth-a myth that it is possible to create a government corporation which, the Government says, will be able to compete on an equal footing with the private sector, be commercial in its orientation and efficient in the delivery of its services. The real effect of the corporatisation of government services, which still use government moneys, is that they are pushed off budget and are allegedly at arm's length from the government, but they are still users of public money. The money which funds those bodies comes initially via tax money, and no taxpayer has any option as to whether or not he or she pays the tax and where it is spent, whereas the capital that is provided for a company in the private sector is provided by people who, of their own choice, invest in that company and the market makes a continual judgment about that company by monitoring its share price. Thus we have this myth that there is an entity, which is still a creature of government but is somehow supposed to be imbued with all the features of the private sector. As I said, it is owned by government, the directors are appointed by government and the chief executive officers are basically appointed by government on the recommendation of the directors who, as I said, are appointed by government.

The problem is one of accountability. In this statement there is a lot of talk about efficiency, which is laudable. There is a lot of talk about competition, being more flexible and businesslike and being on a sounder financial footing, all of which are laudable aspirations. The one aspect which is not stressed is that of accountability. Under this system there is a movement by the Government to write into legislation concerning many GBEs a move away from using the Auditor-General as the auditor. Indeed, it is important to note at this point that much of the criticism that the Auditor-General has to endure is often a result of the lack of resources that he has to carry out the onerous task which he is required by the Parliament to carry out. Of course, the really inhibiting factor is that the authority which provides the Auditor-General with his resources is none other than an arm of the executive side of government, that is, the Department of Finance.

Thus, the Public Accounts Committee, when it recently brought down its report, made a recommendation that the funding of the Auditor-General should be taken away from the executive side of government and given to a committee of parliamentarians chaired by a Presiding Officer from either chamber, in order that there can be a truly independent Auditor-General. While the executive side of government is controlling the purse strings it is impossible for him to be truly independent in a meaningful way. Accordingly, as the Government has deliberately under-resourced the Auditor-General and made it impossible for him in all cases to meet the strict requirements we would require, there has been a move by the Government to enable members of the private sector to be appointed as auditors for these so-called government business enterprises. The problem with that is not that the private sector will not do a good job; of course, it will.

Again, in that Public Accounts Committee report we made the very sound suggestion that the Auditor-General should remain the auditor of the record, but that he could use private sector auditors by way of contract, so that the line of accountability comes back directly to the Parliament. I cite the example of Australian Airlines. There is absolutely no obligation upon Australian Airlines to table its annual report here in the Parliament for scrutiny, but it did. But there is no obligation for that to be done and, therefore, there is less opportunity for scrutiny.

To recap, although this paper stresses the need for more efficient, more flexible and more businesslike operations, it completely overlooks the point that the nature of a government business enterprise is fundamentally different from that of a private sector ordinary corporation. A good example of how the playing field is not level, if one likes to put it that way, relates to the corporations that are raised specifically in this report, that is, eight of the 10 GBEs which come within the portfolio of Mr Willis. It is interesting to note that there are approximately 19 of these GBEs, and they employ between them 50 per cent of the Commonwealth civilian employment in the public sector. So it is a very significant area for scrutiny.

Let us look at two of those GBEs. Let us look particularly at Telecom Australia and Australia Post. Telecom and Australia Post both enjoy monopoly positions in the market for some of their activities, and we have just had a very lengthy debate in the Parliament dealing with the telecommunications package of Bills. In two of those Bills, concerning Telecom and Australia Post, there is a provision which gives both of those bodies immunity from suit. That is, they are not liable for legal actions as an ordinary business would be. Part 4, clause 30 of the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Bill states:

An action or proceeding does not lie against Telecom or any other person in relation to any loss or damage suffered, or that may be suffered, by a person because of any act or omission (whether negligent or otherwise) by or on behalf of Telecom in relation to the supply of a reserved service.

In the previous debate we established that a reserved service is basically a monopoly service. Therefore, this clause includes things such as the first telephone or the cellular mobile. Let us look at an example: Telecom employees come along to a house and dig a trench so they can put in the first phone. In the process, somebody is injured because of negligent action with regard to the service being provided. No action will be open to the person who has been injured to take because Telecom is protected-given an immunity-from anyone suing it in these circumstances.
In the case of Australia Post a similar protection is given. The Australian Postal Corporation Bill states:

An action or proceeding does not lie against Australia Post or any other person in relation to any loss or damage suffered, or that may be suffered, by a person because of any act or omission (whether negligent or otherwise) by or on behalf of Australia Post in relation to the carriage of a letter or other article by means of the letter service.

Let us look at another example. A postman, who is riding his bicycle, bowls over a pedestrian. If this happens in the course of the carriage of the letter service, it is able to be argued that the pedestrian would not have any recourse through the law to sue for damages suffered. On the other hand, if the carrier had been a courier in the private sector, he would be liable. The point is that Telecom does not have to make any provision for damages that may lie against it. It does not have to provide the cost of insurance for damages that may lie against it and it has an advantage in terms of financing itself that the private sector simply does not enjoy.

The overwhelming principle with regard to government business enterprises is that when we talk about efficiency we must also talk about accountability. The answer to these problems, in the eyes of the Opposition and in accordance with our published policies, is privatisation. In our policy statements we have published a list of organisations which we would privatise and those that would be looked at in terms of peripheral privatisation. Very simply, the conclusion is this-and important questions of public administration are involved: while government business enterprises are able to carry on business without shareholders being able to buy and sell shares and thus make judgments about their performance and without the market being able to make judgments as to the value of those shares, the coalition would regard the Auditor-General as essential to making those enterprises accountable to the Parliament and to the people. There is a need to maintain that strict line of accountability to this Parliament so that there is a high standard of accountability in the expenditure of public moneys, in whatever guise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the ministerial statements on reform of shipping and the waterfront made by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis). I want to make two points only which arise out of those statements. I am pleased to see that Senator Tate is in the chamber because one of those points relates to his portfolio. Earlier today Senator Button chastised the Opposition by saying that it had failed to properly read the indications which were coming from writers in Australia as regards the direction that Australian society and the Australian economy were taking. In reply to his comments, I made the point that there were evident directions which this Government was failing to properly read and properly direct attention to. In the statement the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: At the heart of this strategy is a program for reduction of the size of crews on existing ships.

He goes on to give estimates of an $80m saving in crew costs by mid-1992 and at least $50m a year thereafter and reductions in crew sizes on major trading vessels from 29 at present to 21 over the next three years. He also recites the amount of money which the Government will put into a voluntary retirement scheme. He points out quite correctly that shipping is highly capital intensive and that it is, therefore, very sensitive to the fiscal regime of the Government. The Minister draws attention to the 7 per cent taxable grant which will be available until 30 June 1992 to cover the costs of necessary modifications to existing ships for operation with smaller crews.

The first point I want to establish does not seem to have been given proper weight by either the Government or the Opposition. When a regime of wages, tax deductions and prices is imposed, that in itself directs behaviour and the shape of changes into the future in such a way that the changes are mitigated. In other words, there is a move to work against the changes that have been imposed. For instance, if a government demands a high rate of tax on wages, those who are capable of demanding higher wages will attempt to do so to cover the increased costs of that taxation so that their net pay after tax will remain the same as it was before. If we place a higher tax on material consumption, the system will shift so that there will be a lesser consumption of material things.

This Government, by taking action with respect to the waterfront and in a number of other areas, is simply responding to the system as it has been and is not reading the signs of where it needs to go. By changing wages, tax and incentives in the system, one can move the system in desirable directions rather than simply responding to what is occurring and being reactive rather than pro-active. I am referring to a clear need to shift taxation away from tax on income and toward a tax on resources. What is happening to our environment makes it patently clear that it is desirable to minimise the consumption of resources. Of course, labour is a resource which is endlessly renewable as long as we look after the workers. It makes little sense increasingly to tax wages and, as a consequence, to do the sorts of things which are contained in the Minister's statements-namely, to have to reduce the size of crews because the costs of labour have become so high-and then, at the same time, provide a taxable grant to shippers to carry out modifications to ships; in other words, to subsidise the consumption of non-renewable material things while taxing wages which are endlessly renewable.

The first point I want to make is that this Government is being reactive in this document and is not reading the signs correctly as to where it needs to shift the economy. It should be looking, rather, to reducing taxes, modifying wages appropriately and, therefore, reducing the costs of labour, and putting that tax on the consumption of those things which go into the ships themselves. That would be moving us in a desirable direction-a direction in which we will inevitably have to move a few years down the track and a direction which, if taken earlier by other countries, would put us at a severe disadvantage. We should read the signs and modify our policies now.

The second point I want to make relates to a number of features which are proposed within the ministerial statements. I refer to the head of power within the Constitution under which the Government is carrying out these changes-indeed, the head of power which has allowed the Commonwealth Government to legislate in this area at all. The principal head of power under which the Commonwealth has legislated nationally in this area is section 51 (i) of the Constitution-the commerce and trade power. Note the sorts of things that the Government has succeeded in doing with that power. It has maintained a cabotage policy, which is mentioned in this statement. That policy determines which ships shall operate in what ways around the Australian coastline.

It was very interesting to hear Senator Grant Chapman talking about freeing up the operations on the Australian waterfront and saying that what one would need to do there would be to protect things like the environment. If one were to do that, one would be using section 51 (i) of the Constitution, the commerce and trade powers, to protect the environment. The report says that there will be changed conditions for the operation of foreign vessels around our coasts. This power is being exercised by the Commonwealth under this head of the Constitution for a commercial end. There is no reason whatsoever why the same power should not be exercised by the Commonwealth to look after the environment.

It is significant that, contrary to what we heard yesterday from the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), that sections 51 (i), 51 (xx) and 51 (xxix) of the Constitution were not suitable heads of power for the Federal Government to legislate under with respect to the environment, we find the very next day that the Government is further legislating and exercising its powers under one of those heads of power within the Constitution. Quite clearly, that power has not been challenged but in fact has been used quite extensively. I draw that matter to the attention of the Minister in the chamber. I hope that he will take the point that the Commonwealth does indeed have very extensive powers with respect to the environment. This is an example of the exercise of one of those powers. Those powers could be exercised and extended into environmental protection. What the Government really lacks is the will, not the constitutional power.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the key decisions of the Inter-State Commission was its recognition:

SPEECH.PARA: It is abundantly clear that the waterfront industry will not reform itself.

Yet this Government is in fact asking the industry to reform itself. That is what the Government's response to the Commission's report really says. The Australian, in its editorial of 2 June, noted the difference between the rhetoric of the Government in its response and the reality of its response. It noted that officially the Government has accepted the recommendations of the Inter-State Commission, yet by throwing every important question back to the industry for three months of negotiations, it has in effect rejected this fundamental tenet:
It is abundantly clear that the waterfront industry will not reform itself.

The editorial further points out that there is a conservative estimate that the waterfront, because of its rorting and overmanning, costs about $2 billion a year in lost national wealth. The editorial says:

Passing the buck will not produce long-lasting reform. The sweetheart deal between the maritime unions and ship owners-the former being over-paid and under-worked and the latter guaranteed virtual monopolies-has to be dismantled quickly. Anything less will fail to improve the abysmally low productivity of the waterfront.
The editorial makes a further point:

The Government is offering to pay $150m for the most unproductive worker in Australia to clear out. But why should taxpayers be ripped off again for an industry that has brought exporters to their knees and reduced our living standards?
It goes on:

There is no guarantee the few serious reforms the Government has endorsed will be enacted; we only have its blustering assurances of ``firm commitments'' and ``reform strategies''. The most sweeping of these, ensuring the right of employers to employ-a right which, incredibly, is held by the Waterside Workers Federation-is essential. And it remains to be seen whether the Government-or, more to the point, the ACTU and federation-will accept other employer rights, including control of working conditions, in a way that is taken for granted in every other industry.
The editorial concludes that the Government has failed in its reform of the waterfront. The Sydney Morning Herald of 2 June adopts a similar approach. It says:

The package announced in the Federal Parliament yesterday by the Transport Minister, Mr Willis, does not meet Mr Hawke's promise of last October that ``we are determined not to shirk the challenge'' of reforming the nation's transport infrastructure.
It concludes:
Too many important aspects of the package are still open to negotiation, more compromise and possible rejection.
It makes a particularly significant point about the Federal Government. It says:
. . . the Federal Government should not provide such a massive subsidy-
that is, the $150m-odd mentioned by the Australian-
for their retirement without winning cast-iron guarantees of significant reform. Those guarantees are not in place.
It goes on:

Mr Willis insists that this huge handout will not be paid until `there is an agreement satisfactory to the Government'. He lists 17 items for which `firm commitments' will be needed. But many of the items are still open to negotiation.

Item 12, for instance, calls for the industry parties to make a commitment `to develop and adhere to agreed disciplinary and dispute settlement procedures to improve industry reliability and efficiency'.
The Sydney Morning Herald quite rightly says:
Can an industry with such a history of self-interest-
as it has shown over recent years-
be trusted to negotiate its own genuine reform?

Can the Federal Government, in fact, be trusted to be tough with the Waterside Workers' Federation and the employers if they reach agreements that are unsatisfactory? It is, perhaps, significant that two major recommendations of the Inter-State Commission have been dropped. The WWF will not be forced to give up its coverage of smaller ports and there will be no stand-down provisions in the WWF award.
The editorial concludes:
The situation on the waterfront and coastal shipping demanded bold action. The Government, unfortunately, has responded with undue caution and timidity.

This is the essence of the Opposition's concerns about the Government's response. The Government appears to understand the problem and refuses to do anything about it. The Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) in his statement says that the industry has remained grossly inefficient. He says:
The Inter-State Commission has found the waterfront industry in urgent need of fundamental change.

So the Government has referred it to more committees. It has asked the industry to negotiate. In some instances it is going to take three years for the changes that are recommended to take place. But the Minister says that the Government accepts the fundamental thrust of the Inter-State Commission's findings. However, there is no sense of urgency and no commitment to bring them about. The Minister says:
Success will depend on allowing the competitive forces of the market place to operate more freely . . .
But we cannot see how there is any guarantee in what the Government is doing that this will in fact take place. The Minister simply says:
The Government will be pursuing change in three broad areas in line with the Commission's recommendations . . .

It is pursuing it, but it is not bringing it about. The Government says that there will be a fundamental change in employment arrangements, but these are subject to negotiation with the unions and the employers. There is no guarantee that the result of those negotiations will be satisfactory. The Minister says:
. . . port authorities, where the Government is pursuing with the States and the Northern Territory measures to improve the efficiency of port authorities and services they influence . . .

That pursuit gives no guarantee of success. There does not seem to have been any evidence of urgency so far in that pursuit. The Minister stated that the Government would be pursuing measures to create a more competitive commercial environment. What does this really mean? This is the problem we have with the whole statement. The Minister stated:
The Government has accepted the vast majority of the Commission's recommendations in these areas and will be pursuing them in consultation with relevant parties.

The Government's answer to the important question of when, how, and what guarantees of success we will have is that it does not know. The real risk we face is that the Government could go into a situation such as that of the steel plan, where it was prepared, in a major restructuring of the steel industry-which was absolutely needed, and I must say that it was partly successful-to commit very large amounts of taxpayers' money by way of subsidy; the steel industry contributed very large amounts of money by way of capital re-equipment; but the major contribution of the unions, particularly in Port Kembla, was a series of industrial disputes which limited the productivity in the area and in fact reduced productivity levels per man for several lengthy periods during this restructuring of the steel industry to far below those that existed before the huge capital re-equipment program proceeded.

So there we had a situation where the company and the taxpayer put in money and the unions put in strikes. What kinds of sanctions and what kind of protection do we have in this new scheme where the taxpayer is to put in $150m? What guarantees do we have that the unions and the employers will adopt procedures which ensure that there are no asinine disputes disrupting the industry, destroying the efficiency of Australian exporters and reducing our capacity to trade our way out of the disastrous balance of payments problems that this Government and this kind of inefficiency have largely put us into?

According to the Minister, the benefits envisaged by the Inter-State Commission are something like $620m a year in terms of cost reductions and improved reliability if the sorts of improvements that the Inter-State Commission recommended take place. But we have no guarantees that this will happen. One of the things that concern me very much indeed is the fifth commitment that the Government requires under its scheme. It states:
New employees are to be recruited directly into individual enterprises with recruitment in the first year being in accordance with existing industry procedures.
In other words, the Waterside Workers Federation says who can have a job and who cannot. It continues:
In subsequent years each enterprise should determine the recruitment procedures to be followed in consultation with relevant unions.

Either we have a situation in which employers are allowed to employ the employees they want, or we do not. The Inter-State Commission said that this change should be made, but in the ministerial statement it is stated that `the recruitment procedures to be followed are those to be determined in consultation with relevant unions'. What if the unions demand continued control over that employment? What will happen if they are able to determine who can and who cannot be offered a job on the waterfront, rather than the employer? It seems to me that we have a continuation of the sorts of problems that have generated disaster on the waterfront, and there has been no commitment-not even if the Government's requirements are met-to correct what has been a disastrous situation. The eleventh commitment states:
The parties must accept that permanent inclusion of stand-down provisions in awards is a matter to be pursued through normal Industrial Relations Commission processes.

`Pursued', says the Government. It would be much nicer if the word was `achieved'. `Pursued' is another of those wishy-washy words which give the appearance of great progress, of major change; but the Government is simply pursuing something and it does not look like catching it. There is nothing in this statement that really involves catching hold of the problem and resolving it. The Government is searching after solutions-despite this inquiry, which clearly showed what those solutions should be and how they should be achieved. We are now having these further ludicrous wishy-washy statements which, quite frankly, are a major disappointment and, as the editorials have indicated, clearly show that the Government has failed to grasp the nettle.

There is certainly nothing in this ministerial statement which does anything to end the ludicrous situation discovered by the Inter-State Commission of industrial disputes on quite impossible and disgraceful grounds. I will quote from a study made of some industrial disputes between 1 December 1988 and 1 February 1989 which the Commission pursued. It stated:

Most disputes were, if not spurious in intent, at least questionable, and they illustrate a degree of failure in dispute-settlement procedures as well as seeming indifference to the consequence of their actions on the part of labour involved . . .

The disputes studied seemed to have been initiated if and when convenient to labour. Resolution of the disputes was unhurried and, if not completed to the union's satisfaction, impossible. Grievances are considered by both the union and management to be matters that inevitably lead to disputes and work stoppages rather than as impediments to be overcome in completion of their duty to the recipient of their service. This is evidenced by the fact that information provided by the WWF to the Commission regarding these disputes barely mentions delay or diversion to any vessel but merely chronicles the justification for each dispute.

I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table from the Inter-State Commission report indicating the number of vessels delayed as a result of industrial disputation in Australian ports from 1 December 1988 to 1 February 1989.
