TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In accordance with the agreement we have, I have no more time to proceed with this matter. It is a very important issue. It is an issue on which regrettably the Government has failed to act properly. It is an issue which the Opposition is determined, when in government, to fix, and to fix properly, rather than to adopt this wishy-washy, half-baked and totally unsatisfactory response of the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The focus of economic debate in the last couple of years in Australia, and elsewhere, I think, has shifted very importantly and very significantly from what we used to call macro-economic policies to the question of micro-economic reform. I think that is a very significant and probably very timely shift in the focus of the debate, but I think that we need to exercise a little caution on this. In any event, macro-economic and micro-economic policies and reform cannot be as clearly separated as is often indicated from the debates that take place. But also it is a lack of appropriate macro-economic policy which is the root cause of our fundamental economic difficulties today. There is a complete failure by the Government to adopt and pursue those policies of an overall macro-economic nature which are essential if we are to retain and improve, as we desperately need to do, our competitiveness in an increasingly competitive world.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had these problems with macro-economic policy. We have seen a complete failure by the Government to undertake the necessary fiscal policy stance. This is needed if we are to restrain government expenditures and, therefore, tax levels. There must be scope to get more incentive and reward back into the Australian economy so that people will have a go at the things that are necessary in business activity if we want this country to grow. As a result we have, of course, seen a totally inappropriate over-reliance on monetary policy. That has cost us very dear indeed, as any home owner or home buyer in Australia can tell us today and as any businessman who has to borrow at 20 per cent plus can tell us today. All of us who suffer from rising inflation in a world where inflation in many countries is not rising could tell the Government that.

We have a balance of payments problem and deficit which is absolutely horrendous. It has led to Australia as a nation having a debt to the rest of the world of almost $130 billion. This is coupled with the situation where we still, of course, have a level of taxation and Government expenditure unsurpassed in our preceding history. We have also seen the abandonment of wages policy to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). The Government has become a total puppet of the ACTU in this area, as indeed it has in most other areas of economic policy formation as well. We have also seen a disregard by the Government of appropriate exchange rate policies, which has led to violent gyrations in the exchange rate. This has caused enormous uncertainty and lack of confidence and difficulty in doing business by the private sector.

It is macro-economic policy which ultimately determines the outlook for the Australian economy. Unless our macro policies are correct, then no amount of treatment of other policies will lead us to greater productivity and efficiency, which determine our competitiveness, our living standards and our relative place in the world. However, assuming that our macro-economic policies are basically correct, then micro policies become of critical importance. The statements of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) which provided the vehicle for today's debate deal with the Government's response to two important reports on the shipping and waterfront industries. The shipping and waterfront industries are of critical importance to the Australian economy and particularly to our external situation. It is through the ports of Australia that most of our imports and, more particularly, our exports flow. The balance of payments is the Achilles heel of the Australian economy.

The President of the Victorian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Michael Poynter, recently described our ports as the lungs of the Australian economy. That is a very apt description. There are many forms of micro-economic issues. We are dealing with just a couple of them today in the sense of the content of the Minister's statements that are the subject of this debate. There are many. There is the whole question of transport, coastal shipping and the waterfront that we are dealing with. There is also the whole question of aviation policy and the policy we have towards the airlines. We had a debate on that yesterday. We had the absolutely extraordinary situation of Government senators in this place voting against a motion which was supportive of the statements of the Government's own responsible Minister for Transport and Communications, who was supported by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as well, in terms of the need to ensure the continuing viability of Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines by privatising them.

We have the whole question of industry restructuring and the plans the Government has set in place for industry. They are plans which have been very highly regulatory. They have had a very mixed response. In many instances in my view they have done more to harm industry than to help it, particularly by virtue of the whole web of additional regulations that have been imposed on a wide range of industries. We have seen the spectacle of an increasingly entrenched inflexibility in the labour market sponsored by the decisions of this Government in the establishment of its Industrial Relations Commission and other labour market policies which, again, have been quite contrary to the types of change needed if we are to become a more flexible, freed up and competitive economy.

We have seen the Government's total inability to tackle one of the major potential areas of economic reform in this country, namely, the privatisation, the sale to the public, of government business enterprises where government has no place at all in being in business. It is the job of the private sector to do most of the things that the government business enterprises undertake. This includes airlines in particular. The Government has shown its total inability to deal with any of the privatisation issues. This is essentially because the traditional and inherent view of the Australian Labor Party has been towards public ownership. That was instanced as recently as in the last 12 months in the Hobart national conference of the Labor Party where it greatly entrenched again the whole concept of public ownership.

If one looks at the areas of micro-economic policies and reforms that are open to any country, one realises that the tragedy is that this Government has blocked off many of the potential avenues for improvement that we have. It is all the more of concern therefore that the Government's response to the problems facing both the shipping and waterfront industries is so lacking in urgency, in understanding and in depth. All the Government has done in relation to these industries and the reports that it has received on them is to have fiddled at the edges. The reason why the Government has fiddled at the edges and has shown an absolute lack of understanding of the critical importance and the urgency of the problems involved is that it is totally beholden to the unions concerned and to the vested interests concerned. That particularly relates to the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia. There were Ministers in the Government-I know that Senator Button and Mr Kerin were two-who argued strongly for much greater action, activity and change before the Government put its final recommendations to bed in these two areas.

Senator Button was concerned about the coastal shipping measures. Mr Kerin was as well. But he was also concerned about the waterfront. The result was that those two Ministers were rolled. What the Government came up with in response to the reports it had before it was a wimpish, lackadaisical response which shows that the Government is absolutely out of touch with the real issues facing the Australian economy and the desperate task we face over the years ahead to keep ourselves afloat as an economy in a world which is rapidly leaving us behind in efficiency, productivity, competitiveness and living standards.

The inefficiencies in the coastal shipping industry have been estimated by the Industries Assistance Commission to have cost the Australian economy up to $460m a year. It has been estimated by the Economic Planning Advisory Council that industry reform on the waterfront could save up to $850m a year. For example, it is cheaper to ship newsprint from the west coast of Canada to Sydney than it is to ship it from Hobart to Sydney. It costs $82 per tonne to ship milk powder from Tasmania to Melbourne, whilst shipping it from Tasmania to Taiwan costs $72 per tonne. The Government has ignored totally the enormous problems of the industries.

I will conclude my remarks in this debate by referring to an important subject in relation to the waterfront industries-and I will come back to it on another appropriate occasion-and that is the role of the Waterside Workers Federation in the packing of containers. Restrictions on the packing of containers have existed since 1967. At that time, when containerisation was introduced into Australia, containers with goods for more than one exporter-that is called a less than a container load-had to be placed at approved container depots manned by Waterside Workers Federation members; otherwise union members on the docks refused to handle them. The cost of packing a container at such depots runs to more than $600 per container compared with $400 for a container packed in a non-approved depot. When I say `non-approved' or `approved' I refer to depots that are approved by the Waterside Workers Federation, regardless of whether union labour from other unions is available at other depots. In other words, the Waterside Workers Federation has had a stranglehold on the packing of containers where more than one exporter is involved in the contents of the container.

The freight forwarders have been able to get around the problem. The only way they have been able to do so has been by using false documentation. They have deliberately falsified their documentation in order to get their exports out. The fact that there has to be dishonest documenting of freight forwarding is a matter of the gravest concern. The issue is about to go before the courts. A big battle is to be waged on it. The Minister for Transport and Communications, in his response on 1 June, has made reference to the existence of the problem but he has done nothing, as is the case with most of the other recommendations in the report. He has done nothing to show resolve in the tackling of the problem. It is just one example of the enormous difficulties that we face. It is a classic example of the Government's total inability and lack of resolve to tackle the waterfront, shipping and other industries which desperately require reform. As a result, we as a nation are suffering drastically. That is why the economy is going down the drain at a great rate of knots and that is why the life span of the Government is very limited.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) delivered two ministerial statements in the House of Representatives-the first on the waterfront and the second on government owned enterprises. The statements can be characterised by four words: too little too late. The disastrous $103 billion foreign debt figure announced last week is an indication of just how the Government not only has lost control of the economy but also has few ideas about how to regain the initiative and actually cool down our burgeoning debt.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to concentrate my remarks on government-owned enterprises and draw attention to the fact that last week in this place Senator Alston asked a question of Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, regarding a contract which has been let by Telecom Australia to build a corporate office complex in the central business district of Melbourne. Senator Chaney followed up Senator Alston's question by asking whether the Government was informed of Telecom's decision to build a major complex in Exhibition Street at a cost in excess of $300m. At the time the Minister seemed not to appreciate the problems with decisions of this nature which inflate an already oversupplied commercial property market glut and which, because of the huge amount of money involved, will have a specific effect on heating up the economy.

It is all very well for the Government to say that government business enterprises should operate at arm's length and be administered both efficiently and on commercial principles. However, it is ridiculous for a government-owned enterprise the board of management of which is appointed by a Minister, which operates under an Act of this Parliament and which provides an annual report to this Parliament, to undertake actions which are in direct conflict with government policy. The reality of the matter is that a government instrumentality has made a decision to undertake a $300m building development and the Minister says, `We have no say in that decision because we want it to act according to commercial principles'. In all circumstances, government economic policy should override any arm's length philosophy when the national economy is as sick as Australia's has become. It is important that these sorts of enterprises operate within the general philosophy pertaining at a point of time.

The Government's attitude in this area begs the question: what exactly are its priorities? Why does the Government continue to preside over an economic situation where ordinary Australian families trying to buy or build a home and struggling with ever-increasing interest rates are being squeezed because of decisions such as Telecom's? The Government's lame answer to this is to say, `Our hands are tied'. What an abrogation of responsibility. Ordinary home purchasers are being squeezed and are being asked to pay the price of restraint through high interest rates while at the same time government instrumentalities are allowed to build their large Taj Mahals, pushing upwards the already burgeoning and overheated economy. Therefore, I ask: Does the Government really believe that it should have no say in decisions made by Telecom, Australia Post, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission and others? If so, why did the Prices Surveillance Authority-a government agency-undertake an inquiry into foreshadowed postal charge increases by Australia Post? What double standards!

I now come back to my earlier point about the Minister's statements. The failure of the Government to involve itself in the Melbourne development by Telecom is yet another example of a government which has abrogated control over the economy. When all the technical niceties are stripped away, Telecom Australia and other government business enterprises operating with public money are accountable to the Australian taxpayer and his parliamentary representatives in this building.

I turn briefly to another point. In my view, it is vital that either the Commonwealth Auditor-General should maintain a direct audit role over all government owned enterprises or, if an enterprise engages a private sector auditor, the Auditor-General must still have a final overview of that enterprise's accounts. It may be necessary for the Auditor-General to audit the auditor. In many cases, the use of the Commonwealth Auditor-General has become the only link this Parliament has with particular government enterprises. If this link is severed, what role do we as parliamentarians have? Senator Walsh has said that the control is through the bottom line. I say that that is not good enough. It is absolutely fundamental, both to the doctrine of parliamentary accountability and to the oversight of public spending that the Auditor-General maintains an integral role in the scrutiny of revenue expenditure by each government enterprise. I was very disappointed with the two ministerial statements made last Thursday, but most particularly with the statement on government business enterprises. It is no good tinkering at the edges with issues such as the waterfront and government business enterprises. The actions of a responsible government should be a wholesale overhaul of government involvement in both areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating two ministerial statements that were made in the other place last week. One relates essentially to coastal shipping and the other relates to the waterfront. I join a long list of disappointed and disillusioned senators who thought that at this time, if at no other time, this Government would grasp the nettle and dedicate itself to proper and conscientious reform of the shipping industry and the waterfront. Tragically, its response to these two major problems is epitomised in the way that we have seen the Government respond to many other problems in recent times. It would seem that this Government is paralysed. If it is not paralysed, it is certainly straitjacketed. It is obvious for all to see in the naked light of reality that this Government is absolutely controlled by the left wing.
—Ha, ha!

—Senator McKiernan chuckles knowingly on the other side of the chamber, being one of those-as is the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU)-who pull the levers while our Treasurer, Mr Keating, really just has to bow and scrape and deliver what he is allowed to. We hear this Government so often saying to us that it has a relationship with the Australian Council of Trade Unions which allows it to enter into agreements and arrangements in a way that the coalition could not. These are the grotty and grubby sorts of deals that this Government is proud of doing with the ACTU; they are certainly not deals we wish to do when in government. We expect the Government to at least be an equal partner in this relationship, not a wimpish junior partner that gets its marching orders from Kelty, Crean, and the minions that run the ACTU.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems that we now have an economy which is drifting perilously close to stormy waters. By any measure, it is bound to cast itself on the rocks of destruction. There is no informed observer or political commentator who would not suggest that our economy is in serious peril. What is Mr Keating doing? He is hanging on to one lever only-that of interest rates. Why is he doing that? Because that is the only lever he is allowed to hang onto. He is not allowed to involve himself in privatisation, relieving the taxpayers of tens of millions of dollars just to allow these government corporations to have some capital base, some capital equipment and some capacity to function in a reasonable way. What has the Government done to reduce demand through cutting its own budget or more particularly, if it had the skill and capability, targeting more effectively the dollars that it dishes out? Where is the Government in relation to deregulation of the labour market and any of these micro-economic reforms which are fundamental to turn our balance of payments around and fundamental to our economy heading in the right direction? We see this Government straitjacketed and incapable of taking even the most modest steps.

With some trepidation Senator Button steps out and cautiously suggests that there might be some merit in selling off Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines. One slap from the Left and he scurries back into his little hole. One has only to look at the uranium debate that is going on in this country. There is $70 billion worth of identified resources in the Kakadu region, yet this Government is not even prepared to look at the matter. It finds itself straitjacketed by the rigidity of its ideological pursuits. When it comes to reforms of the waterfront and coastal shipping, is the Government going to be any more brave, courageous, committed or able to undertake the fundamental reforms that are necessary? Of course it will not. At the end of the day it opts out of all the important and hard decisions in terms of the labor force, restructuring of awards, cabotage on the coast and shipping transport between New Zealand and Australia. The Government will not touch any of these areas because it has done a deal with the ACTU, as usual. It is like doing a deal with the devil, or perhaps like doing a deal with a tiger. The result is that one just gets eaten last.

When we look at this report-time will not allow me to pursue it at great length tonight, but I promise there will be another occasion-we find that in terms of job recruitment, job restructuring, work practices, a supplementary work force, enterprise employment and all the fundamental areas that are intrinsic to any basic changes, absolutely nothing is happening. What has been done in relation to trans-Tasman shipping? Nothing. As we all know, at present it is possible for international shippers to ply between Australia and New Zealand. There is nothing to stop them except the thugs-not the tugs-they run into at each end. They will simply say, `We are not going to load you or unload you'. A ship could find itself arriving in a port of Australia with a New Zealand cargo not being able to discharge its cargo because the trade union movement will not allow it to do so.

One has only to look at some of the fundamental areas that have been detected by the Inter-State Commission on the waterfront. It talks about ineffective management; poor work force training and career arrangements; introspective industrial attitudes; poor response to user needs; poor information flows to users in between links in the transport chain; lack of supply and demand balance, often reflected in congestion and queues or in under-utilisation of expensive facilities; diffusions of government responsibilities; abuse of monopoly power, reflected particularly in port authority pricing and investment policies; and a tendency for matters to improve considerably while they are under investigation-I think it is the sixteenth investigation-only to lapse once the pressure is removed.

One has only to look at the costing, manning and pricing of the ports of Australia. Wyndham, in my own State, is a classic example. In the cute little port of Wyndham members of the work force work for an average of 7.4 hours a week. For their trouble they take home $433.96. That is $62 an hour. Into the bargain, if a ship happens to arrive when all these waterside workers are preoccupied with their second full-time jobs elsewhere, there is a strike on and the ship stays tied up to the side, not being loaded or unloaded until such time as the waterside workers are able to discharge their responsibilities elsewhere. One has only to look at the various restrictive work practices where we see a whole range of problems that confront the industry. Labour ordering arrangements, for example, also impose significant costs. Waterside labour in most Australian ports must be ordered by 10 a.m. or 11 a.m. the day before it will be required.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate has been debating a statement brought down last week by the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis. I do not want to go into that debate fully, but there are some aspects of it that deserve airing in the Senate. The Minister said in his statement that he was implementing reforms in government enterprises, and I welcome that. I particularly welcome it for Telecom Australia, which has laid down a profit of $776.2m and, with a bit of creative accounting--
—Order! Senator Boswell, under the Standing Orders, you are not meant to be speaking on the ministerial statement. I suggest that you seek leave of the Senate.
—I seek leave, Mr President, to speak on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under Telecom's profit and loss account, a profit of $776.2m is shown. There is depreciation for services for life charges of $311m; charges in treatment of expenditure, net reduction in depreciation of $125.2m; stock write-downs of $38.2m and bad debts written off of $59.5m, with a total of $533.9m. If that were added to the previous profit of $776.2m, the aggregate amount would be around $1.3 billion. That is a very healthy profit. I do not deny any organisation the right to make those profits but, having made those profits, Telecom has a responsibility to fulfil its social obligation. I ask the Minister for Community Affairs, Senator Bolkus, who is in the chamber tonight, to take this on board.

SPEECH.PARA: There are still 8,000 people in western Queensland, central Queensland and, I believe, in the north-west of New South Wales, who are either on party lines or who do not have telephones at all. Up to six people use one party line, which is inconvenient, to say the least, for rural producers. As announced in the 1987 May statement, the Government decided that Telecom would pay sales tax and excise tax. Telecom's response was that it would not finish the rural telephone connection service, and that it would extend the time to complete that service by two years. A government instrumentality which is making a profit of $1.3 billion has an obligation to fulfil the telephone needs of rural people. Some rural people who do not have a telephone have been waiting for up to nine years to have one installed. Meanwhile Telecom has chased contracts all over the world. It is ironic that Telecom is putting phones into Saudi Arabia, yet it cannot put phones into rural Australia. That is a dereliction of its obligation. I ask the Minister to take this matter on board and to take it up with Mr Willis.

Out of 5,000 services that should have been completed this year, only 3,000 have been completed because of wet weather; of course, Telecom cannot be responsible for that. Mr Duffy and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised that these telephone connections would be made by 1990. However, there are people who are still waiting for telephone services. That date was extended to 1992 because of the lack of funds, according to Telecom. It is a contradiction in terms when a government instrumentality makes $1.3 billion, sets out to win contracts on the world market, for which it should be commended, and agrees to put telephone into Saudi Arabia and Third World countries, yet our rural producers are being treated worse than people in Third World countries. It is a shocking state of affairs. The Government has to address this problem quickly.

People have been allocated automatic lines and have been told that they would receive a telephone in the next two years. They are not allowed to put in their own private line. So some of these people have been waiting for four years to obtain a telephone. They are willing to pay for their own telephones, to bring in their own lines, but they are not allowed to do so. Other lines have become so disused and are in such a state of disrepair that it is almost impossible to receive any telephone calls through them. People have been told that they will receive phones `next year' or `the year after' and so it goes on. Some people have been told for nine years that they will get a telephone, yet they have not received a telephone. They are supposed to have the telephones by 1992. People fear now that Telecom will not even meet the 1992 commitment.

As I have said, I welcome any reform of government business enterprises. But the Minister cannot be serious about any reform when he is denying 8,000 rural producers in western Queensland and north-western New South Wales a telephone in 1989. I plead with the responsible Minister to do something about this urgently.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, upon notice, on 8 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the premise on which the granting of Patent No. 511.771 was based.
(2) Is the Minister able to confirm that a patent has been granted on a ratio.
(3) What are the benefits to the company involved in the granting of this patent.
(4) What are the disadvantages to the community.
(5) Can the Minister confirm that there is no provision to appeal against the granting of a patent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Patents Act 1952 specifies the criteria by which all patent applications are examined prior to the granting of a patent. Thus the premise upon which the granting of patent No. 511.711 was based is that the application was considered by the Patent Office to have met these criteria. In very general terms the conditions specified by the Act are that the invention is fully described, including the best method of performance known to the applicant; that the invention claimed is new; and that the subject matter is suitable to be patented.

(2) The Commissioner of Patents has informed me that the invention relates to excavating teeth for use in machines such as front end loaders, mining equipment and the like and that the claims of this patent do not define a ratio itself, but rather a device characterised by certain components having a prescribed dimensional ratio. Although a ratio is not patentable, the fact that a device is distinguished by characteristics which are defined in terms of a ratio is not itself a bar to the granting of a patent.

(3) and (4) The same as with any patent that is granted. The role of the Commissioner is limited to the consideration of particular issues relating to entitlement to a patent and, even in relation to those issues, the Commissioner is under a legal compulsion to grant a patent unless it is clear that the patent would be held invalid. It is not within the role of the Commissioner of Patents to consider the benefits of a particular invention beyond the point at which the entitlement to a patent is established nor any possible disadvantages to the community.

(5) No. Upon ``acceptance'' of the complete specification prior to the grant of a patent, the Commissioner advertises his acceptance in the Australian Official Journal of Patents and this allows third parties to mount an opposition proceeding before the Commissioner in which the third parties may raise a range of issues bearing on the entitlement to a patent. Further, there are provisions for the revocation of patents by the courts on the grounds of invalidity at the suit of third parties. Invalidity of the patent is also a defence to a legal action for infringement.
